When you look at a three dimensional space , in a three dimensional space the one and three will not be in the same plane .	4.22468729879171

The specificity can have a very large variety and one must also appreciate that the specificity of these enzymes in terms of their catalytic action is attributed to the active sites .	3.97659926730498

As we also saw in the last lecture where the catalytic function was studied , the catalytic functions of the enzymes are responsible for the role played by active site .	3.4680091114237204

The specificity also is the result of the conformation of active site .	4.761746087272109

The active sites must be considered as consisting of two different parts : the binding sites and the functional sites .	3.906573577791697

Another factor of stereospecificity is that prediction of stereospecificity by any ground rule is difficult .	2.548711990217316

We are able to know the specificity only while we determine the amount of product formed on a particular substrate .	4.286419014729612

In the case of a chemical reaction to take place you have ?	4.367797445096853

G value , the free energy change of the reaction , which will give you an idea whether the reaction will take place in the forward direction or reverse direction or there will be an equilibrium established .	4.277980107775745

But in the case of specificity of enzyme action the only way to understand the specificity is that we monitor the product formed on the substrate and then we can say yes this is specific to the substrates .	3.8766216369276405

Once we find the specificity then we can propose hypothesis or mechanisms by which the stereo specificity can be explained .	3.5633637836240246

But there are no other thermodynamic or kinetic interpretations which can be applied to the specificity .	4.285576992977052

That is another feature .	7.997584406314974

One of the most interesting features of enzyme specificity is their stereochemical specificity because when there is a single molecule the functional groups are different , active sites also may have different functional groups to bind them and the steps can be understood .	2.8979592449771316

But to understand the stereochemical specificity that how enzyme is able to identify the two different stereoisomers , the minimum requirements on the function of an active sites was proposed by Oxten as early as 1948 .	2.810352392208291

He proposed that at least there must be three sites of different points of interaction on an enzyme active site .	3.058382333175828

Here the bottom one is the whole enzyme molecule and the dotted line represents the active sites .	4.078489785738495

I must again remind you that this is not a planar site .	5.2382233642251945

It is a three dimensional structure on the surface of the enzyme molecule and not that all the amino acids on these active sites are located in proximity in the amino acid chain .	3.949491848953854

They are brought in proximity by folding of the enzyme protein .	4.284602940576879

At least it is understood that as proposed by Oxten that the enzyme active site also must have at least three different functional residues on the active site which can interact with the substrate molecule .	3.314647820848803

These three interacting sites let us consider that they are the interaction sites .	5.114599517824701

Minimum two of them must be binding sites , out of the three at least two on which the substrate molecule can bind to the active site and put the substrate in a very fixed orientation .	4.520813924728556

We have two points .	8.56792333288512

We are holding the enzyme molecule bound to the substrate .	5.559597392515843

This binding has to be oriented in such a way that the third functional group on the substrate which has to undergo reaction is brought in vicinity of the catalytic site .	3.7207487394845664

That is one minimum requirement for explaining the specificity of enzyme action that there must be minimum three sites which interact between the enzyme and substrate .	2.7033936568608086

Two of them must be at least binding sites and the substrate binds on these two sites to the enzyme molecule whereby it orients the substrate molecule along with the enzyme such that the reactive functional group and the reactive site on enzymes active site come in proximity or in vicinity .	3.2567612510283785

Of course the various mechanisms that we discussed it could be a strain on the bond , it could be the entropic factors and it could be various covalent interactions or electro static interactions that might play a role to carry out the catalysis .	3.3891517793658794

But as far as the binding is concerned , it has to be specific in terms of bringing the functional group on which the reaction has to take place .	4.977336910631696

I will try to explain the same points with a particular example of oxidation of a D - amino acid , using D - amino acid oxidase where you have this amino group which undergoes reaction .	3.306787068627799

In the molecule the carboxylic group and the methyl group are bound onto the enzyme active site .	3.7832455880874196

The one which binds methyl group will be hydrophobic in nature and this will be bound predominantly by electrostatic interactions .	3.483394872777029

These two binding brings the catalytic sites in close vicinity of the amino group which is available for reaction and the catalytic reaction can take place .	4.079410826113901

This is your D - amino acid .	5.694765705606286

You consider corresponding L - amino acid on which the location of H and amino group will be different .	3.8294617609858848

Even if the binding takes place this amino group cannot come in the vicinity of the catalytic site , cannot approach the catalytic site and no reaction can occur .	2.975881315193784

That is why the concept of three interacting sites fairly explains the position of enzymes catalytic action as far as their specificity with respect to stereo isomers is concerned .	2.726648595133858

The situation in the case of different substrates which can have different functional groups can be much simpler .	4.274414124085321

Because the binding site will bind two of the functional group , the third functional group which has to undergo reaction will be only recognized by the catalytic site and no other functional group will be recognized and so reaction cannot take place .	3.394209549864911

One of the very early understanding that as early as 1890 , Oxten proposed such a mechanism which puts a limit just like in the case of rate of a reaction we have a thermo dynamic limit .	3.2253972315520394

If there is a reversible reaction , these are the kind of limits like equilibrium constant will be achieved at this point and so on .	4.184254298689014

Similarly Oxten proposed a limit that minimum there must be three points of interaction .	3.1420749521976914

In case of very hard core specific enzymes the point of interaction can be more than three also .	3.312172032714347

Instead to two binding sites there can be three binding sites also .	3.62508299228373

That depends on the requirement for the enzyme .	7.9835366998512445

As early as in 1890 , Fischer proposed Lock and key hypothesis which explained the enzyme specificity .	2.7304472234584014

This explanation of the specificity was purely based on certain observations and analysis of the situation mostly mental and not analytical because not many analytical facilities were available .	2.4937045131829407

It was suggested that the enzyme active site and the substrate have a conformation which is analogous to lock and the key .	3.7694903147235617

That means the Ö. .. on the key are exactly fitting to the site at which it has to interact with the lock .	3.4304828795055053

They are exactly fitting .	8.42166589764506

This is the active site which is analogues to the lock .	5.399183195102249

The binding sites on the substrate come in proximity or bind to the binding site on the active site of the enzyme molecule .	4.20775636124135

Similarly the reactive group on the substrate comes in contact with two catalytic sites and then once the reacting groups gets entangled with the reaction sites on the active sites , the binding is complete and it can exhibit the catalytic function to take place .	3.391994078890341

Now that was the understanding and they also very clearly understood at that time that both substrate as well as the active site on the enzyme molecule have rigid structures .	3.2815613926274465

There is no question of change if they are rigid in nature .	4.2280599390887

They are just like a lock and key ; there is no flexibility .	5.173730920962188

If there is slight modification either in the conformation of the key it will not fit to the lock and thereby the reaction will not occur .	3.5542543337836965

In fact the Fischerís lock and key arrangement was not based on any of the analytical probes .	3.2684274468613848

It was only a conceptual explanation given because at that time , one thing we must appreciate that , not a very large number of enzyme reactions were understood .	3.436480121970951

Even the stereospecificity was not clearly understood .	4.325794671476197

It was mostly some very common reactions like hydrolysis of sucrose to glucose and fructose , most of the hydrolytic reactions were understood and this mechanism proposed only such a macro understanding that the substrate and the enzyme have rigid conformations which are complementary to each other and which fit in strictly .	2.614193565410799

At the time of Fischerís Lock and key mechanism , the most understood enzymatic reaction was hydrolysis of sucrose by invertase to glucose and fructose and obviously they would look into variety of other sugars like lactose on which the enzyme could not act .	2.413185507101395

They could distinguish between the conformations of the substrate molecule and have much detailed information .	3.721191530953038

But still the surprising thing is that the concept is not totally invalid today .	3.866073687099225

In many cases it can still explain the whole theory or whole requirements of specificity .	2.8064261351635555

Then came number of other developments and particularly the development with respect to the availability of analytical data on enzyme substrate binding .	3.27884827568458

People were able to make enzyme substrate complexes and their analogs , analyze them by NMR or EPR or variety of analytical physical tools and they found that when the enzyme and substrate do bind there is a significant change in the conformation .	2.8729890985445143

The conformation is neither the same what was available in the case of enzyme molecule .	4.741980629818199

So there is something going on and keeping those data in view Koshland proposed a hypothesis as late as 1958 what we understand today as Koshland induced fit model .	2.332993485412268

His proposal was a slight modification of the lock and key arrangement .	3.605134895490123

He said that the substrate has a rigid conformation with its binding sites and the functional site or the reacting groups present at a particular conformation .	3.929035214465615

But the enzyme active site is not a rigid conformation .	6.91158655375887

Itís a flexible conformation .	6.038849107535983

That means as soon as the substrate comes in the proximity of the enzyme active site , initial binding takes place .	3.970481820754082

The enzyme active site binds onto the substrate molecule .	4.705726690555999

For example this is a functional group and this let us say is substrate .	6.552692637875202

The enzyme active site as soon as it comes in proximity , it wraps around the substrate molecule .	3.8781175487503585

He gave an example that the interaction between the substrate and the enzyme is some thing like a hand and the woolen glove .	3.462359882828277

You wear a woolen glove .	5.638624637790718

Your hand is analogues to substrate .	6.301122704107934

Then when you put in the woolen glove it exactly fits into hand depending upon the conformation of your fingers .	2.986548926270641

Everything goes in line and interacts with different fingers and one can be comfortable and the reaction can proceed .	3.2665922728113257

For example you have two binding sites .	6.54198117017034

The free active site on the free enzyme molecule without interaction with the substrate has its particular configuration where the catalytic sites and binding sites are distantly located .	3.5621670230783486

As soon as the binding groups come in contact with the binding site as they have interacted here the active site undergo a change in conformation and this catalytic sites are brought in proximity so as to wrap around the reactive group on the substrate molecule and then the ultimate conformation of the enzyme substrate complex which can use one of the mechanism by which catalytic reaction can take place , can be applied .	3.425087044071452

Such a mechanism very effectively can explain the high degree of the specificity for the enzyme molecule .	3.874032943726044

In the case of induced fit hypothesis one can also appreciate that in certain reactions for example even if there is reaction contaminant in the reaction mixture which are very similar to nature in the terms of their conformation to the actual substrate , they will not be able to interact .	3.438183593636752

For example in the case of lock and key mechanism if there are molecules which are similar in conformation they might be able to partly interact with the catalytic site and influence the reaction .	3.4674871422063647

Whereas in the case of the induced fit mechanism once the enzyme active site is totally wrapped around the substrate , the reaction sites are not at all available for any other contaminant and therefore there is no chance of any other contaminant present in the substrate molecule to be able to interact with the enzyme molecule .	3.465235581339911

One of the most typical examples of enzyme catalyzed reaction which was responsible for the elucidation of induced fit model was the hexose kinase .	2.9757679286944283

The phosphorylation of D - hexose at the expense of ATP to hexose - 6 - phosphate .	3.1019251649535655

In the absence of hexose , the ATP hydrolyzed extremely slowly .	3.3856280281496702

The hexose is present in the proximity of the enzyme , the enzyme will bring both hexose and ATP along with the binding sites and then it can flop around the two molecules and the reaction can take place in a very fast speed .	4.579678743211116

The induced fit mechanism can also explain very clearly the bimolecular reactions which were difficult to understand as far as the lock and key arrangement .	2.752015461265263

Lock and key arrangement was very easily able to explain the unimolecular reactions .	3.683064192725711

But in case where two substrates are involved as in the case of hexose phosphorylation , the role of hexose and ATP both participating at the binding site for the reaction to occur could be explained using induced fit mechanism .	2.844857761677615

If you consider all the three explanations that we have considered today like Oxtenís three site interaction model , lock and key mechanism of Fischer or induced fit hypothesis of Koshland , when we talk about the specificity they donít link specificity by any means to the catalytic function .	2.779135110888724

They consider specificity totally in isolation .	4.891387304636473

None of them is able to provide a suitable explanation for the catalytic function .	4.2429357706123465

When we discussed the various ways in which the enzymes are able to catalyze reactions we understood that binding of the enzyme to the substrate was a very important feature in the acceleration of the reaction rate .	4.4811674713713465

Binding of the substrate to the enzyme involves some expenditure of energy that is the binding energy involved in it which ultimately gives you an advantage in the reduction in activation energy and there is an initial energy .	3.5987074505318923

It is also presumed that this binding energy is not totally a wasteful energy for the enzyme reactions .	3.7145452751974233

A part of this binding energy also contributes to specificity and therefore if you look at the effect of strains that are developed , a hypothesis which is called as a strain that means at the stage of binding we understood that in the case of lock and key mechanism they are rigid .	3.059900922803307

But we might assume that the active site is almost complementary to the substrate molecule but is not exactly complementary , a situation which is slightly closer to lock and key mechanism not in absolute terms that they are complementary but they are not exactly complementary .	3.1298096618393783

Therefore when the substrate and the enzyme active sites are brought in proximity and the binding takes place between the substrate and the enzyme active site it brings in a strain .	3.9612697591014423

You see that the active site here unlike the lock and key mechanism is not exactly complementary .	3.7863155047423005

This slot is slightly longer and therefore while the binding takes place it makes a sort of a strain onto the reactive group and it is analogues to the mechanism which we proposed for catalytic function that means strain mechanism and which contributes to reduction in the enthalpic component of the free energy of activation .	2.848479046307708

During this interaction of the enzyme active site with the substrate , the strain produced onto the reactive group as a result of binding process is responsible for specificity as well as part catalytic function .	4.084649190318727

These strain developed may contribute towards the reduction in activation energy but it is a result of binding process .	4.232041417368071

This binding process brings in the specificity and the nature of the binding site or the active site on the enzyme molecule is slightly complementary or of the similar type but not exactly complementary and the complementarity comes only after binding has taken place which results in the distortion of the reacting group and then the complementary comes in .	3.0162587344857252

So that is called the strain effect which can take into account both catalytic function as well as specificity .	3.727903658991861

The strain effects have been discussed when we were talking about the ways in which the enzyme reduces energy of activation .	3.1993885004501226

The strain on the reacting group was one of the mechanisms .	5.484740825732595

Because the active site is not exactly complementary , after the substrate approaches the binding sites it forces the reacting group to develop a strain so as to bring in complementary to the catalytic sites .	3.4410898577877176

Then only these catalytic sites can combine .	4.593630972979386

Otherwise if it was totally complementary without the strain then the reacting group will come down some where here and no reaction can take place .	2.7228730329834407

Only when a strain is developed the reaction takes place and the reaction takes place with the suitable degree of specificity introducing to it .	3.1250943035170953

Because the binding has to take place and the binding process requires a strain onto the substrate molecule so that it comes in proximity of the catalytic sites .	4.406982513741743

If strain is not developed it will remain in the binding site but not at the active site .	3.8474081486717586

The enzyme will not be able to provide the catalytic function .	5.8739299069528395

Like in the case of other mechanisms or other hypothesis proposed for specificity while we are able to explain that binding will take place , the functional group comes in proximity to the reacting group but it doesnít explain if the reaction will take place or not .	3.332355808819395

Just coming in proximity could provide you an effect what we discussed like high substrate concentration in the proximity of the active site but does not explain you how the energy of activation is induced .	3.03749165830532

Here in this case this also explains how the energy of activation is reduced in terms of its enthalpic contribution .	4.279330448660259

Another thing which is very well related to this strain mechanism is the mechanism what we understand as transition state stabilization .	3.49355208510981

Here in the case the effect is almost very similar to what we call as strain effect but while the substrate enzyme binding takes place at the active site there are still some unfavorable interactions at the active site of the substrate That means the substrate molecule in the vicinity of the active site is not very comfortable in terms of its interactions .	3.625764530353186

The presence of certain unfavorable interactions at the active site for the substrate when the binding has taken place tends to distort the substrate molecule in the direction so that the enzyme substrate complex tends to become complementary to the transition state .	3.4559916490803793

In the first characteristic feature of catalysis we saw that the transition state is complementary to enzyme substrate complex and not the substrate .	3.5685391721445696

The enzyme is complementary to enzyme substrate complex , the enzyme active site and not to the substrate itself .	4.732438563284345

Therefore the role of the binding of substrate molecule to the enzyme at the binding site , the substrate doesnít remain very comfortable .	4.671518510980713

There are many unfavorable interactions that is present there and they distort the substrate molecule so that these enzyme substrate binding approaches towards that of transition complex .	2.933931765384443

The first step is binding of the binding sites onto the active site .	4.9186408060252695

Once that takes place , still the catalytic sites are not approached by the functional groups which are likely to undergo reaction .	3.8082539484889577

But in addition to the binding site there are many unfavorable interactions present between the substrate and the active site .	4.496695743122379

Consider three different functional groups .	8.637667913972201

In addition to that on the active site there will be many more amino acid residues which will be in the proximity and they might provide some kind of unfavorable interactions .	4.120620979746782

Now these interactions tend to distort the substrate and this distortion of the substrate is favored towards reaching the transition state .	3.385104988673774

In other words we are developing a strain onto the substrate molecule so that the substrate molecule reacting groups are coming in proximity to the catalytic site .	3.734533826356935

In the hypothesis of the transition state stabilization it is stated that the unfavorable interactions available at the active sites on the substrate favors the distortion of the substrate in such a way that the final enzyme substrate complex approaches the structure of that of transition state .	3.4358120048155576

Because partly you have already taken up that path .	4.180659717437349

That is what happened in strain development also .	5.32205480971167

So these are some of the major mechanisms that have been proposed for explaining the specificity of the enzyme action .	4.277810320670044

It is over all rate of reaction in terms of rate of product formation that indicates whether the enzyme is specific to a substrate or not .	4.615477854752608

What is the order of specificity , to what extent it would be specific , what are the impurities which can interfere in the specificity they are all related to the results of reaction that is the rate of formation of product .	3.9608345660058273

The specificity also has a very significant role in terms of the industrial applications of enzymes .	5.25772197730886

We must also appreciate that while in the case of the catalytic function we understand that if the rate of reaction is increased its usefulness as a industrial catalyst is also very high because higher the rate of reaction you can very efficiently use it for industrial purposes .	3.641944109501841

But what is the role of specificity .	11.069917981813472

The specificity in fact has both negative as well as positive role .	3.9468608399512006

Positive role in the sense , that you can restrict the formation of any of the by - products .	5.44599778535335

Even if your feed history substrate is impure to some extent you will know that only reaction which can be catalyzed specifically by that enzyme which you are providing will take place and no other reaction will take place .	3.186208909097061

Even the side products formed by action of water usually most of the organic chemists consider water for organic chemical reactions as the culprit because it can lead to variety of side products .	2.555620564477597

So all the side products can be absent , which can make our life comfortable as far as the purification of the product is concerned .	3.329928452578058

That means many of the enzymes cannot be produced on a very massive scale because the requirement will be only for single reaction and therefore for a single reaction the requirement will not be very large .	3.3280253875044137

We have so far seen that the performance of idealized continuous flow immobilized enzyme reactors depends primarily on the reaction kinetics and the basic assumption for idealized reactors was that the immobilized enzyme preparation does not experience any mass transfer or partitioning effects .	3.0231064321572756

The immobilized enzymes experience in addition to the catalytic activity three major external effects during immobilization .	3.172249317324751

One is the conformational changes as a result of which the basic turn over number of the enzyme might be altered ; even the value of Michaelis Menten constant may also be altered .	4.22506509781322

The other effect is partitioning of substrate and product which also results in alteration in the Km value of the enzyme reaction .	3.7493875943188613

Then the third effect was mass transfer of substrate and product and this mass transfer as we noticed was at two levels .	2.781219289348716

Or in a very broader sense if you consider the reaction in immobilized enzyme reactor it will imply that in addition to the biochemical reaction there will be four more resistances involved .	4.091551803376494

One will be transport of the substrate from the bulk to the surface ; from surface the substrate has to transport to the site of the enzymatic reaction which means the enzyme molecules that are located throughout the immobilized enzyme particle and then the reverse process that means the product produced as a result of biochemical reaction has to transport back from the carrier interior to the surface .	3.5564394305770066

Therefore the two major matrices which provide resistance to the over all reaction is the thin film around the immobilized enzyme particle and the whole matrix itself and the pores in which the immobilized enzyme is distributed .	3.930435862998244

I think you will also recall what we had seen earlier ; the diagram in which you have a thin film , a stationary film around the particle .	3.6849805775834112

This film thickness will depend on various physical properties of the fluid .	4.6896081597579595

Then you have enzyme distributed all over the pores in the particle and the substrate has to transport from the surface to those materials and similarly reverse .	3.5128891635168196

I like you to have a look at the substrate gradient .	6.413322943837077

If you consider that this regime is the thin film then from the bulk there might be a linear substrate gradient across the thin film and the concentration might drop at the surface and from the surface to the interior of the particle that means to center of the particle there might be again a gradient as a result of biochemical reaction .	3.0249094518022854

Because the substrate will be consumed and as the substrate progresses through the particle depth the concentration will be dropping down and there are two possibilities .	3.601508062378786

One is that you have a rather more convenient situation that from here the substrate concentration goes like a profile like this which is more favorable in the sense that around the whole particle there is some substrate available for biochemical reaction to take place .	3.3865231651818744

On the other hand it can also happen that the substrate concentration drops to zero earlier than the substrate has reached to the middle point and therefore this portion which is highlighted here is deprived of the substrate and the overall reaction rate that is observed apparently is much smaller .	2.9653652116514713

There might be coupled partitioning effects as I have shown in the lower figures in the gradient lower but basically these are the three major issues : biochemical reaction , external film diffusion and internal pore diffusion that are encountered in the case of an immobilized enzyme reactor which need to be considered while we consider the reactor performance .	2.8685426278625235

Although in the idealized reactor performance we have not taken into account but in the actual reactors they need to be taken care while analyzing the steady state reactor performance .	3.404471312417013

An important feature of the performance of immobilized enzyme reactor is that one needs to identify the limiting rate , the step which has a limiting rate the lowest reaction rate .	3.9504161902290975

That means a comparison between the biochemical reaction rate and the rate of diffusion by the Ö .	5.110246278896478

film diffusion or the pore diffusion .	7.132774005664579

One must be able to identify by some analytical method or experimental method that which is the rate limiting step and we must analyze or design our reactor keeping in view the rate limiting step .	2.9489884928177807

Consider that we have an immobilized enzyme preparation with a very high enzyme loading .	5.9269738669553895

That means the preparation is highly reactive , the rate of reaction can be very high and the rate of diffusion is slow either because of the Ö. .. of the substrate or the chemical nature of the matrix .	4.541285545950613

If the rate of diffusion is slow in that case the diffusion will become rate limiting .	4.215059690697291

If the difference between the rate of diffusion and the rate of biochemical reaction are too large then one of them will be the controlling factor and the whole reactor design must be based on that particular step .	3.8592295015906064

Alternatively if you take an immobilized enzyme preparation to be very lean loading that means the loading is very low and the catalyst is not very reactive or alternatively the enzyme Ö .	4.771997949998109

that turn over number is very low and the rate of diffusion is very fast .	5.512791219475047

In that case diffusion effectively will not play a key role in the reactor design and the reactor design can be easily taken care by idealized reactor performance considering the reaction kinetics in picture .	3.5460565715480326

Based on these three parameters particularly as I mentioned earlier the conformational changes , mass transfer effects and the partitioning effects , the kinetic parameters for immobilized enzyme are classified into three major classes .	3.029214110348757

One is intrinsic parameters which are the same as that of soluble enzyme which means no partitioning in a soluble system , no mass transfer limitations ; the sole parameter is the reaction rate and they are called the intrinsic parameters .	3.690481746979365

If we consider the rate expression our classical rate expression v = k2E0S / Km + S will apply to the situation .	3.9421109723246093

The second class of the kinetic parameters is defined as inherent parameter .	4.4439473393512605

Inherent kinetic parameters are those which are obtained as a result of conformational changes only .	3.9695379751229343

That means they are dependent on the method of immobilization .	4.786262653408869

That means the kind of reactants we have used in immobilization , the kind of matrix we have used in immobilization and whatever the interaction between the matrix and the enzyme under the conditions of immobilization , whatever conformational changes have taken place , whatever kinetic parameters have been modified as a result of this interaction are considered in the inherent parameters and we define them as ví = kí2E0S / Kím + S The parameters are just given prime and the inherent parameters have no role to play or not much can be done during the reactor design or reactor operation .	2.6283941119832033

They are the final property of the immobilized enzyme , kinetic property .	5.2882126987832745

I must again clearly stress that the inherent parameters do not consider the diffusional effects or the partitioning effects .	3.0716772938272796

That means if the system has no partitioning behavior or no diffusional limitations ; diffusion will be there because there is a phase difference .	3.4472576219029145

But if the diffusion is not the rate limiting step or rather it is quite fast compared to the reaction rate the inherent parameters will be useful .	4.080912644551675

On the other hand in case the mass transfer effects are very severe they can be totally rate limiting steps .	3.5113383835477254

That means the whole rate of reaction is controlled by the rate of diffusion .	5.014611898233445

Biochemical reaction is very fast and the rate of diffusion is slow .	6.259507809370888

The rates may not be absolutely very far apart if the two are very comparable in that case we need to consider our apparent reaction velocity as equal to vapp = kí2E0S / Kappm + S Here when we say that the apparent parameters are those which can be modified , which can be taken care by reactor operation .	3.3733390001397425

That means as I mentioned some time earlier that the thickness of the film can be controlled by either increased linear flow velocity in the case of packed bed reactor or by increasing the agitation speed in the case of CSTR .	3.1763767090252637

Similarly on the other hand the internal flow diffusion also can be regulated by controlling the particle size .	3.858124010386351

That means the distance of transport of the substrate into the immobilized enzyme particle is minimized or reduced .	3.9504841048379786

Therefore the substrate will be available all across the particle and thus can be modified .	4.2502967191981575

Therefore they are called apparent parameters and in all possible analysis we must be interested in the apparent parameters , Kappm .	3.1681431512731955

That will dictate if you want to consider diffusional limitations also as a part of our analysis .	3.6529501461041463

By the experimental reactor operations in the laboratory many people have noticed that diffusional limitations play a key role either by varying the agitation speed in the case of a CSTR or by the varying the linear flow velocity in the case of PFR , the rate of reaction can be improved and so diffusional limitations can be overcome if any .	2.5829755593805026

You would recall that in our previous lecture we had discussed what are immobilized enzymes , why should we immobilize enzymes and what are the requirements of immobilization of enzymes and the three major requirements – a soluble enzyme and the carrier and method of immobilization .	3.275393252269936

We were looking into their characteristics .	4.823996865493523

The soluble enzyme , as we all know , required for immobilization must have certain properties that is it should possess high specific activity and also desirable functional properties that are required for use of immobilization enzyme .	2.587395570513198

A large numbers of methods of immobilization are reported in literature .	3.765015417674944

Most of them can be classified simply into three major categories one is carrier binding methods .	3.0974355161028377

Typical examples are adsorption ; covalent binding and we will be discussing them in detail .	4.258415187403337

The other method is cross linking .	5.214914902263592

The enzymes themselves posses a large number of functional groups which can be made to react to each other , thereby aggregating the molecules and making them insoluble in water .	3.520904900448157

Just to repeat the cross linking refers to linking more than one enzyme molecule through their functional residues present on their surface .	2.9058092122982395

Most of the enzyme molecules will have a large number of functional residues .	8.242395135380788

They may be hydrophobic groups ; they may be electrostatic charges or other functional residues .	3.199918368642127

They can be linked under certain conditions , under ambient condition so that their inactivation is not allowed and on those conditions aggregates of the enzymes can be made which can function as immobilized enzymes .	2.770119356609724

The third type of method is entrapment methods where the enzymes are entrapped within a matrix .	3.7822705752336567

It could be a gel , it could be a micro capsule and there by you could provide them an environment which is very analogues to a living cell and then use them as immobilize preparations .	3.129123426543519

You can see that a large number of methods are available .	4.772735572577618

Under each category also there are number of methods and we need to choose a suitable method for a particular purpose .	3.9750026578588424

There are no general rules .	6.137845027409696

It often goes by trial and error and some available information .	2.9457963467563886

Out of the methods available , which we will discuss subsequently , if we have to choose an immobilization method to use for a specific application there are four distinct parameters which should be looked into .	3.1569925018865943

The first and probably the foremost is yield of immobilization .	3.2443072070009635

That means during immobilization procedure what is the loss of enzyme activity because there is no method which can give you hundred percent recovery of the enzyme activity that you have put into the system .	4.238715267642762

There will be some enzyme which will be deactivated or lost during the immobilization and the loss of enzyme activity has to be kept minimum for all practical purposes .	3.446149882800608

When you consider the yield of an immobilization , it is basically a term which can be considered on the basis of material balance .	4.57397877005359

This is the total picture of all the species that will be available and the loss of enzyme activity , soluble enzyme activity let us say as E0 , residual enzyme activity as Er and the immobilize enzyme activity as Ei , then the loss of enzyme activity is E0 - Er - Ei / E0 That is the loss or rather fractional loss of enzyme activity .	2.830487718610591

Of the total enzyme activity , the activity is distributed into two fractions - the immobilized enzyme as well as the uncoupled enzyme in the residue and these two theoretically should combine and form the total value of E0 but very often at the end of a method there is some balance left and the balance is the loss due to deactivation during immobilization .	2.8524051919863016

The yield of the immobilization is defined as r = Ei / E0 - Er Very often there is confusion in reporting these terms and that ’ s why I have tried to put them in the form of an expression .	2.887598052344863

While we talk of a yield we must keep into mind the residual activity in the supernatant .	3.3095501519669566

Its not in the total enzyme because part of the enzyme has been recovered in the supernatant which if desired can be recycled .	4.22090280878337

Therefore the yield will be the activity which is recovered in the immobilized form divided by E0 - Ei in the residue .	3.395124073632977

When you talk of Ei that is the activity of immobilized enzyme you are measuring in terms of the activity only .	5.410989574056429

So that means it is active .	6.8181830725157155

Right in the beginning I made it very clear that when we talk of quantification of enzyme it is just not a physical quantity like mass or concentration .	2.840084443658721

It is the functional property .	6.367028247361145

Its quantity is functional property and the activity represents functional activity .	3.4220604302980098

We are not measuring Ei in terms of protein contents .	4.993751295300569

I am measuring all these terms E0 , Er and Ei in terms of catalytic activity .	3.6471280963862345

So it is functional .	7.986527145428291

This loss , if it is a let us a physical quantity like protein concentration the balance will be perfect .	3.444443951761444

You cannot account for any loss of protein in the system .	4.014046866079002

It is only the loss of activity because of the conformational changes .	6.248092824896729

The other factor which is important to be considered is enzyme loading .	4.389280929830988

When we talk about specific activity higher the specific activity , enzyme is catalytically better .	3.3303360547958123

Similarly in case of enzyme loading we talk of international units per gram of carrier or if you take into account the bulk density of the carrier you can also say international units per ml of carrier bed that means you pack the carrier into a bed , packed bed , and then consider the volume .	3.1380194053425834

So enzyme loading is another factor and we want a preparation with as high loading as possible theoretically .	3.1398590128337194

The enzyme loading will also have a direct linkage with the mass transfer limitations .	4.107701690324594

We will see subsequently how mass transfer and catalytic activity are linked .	3.562639388469698

Then the third parameter which is important to look at is storage and operational stability .	4.249642758575193

As I mentioned that we have to look for enzyme and one of the major advantage of immobilized enzyme is that they can be reused , they can be repeatedly used , continuously used and therefore they must possess a much higher stability than the soluble enzyme .	3.9709668813483323

This stability is not only in terms of use but also during storage and this parameter is usually expressed in terms of half life .	3.5460809317179325

Either half life during storage that means the time in which the activity loses to fifty percent of the original activity or during use in a continuous reactor or in a batch reactor that is in terms of number of cycles .	3.9035671982012032

You can express in that term .	5.190443065664458

That will be only restricted when you are talking of a fibre or a surface .	4.414872315277995

The most commonly used matrices are beads - the spherical particles and that ’ s why gram or volume and they are packed in a packed bed .	3.0032610038562546

When I say per ml I am referring to a parameter which is analogues to use in a packed bed .	3.6901460616015207

But if you this in a surface , in fibre or in a film you can also express in terms of a surface area .	3.7173329943006084

That is always allowed .	8.46253857077368

But for all industrial application the surface excepting for biosensors and things like that which are very specific applications , for industrial catalysis it is used in the form of particles and used with the packed bed .	2.9686108858863665

We will discuss those aspects subsequently .	4.848562318224201

Iu / m2 also is a feasible parameter that we can define .	5.0427123553390825

For example in the case of adsorption you require a carrier .	4.771590023155096

If suppose you want to adsorb by ionic binding , you need a carrier which possesses charges .	3.8139289699585843

Similarly if you want a covalent binding you need a carrier which possesses certain functional residues which can be coupled to the enzyme .	3.906883439451241

So each method will have some limitations on the choice of carrier and therefore the cost of the carrier .	4.122358944126323

Another parameter which must be taken into account is regenerability .	4.099858987389123

Very often even after the immobilized enzyme preparation has been exhausted during use the carrier can be recovered and reused .	3.384866705877237

So the cost of the carrier must be taken into account in terms of per cycle not the absolute cost .	4.137808402150288

You must differentiate between the absolute cost and cost of the carrier per cycle .	3.7514945587846174

Because many of the carriers although expensive , can be used for a long period and in number of repeated cycles .	4.240156599288301

Therefore they are still acceptable and desirable because of other desirable property .	3.0446308904070136

The first and probably the simplest method of immobilization is by adsorption .	4.033312013532876

The adsorption method is a very broad , non - specific method and it involves binding of the enzyme to the surface of an insoluble carrier that has not been specifically functionalized for covalent coupling .	3.3166280990447823

I must mark here particularly the phrase “specifically functionalized for covalent coupling ” .	2.705374872025055

This probably gives you an idea that this is a very broad non - specific method .	5.180650232941954

If we consider all the carrier binding methods excluding those which involve covalent linkage , rest of all the bindings , interactions between the carrier and the enzyme are covered under the term called adsorption .	2.904118226252635

A very broad based method which involves a number of non - specific , multivariant , reversible interactions between the enzyme and the carrier at mild conditions .	3.388686292867999

The second point also builts in a number of phrases .	4.143466447880445

For example the interactions that are involved are non - specific , very often more than one interaction is involved in a particular method , multivariant that means more than one physical property is employed .	3.188251149032483

In most cases the methods based on adsorption are reversible in nature .	3.5081423779924283

That means under certain conditions while you can adsorb the enzyme on to a carrier you can also create condition by which you can desorb the enzyme .	2.9146345168647825

The basic property of this reversible interaction also makes it a weak binding .	3.2847526426453806

Weak binding in the sense while during use , the enzyme can also dissolve slowly over a long period of time and if the carrier characteristics are sturdy they can be regenerated and reused .	3.4628657561789993

Multivariant means that more than one physico - chemical interaction is involved in binding .	4.4341723520576535

Another feature is mild conditions and that will apply to most of the immobilization methods and also to adsorption .	4.163262599272937

That means the environmental conditions required for adsorption must be mild and here I think I like to very specifically define the term mild .	2.8158758317662573

Mild refers here not to the value one or two it refers to those conditions under which enzyme is conformationally stable .	3.2749792468962267

The definition of mild condition refers to those conditions which are environmentally acceptable to the enzyme .	3.1744748722703973

If the enzyme is stable at 70ºC , 70ºC is acceptable and can be considered as mild .	3.957212594645483

But if the enzyme is not stable even at 20ºC you may have to go to 4 degrees to immobilize and the definition of mild will remain at 4 degrees .	3.199654026508946

I have purposely not used the word ambient because you refer it to a well definite range .	2.739664737941106

The advantage of the situation is that usually the methods based on adsorption results in high yields .	3.578325939996644

A disadvantage is that the preparations do not have very high operational stability .	5.319054306819469

The method is reversible in nature , the interactions are reversible and so operational stability is usually not very high .	3.3110907375824294

Although by various other manipulations like adsorption , coupling with cross linking the operational stability can be improved but intrinsically adsorption based methods are usually operationally high .	2.3899841378442814

If suppose in the case of covalent binding half lives are of the order of few months here it may be of the order of few days .	3.5352816712595185

So that is what it refers to but allows the regeneration with carrier .	3.3415449060296534

On the other hand although the operational stability is not very high but the advantage is that the carrier can be regenerated and reused .	3.348001096144567

That is the plus point .	6.144972143900923

You have a large variety of carriers that can be used .	5.555943466128468

We will look at some of the examples of the carriers and finally adsorption based methods have been very often used to study the enzymology of systems that naturally occur in biological system because in case of living cells most of the enzymes are supported on a solid matrix through adsorption only .	3.013092232926181

There are no covalent linkages .	6.149321847209094

Either the enzymes are supported on membrane or they are supported on certain particulate matters and therefore the methods based on adsorption are usually very analogues similar to those that are found in the living system .	2.937707447555235

Operational stability is defined in terms of half life .	5.295364679070086

Consider the use of immobilized enzyme in a reactor and pack it in a packed bed , feed in and effluent out .	4.358044787172075

Here X - axis is operational time and Y - axis is fraction of conversion .	4.183540530074638

What you notice is that when you start at zero time the fraction of conversion will keep on going down as the enzyme activity is reduced or lost .	3.388427404423729

If you consider as a first order process then the half life of this that means the time it takes to reach the fifty percent of the original value is half life .	3.4527879111770203

If we consider E = E0 e - kdt You can simply calculate half life as t1 / 2 = 0.69 / kd t1 / 2 is less in the case of adsorption .	3.179451317242473

Other way , compared to covalent binding .	4.859940451976413

Right . Because the interaction is reversible in nature so it keeps leaking .	3.5647407653767567

A very crude term could be the enzyme keeps leaking values , very small amounts , slowly not in a very fast rate .	3.113339399799363

This property of leaking of the enzyme from immobilized preparation has been very advantageously used in many cases of the enzyme therapy purposes , where we want to put an immobilized enzyme preparation onsite at a site where the enzyme is required and the enzyme must leak continuously not in a very high concentration and over a long period of time .	3.5783315803081677

Some systems like immobilized …… .	8.328648499450821

has been inserted into the blood stream in the immobilized forms - microcapsules and the enzyme leaks slowly and the immobilized system can remain in blood stream over a few months .	3.1957190366312593

You have to give another shot to keep the enzyme activity available in the blood stream .	4.373916452572129

So these methods can have an advantage that the reversible nature can also be used in some cases where you want to use the drug or a therapeutic agent with the requirement of slow availability over a long period of time .	3.1574416985513065

As far as study of reactor system is concerned , we are not measuring the enzyme activity every time .	3.758576369645819

What we are measuring is the conversion at the effluent .	4.883260066558315

So that ’ s why the graph is in the form of conversion .	4.924172148379087

Three most common types of adsorption methods are based on physical adsorption which is again a most non - specific type of adsorption where we use hydrogen bonding , electrostatic interactions or Vanderwaal interactions , a variety of interactions where there is no specific reasons and we use a very broad range of carriers like alumina , celite , bentonite , glass etc where which by certain conditions of pH , temperature and salt you can adsorb the enzyme on to the surface and they can be used .	2.4318810377777806

The second method is ionic binding where you take a tailored matrix which has a definite charge on the surface and ion exchange resins are the most commonly used matrices .	3.641759214212704

DEAE - Cellulose , Amberlite etc which are charged particles and these charged particles based on the electrostatic interaction can bind the enzyme molecules at a pH where the net charge is counter .	2.910375816852987

The enzyme at this stage is counter charged at a particular condition .	4.083557660766158

The third category is hydrophobic binding where we predominantly use hydrophobic interactions on the surface of the carrier and the hydrophobic interactions on the surface of the enzyme protein .	2.9583472401113977

Although bulk of the hydrophobic residues are buried inside the residue of enzyme but still on the surface there are very small hydrophobic patches which can be used here for immobilizing on to the surface of a hydrophobic carrier ; carriers like polypropylene beads .	3.0139621221206623

There is a commercial product by the name Accurel , which is a microporous carrier consisting of polypropylene , butyl or hexyl sepharose etc .	2.4848278679486793

There are number of hydrophobic carriers used and which are available for binding of enzyme .	3.8880453226132543

Many of the carriers which are available today for adsorption of enzymes are developed for chromatographic separations .	3.371016670393027

For example all the carriers like hydrophobic binding or ionic binding were originally developed for chromatographic separations where the function is same .	2.5032982358010227

That means you are binding through ionic interactions and desorbing it under the conditions of desorption and therefore the same thing applies here .	2.990002347248212

In fact the preparation of immobilized enzyme by adsorption is very much similar to chromatographic separations on ion exchange resin , although we are only interested in the first part of it .	3.3573097724140757

Only adsorption part ; desorption is not our interest where as in the case of chromatography both the parts are important .	2.938468401272685

Another important group of adsorption methods is metal salt linkage .	3.544383645121233

Certain metal salts like titanium tetra chloride and ferric chloride form a kind of an inorganic bridge on the surface of the carrier and to which the enzyme molecules can couple .	3.303981515972475

The linkage that is formed , what we have in the literature and what people have used , is the metal salt linkage .	3.3837120644178325

It is not a covalent linkage ; it is a physical interaction and there by the enzyme is held but has been very successful method from the practical point of view .	3.6060674121296747

We will discuss that in detail .	5.833168756698502

Most of the adsorption methods can be characterized by the classical adsorption isotherms .	3.317110974794391

Depending on the nature of the carrier and nature of the enzyme that we are talking about , the isotherms may vary .	5.188698175711476

Three general types of isotherms are known .	4.753973235640771

One is linear where q is the concentration of the enzyme protein on to the surface of the carrier ; y is the corresponding concentration in the solution at equilibrium .	4.208662483825522

If you take a combination of enzyme in carrier concentration and at equilibrium measure the concentration in the solid phase and the liquid and you make an isotherm , then you may end up sometime in some cases a linear relationship where q is equal to k.y To make the isotherm , take different ratios of the carrier and the enzyme activity .	3.0554984424457197

That means enzyme activity to carrier ratio is varied and at different combinations you allow equilibrium to be formed and under equilibrium condition you measure the concentration of the enzyme in the liquid phase and also in the solid phase .	3.0391633041101658

Each point represents a particular enzyme to carrier ratio .	5.156616286939999

You can find three different types of isotherms : linear is simple ; Freundlich is more general in the sense that it does not fit into any hypothesis but in general you can vary curve fitting .	2.8718088920792977

What ever kind of isotherm you get , you just raise to a factor of n and by analysis of your data you will calculate the value of k and n .	2.710026180476496

You could make a log log plot and you can get the value of k and n .	4.0885852623011685

The most established and analytically proven method is Langmuir isotherm .	3.0802330496657055

Here q is the concentration of the enzyme protein on to the solid matrix and q0 is the maximum capacity of the matrix .	4.44430141039073

If you take a very high enzyme concentration compared to carrier , allow equilibrium to be established that means the concentration of the enzyme on to the immobilized preparation which will represent the saturation behavior is q0 .	3.427895180455732

You will notice that it is analogues to your Michaelis Menten kinetics .	4.876465003823105

These three expressions the Langmuir isotherm , Michaelis Menten kinetics , hyperbolic expression and also the Mannose equation for cell growth are almost analogues expressions and that indicates that there is some inter relationship or some similarity in their basic physical interpretation .	2.596172285470124

Langmuir isotherm is based on a theoretical development .	6.257831546605961

One can develop on the basis of number of binding sites on the carrier molecule for enzyme .	4.4188294130462955

Here just like we consider the enzyme substrate binding where the enzyme acts as the carrier and the substrate is ligand here the carrier will be the matrix and the protein will be the ligand and on those conditions you can develop it or you can analyze it by a double reciprocal plot .	3.76182496878423

The analogy is that the three expressions , the Langmuir adsorption isotherm , the Michaelis Menten kinetics and Mannose kinetics for cell growth they are analogues terms .	2.85933599420492

In the case of enzyme we are talking of enzyme substrate complex formation .	5.291454111062898

That means enzyme is the matrix , surface is a ligand .	5.258672060914586

If we talk in terms of adsorption , the substrate gets adsorbed on to the enzyme surface .	5.390650234526985

On the other hand here in the case of adsorption the enzyme is itself a ligand and the matrix or the carrier is the surface on which the ligand adsorbs .	3.560748427550017

In the third case , in the case of cell growth , the Mannose model of microbial cell growth it is a substrate which is a ligand just like enzymes but the matrix is the cell mass itself and it reflects the transport of substrate into the cell .	3.1288871832801903

So this is adsorption that is transport and enzyme catalyses enzyme substrate binding .	2.8472486082754087

So these three phenomena are intrinsically someway related because they end up in a similar kind of a kinetic expression .	3.2583712083746232

As far as the analysis is concerned all the three can also be analyzed by a double reciprocal plot .	3.7938993649597674

That is if you plot 1 / q versus 1 / y you will get a linear plot and you will get the value of q0 and k .	4.598115666184484

The adsorption process for a particular enzyme and for a particular carrier can be analyzed quantitatively .	5.193101795547182

Many physical factors influence the adsorption process .	4.912225250088202

I have listed some of them here .	6.608958517395832

The first parameter is pH .	6.669154687498708

The pH will be a very major parameter which will affect the binding in the case of ionic binding .	5.0950903930856475

Even for other forms of binding processes pH plays a key role and very often it has been noted that the binding by adsorption is maximum at its isoelectric points .	2.9308514383736286

Large variety of relationships with respect to pH for the quantity adsorbed has been found .	3.482892151551217

There is no general ruling but in general or a common feature can be considered that at the isoelectric point the pH value will be most preferable for the adsorption processes .	2.816689323616414

No . Net charge is zero .	6.273517457166829

It is not that the proteins are not charged at that pH .	3.8873790139275783

The negative and positive charges are equal .	4.891941731039635

Not that there is no charge .	9.891603041523384

The second parameter is salts .	6.006271212496867

Salts have a very complex behavior .	10.226812459440259

In fact it has almost opposite behavior .	4.10300010127795

You must have studied also in the case of bio separations particularly the concentration of salt is used for increasing as well as decreasing solubility .	4.103933605341143

But in most cases the salt concentration is required to be kept at a minimum because salts are very good eluents also .	2.90503317451829

In ion exchange chromatography very often we use high ionic strength as a medium for elution of the adsorbed material .	2.5799697356700904

Therefore at high salt concentration adsorption is usually poor and minimum salt concentration is required to be kept .	2.810812264648615

Protein concentration will be important and we have seen from the adsorption isotherm itself .	4.747929969452432

The definite ratio of protein to carrier will play a particular equilibrium behavior and higher the protein concentration you can reach nearer the saturation level at equilibrium .	2.8247102305768625

Temperature again is a very significant parameter which must be understood .	5.598106517628046

If we look at adsorption of a small molecular weight material or a small molecular weight ligands on to a surface the general behavior is that increasing the temperature reduces the adsorption .	3.298478888939942

That means the quantity of ligand adsorbed per unit weight of the carrier for low molecular weight ligands will be less as you increase the temperature and the reason attributed to this is because of the movement of the particles as the temperature increases .	3.8474061824901153

That means the movement of particle increases and the tendency is for desorbing rather than adsorption .	2.8660342174463995

But in the case of protein adsorption when we are talking about enzymes , we are talking about proteins and macromolecules , adsorption over a narrow range of temperature offers a reverse phenomena .	3.1193381142538037

That means adsorption increases with temperature .	4.826361832096054

Mind the word I am using “over a narrow range of temperature increase ” .	3.459700877516636

If you increase to a higher level desorption also might start .	3.425712251139017

But before desorption even inactivation might start .	4.00388749867261

But we consider the adsorption at …… range of temperature .	5.4446030984815055

The primary factors responsible for the increase in adsorption with temperature are when the protein binds to a surface there is some unfolding of the protein molecules , which is an endothermic process and the increase of temperature resulting in enhanced adsorption supports the hypothesis that the binding or adsorption of a protein molecule or a polymeric material to a surface is an endothermic process coupled with unfolding of the confirmation .	2.8460409928589536

When I say unfolding I am not referring to total deactivation but minor modification in the conformation which extends its total volume or total surface area .	2.5222113472880423

The other factor which is important , which is probably attributing to this increase of adsorption with the increase in temperature is the diffusional processes because most of time we are talking about the carrier being a porous material and the ligands or the protein here have to diffuse into the surface , into the internal pore surface and the diffusion process gets increased by increase in temperature .	2.607219619331425

So both the unfolding of the protein molecule on the surface of the carrier and the diffusional processes involved in the adsorption in the internal pores ultimately leads to give you a phenomenon which represents increase in adsorption with increase in temperature over a narrow range .	3.09656841210781

Carrier properties , depending on the property like surface property of the carrier particles which were used as matrix , will also play a role on the adsorption behaviour depending on the nature may be sometime even the carriers are pre - conditioned , swollen to improve the property .	2.829743537058257

Time of adsorption is another parameter which is significant and important because we are talking about the macromolecular adsorption .	3.763891285463316

So the diffusion is involved and the time required very often is controlled by diffusional limitations and the rate of diffusion controls the time required for adsorption process .	3.5038394603328116

This in the case of a small ligand is not a constant .	6.325927602467145

At least four major methods are used for adsorption .	5.229366837028064

The first and probably the most trivial method is the static process .	3.1296327607505745

That means you bring in an enzyme solution in contact with a carrier and leave it over night or over a long period of time .	2.761624478926699

Adsorption takes place without any hesitation .	5.597866199863403

It takes a very long time and that is the process very often many people use in laboratories .	4.200860880915269

The yields are also much lower particularly for porous carrier because of the diffusional limitations .	3.725855579323082

One of the most disadvantageous situations in the case of static process is that the loading of the enzyme is not uniform over the carrier .	4.400375331956031

Even if you allow for a long period the loading is usually not uniform .	3.9453111166178587

Suppose this is the carrier particle .	12.57156599384101

You have lot of enzyme molecules on the surface but on the interior it is very , very rarely distributed and the loading is not uniform .	3.811476586360687

The most commonly used method in the laboratories is dynamic batch process in which you mix the two components , the enzyme and the carrier under known conditions or under standard conditions for adsorption , which favours adsorption and agitate them , stir them mechanically , under mild stirring so that the carrier particle should not get degraded and also the enzyme molecules should not be influenced .	2.7262604076371137

The equilibrium is allowed to be reached over a period of time .	3.3375715780330513

It usually leads to a fast method and most common method used in the laboratories .	3.9494226547990126

In the commercial establishment when we use adsorption as the method of immobilization we use reactor loading process .	3.2146399672026633

That means first of all the reactor which is to be used for bio - conversion of the enzymatic reaction is packed with the carrier itself and then the enzyme solution is recirculated constantly through the carrier bed and over a period of time the enzyme gets adsorbed on the matrix .	3.26179372833253

It could not only be packed bed ; it could also be stirred reactor in which the enzyme is added and the enzyme solution is allowed to be stirred along with the carrier and after a period of time when the supernatant enzyme activity has come to minimum value you stop the process .	3.2669125108920913

In all these methods which we are talking about , the final step is washing because very often you will have that some of the enzyme will be adhering to the surface of the particles which is not really immobilized in the proper sense .	3.8298067522068426

It is not adsorbed ; some adhering along with the liquid and so fresh wash of the buffer at a particular pH should be given so that all the adhering enzyme is washed out and only that which is physically bound by adsorption is retained by the carrier .	2.5137793156577373

The final washing in the case of reactor loading process is done with the substrate solution itself because during the operation it has to meet the environmental conditions which are provided by the substrate solution , the feed .	3.4193353213428086

Under those conditions it must remain adsorbed and so the final washing in the case of a reactor loading method is provided by the feed substrate itself so that whatever desorption has to take place under feed substrate condition , takes place and the enzyme is in the stable form .	3.0539779042069806

The fourth method is electrodeposition process in which the carrier is placed in proximity to one of the electrodes and the current is applied between the two electrodes and the enzyme particles which are charged usually they get deposited on the carrier particles and at the end the carrier is removed which gets coated by the enzyme particle .	3.617474561724852

One thing we have to keep in mind , a very important feature that during the electro chemical process there will be certain ions which will be removed from the electrodes or from the process .	3.605799839548897

If the ions are important for enzyme activity then they must be provided in the electrolyte itself .	3.3351972851374225

Extra quantity of those will be provided in the electrolyte otherwise you will not be having a functional enzyme preparation in the immobilized form .	3.1658844103956625

The last method based on the adsorption process is by inorganic bridge formation as I mentioned or metal salt linkage .	3.507443677847376

This was originally developed by British group Barker , Emery and Novais , one of the references I have sited here , in seventy one .	2.570209105132199

It involves the metal salt linkage .	5.298500056936243

The basic principle of the method is the method employs transition metal salts like titanium tetrachloride , zirconium tetrachloride or ferric chloride for linking an enzyme to the carrier .	2.6452252143763983

Carriers are usually cellulose , nylon , glass beads etc .	3.7535646098319284

If you put cellulose into it , it might get degraded totally .	3.2949038526304193

So the time of contact is very important and it is not used mostly more than five minutes and if you take a dilute solution probably you can go higher , followed by filtering and drying of complex at 45ºC .	3.353151331368076

Excess unreacted salt is washed with buffer .	4.2484977978942675

The activated carrier is then stirred with the buffered enzyme solution followed by washing of the unbound enzyme .	2.3414375028686494

The method is very simple and involves two steps , activation of the matrix by steeping it in a transition metal salt solution whereby the transition metal salts form an octahedral complex .	2.927465901834336

The chemistry of that can be considered like this .	6.55122948362655

Titanium tetra chloride will exist in different forms and the complexes will be either dominated by water molecules as the ligand in the octahedral complex form .	2.539407791874403

The titanium tetra chloride solution will exist in different forms complexed with certain ligands .	3.10936061526913

One of the major advantages is that you always end up having a distance between the carrier surface and the enzyme molecules .	3.8514086697592136

Therefore enzyme molecules and the carrier surface are separated by these linkages , the metal salt linkages .	3.8761228027790158

But in this case because there is distance between the matrix surface and the enzyme , steric hindrance is minimized .	4.808169441284338

The second major advantage which has been noted in these cases is that if you use a regenerated carrier after the enzyme has been leached out , you again immobilize the enzyme on the regenerated carrier .	3.164316128532385
