Last time we were discussing about the application of the immobilized enzymes and we had mentioned that the enzymes find applications in a variety of situations and we dealt with the applications of immobilized enzymes as industrial biocatalyst in process industries .	3.2948520664286196

Two major sectors of applications of immobilized enzymes are analytical applications and also their application in the therapeutics for the treatment of diseases in human beings and both the applications are also particularly important or in contrast to the application as industrial catalyst lies in the effect that you require much more purified systems and the use of high value enzymes in their applications unlike in the case of industrial biocatalyst where mostly we were dealing with relatively lesser valued enzymes and the two applications on analytical applications and therapeutics require relatively high value enzymes and in a higher purified state .	2.4211839144007907

Just to take up the analytical applications the variety of applications that have been reported can be classified into four different types : the first is automated analysis procedures by combining immobilized enzymes with various analytical tools .	2.6228572302015016

One way is as you must have done in your laboratory class the use of glucose oxidase for example for assay of glucose .	3.5571690977318453

The use of soluble enzyme may be fine if you have to analyze let us say couple of samples three or four .	4.2760080470225414

But in situation where the sample to be analyzed are in very large number and very often such instances are met in hospitals and in clinical laboratories where few hundreds of samples everyday are encountered and use of soluble enzyme may be some times uneconomical .	2.4670713660757695

Similarly in research also a student might be analyzing the similar sample hundreds of them over a day and just to get his results .	2.306992375312565

So in those cases the analytical procedures can be automated by combining the immobilized enzymes , instead of soluble enzyme , with a standard analytical device .	2.912999452057431

It could be a spectrophotometer , it could be a fluorospectrophotometer , it could be as simple as pH meter .	4.111731248550714

So any analytical simple analytical tool can be combined and used .	3.2430500422706916

A very simple example of this approach was reported by Hicks and Updike way back in 66 .	3.1544782409849668

Another point is the bulk of the analytical applications were the earliest uses of immobilized enzymes .	4.230337383332301

In fact their application in process industry was adopted much later than they were used in analytical applications and that means the cost implications are much more severe in analytical sections .	2.680717967914856

The setup is like this that the given sample in which a chemical species to be analyzed is passed through an immobilized enzyme column a very small column and here in this reference it was glucose or lactic acid determination based on glucose oxidase or lactate dehydrogenase and they were immobilized on polyacrolymide gel and packed in a very small column and the substrate was fed at 0.8 ml per minute and then this is passed through a delay line so that you provide a reaction time and a coloured reagent is added here and after that in a spectrophotometer , a photometric cell which is connected to a system , the reaction passes the and color developed is monitored .	2.4602975815376102

You can also have some standard solutions and this is a two way valve whereby you can either put a standard solution and measure observant in the photometer or you can put the actual cell and on the other side you have a buffer or a control solution which also passes through a delay line and a different photometer of the same wavelength and to empty the photometer tube pulses are used so that in a pulse mode the tubes are filled and emptied while the flow is continuous for the photometer measures in a pulse mode and the materials are removed .	2.4084264968038105

In fact two of the systems which were very early reported were glucose by glucose oxidase and lactic acid by lactate dehydrogenase .	2.5303680832305804

This is the kind of reaction that takes place in the immobilized enzyme column .	6.764796656937658

The lactic acid sample itself is mixed with NAD solution and pyruvic acid is formed with reduced NAD and reduced NAD is then oxidized with a dye DPI and then the NAD gets regenerated that means that is oxidized and reduced dye is colourless .	2.1562964183518303

This DPI is blue and this is colourless .	6.355937039579842

So difference in the absorbance is related to the concentration of the lactic acid .	5.233349788225427

On the other hand , in the case of glucose it is glucose to gluconic acid plus hydrogen peroxide and hydrogen peroxide acts as an oxidizing agent and it oxidizes the DPI to coloured product which is blue in color and is measured .	2.14002009799009

A large number of other dyes also have been reported and this dye is only just to facilitate the measurement of the colour .	2.980506272137162

Two other very interesting examples also came in almost during the same time in 64 and 65 .	3.1554247439938927

Riesel and Katchalski in Israel reported the use of urease immobilized on diazotized amino acid copolymer used for the determination of urea in urine or serum and also for the removal of urea from body fluids .	2.251290943380596

The urea system in urine samples is used today in many large hospitals on a commercial scale where the requirement is almost thousands samples in a day .	2.222308494713803

So instead of employing number of analysts they have an auto analyzer in which the immobilized column can carry out the job and almost thousand samples can be analyzed using a single cartage of immobilized enzyme and the cost can be saved effectively .	2.798836661066328

The other report is by Gilbault and Kramer in 65 .	3.3902696974178013

They did for cholinesterase which was entrapped in a starch matrix and it was used for continuous detection of anti - cholinesterase .	2.5966749918237335

This is an example not really of a metabolite or some kind of a substrate or the product but it was just like an environmental analysis where the presence of certain cholinesterase inhibitors present in either effluents or nearby as a result of pollution were monitored continuously using an immobilized cholinesterase entrapped in a starch matrix plus a fluorescence spectrophotometer because the product ultimately gives a fluorescence and the change in fluorescence as a result of inhibitor present .	2.362949454182816

That means florescence decreases and by that one can monitor continuously and the measurement of florescence gives you a direct indication of the concentration of inhibitor in the feed stream .	3.4033761857657185

The second class of analytical applications is enzyme electrodes .	3.7530398696208214

Although it is listed as second it has become commercially a very , very important sector of analytical tool .	3.0930923613376606

What is an enzyme electrode ?	8.705395735551589

In general we call it a biosensor , an analytical device .	4.055884282148318

We know the transducer to utilize the selective analysis of a biochemical species in a sample .	2.7315018312016823

So there are three distinct segments one is the biological unit which is integrated with a transducer and the third is anylate .	3.2256189769207735

These three systems , the biological unit , transducer and anylate have to have a linkage .	3.8274393858212994

That means if this anylate has to recognize this biological unit there must be an affinity between the two .	2.924112673115685

Secondly the substrate or the product of the reaction which comes out as a result of this interaction must be able to generate a measurable parameter which can be measured by transducer in quantitative terms so that it can be related with either the substrate concentration or some species in the sample .	3.694761206376539

Anylate means that chemical species which is to be analyzed say for example you want to analyze sugar some glucose in blood ; glucose is the anylate .	3.6120573763284036

The chemical species which needs to be analyzed is anylate .	4.933175606547585

In other words the concept is very simple and a large variety of biological units have been used to prepare biosensors .	4.0225218718209605

As far as we are concerned you will be stressing more on enzymes as biological units but other than enzyme you can also use microbial cells , plant cells , animal cells , cell membrane , Lectins or antibodies depending upon the anylate .	2.592468677195855

The purpose is that the chemical species to be analyzed must have a specific recognition for the biological unit and the type of transducers that are very commonly used are amperometric or potentiometric electrodes and the recent year developments have been in the area of field effect transistors , thermisters .	2.5861246925467625

But still on commercial level amperometric and potentiometric transducers are the common tools that are used in bulk .	3.2283354974400753

Anylate is the chemical species which is to be monitored in the sample .	4.763635452685158

Say for example if you want to monitor urea in urine samples ; urea is the anylate , urine is a sample the fluid to be analyzed and the biological unit which is recognizing that analate is the material either an enzymes or a cell which has the some affinity for that molecule and you need a physical transducer which can sense either the substrate or the product or any other signal which is generated through the reaction .	2.4789389149570633

I will come to that later .	6.116573557203749

This is immobilized enzyme .	8.576028815451322

The substrate molecule recognizes the enzyme species present on the immobilized enzyme .	5.624322870918175

There can be a membrane through which the product or any other species which comes out as a result of reaction passes through and approaches transducer , an analytical device which generates a signal that can be monitored .	3.018980237041203

It can be in the form of a current ; it can be in the form of potential difference ; it can be the form of temperature change and variety of signals can be generated and that depends on the type of ……… producing .	4.06092575007097

Secondly convert the recognition process into a physico - chemical change which either directly or indirectly generates the current .	2.3489834969588625

In the electrical circuit current is a very easily measurable parameter and just to make it suitable for repeated use we need to immobilize the bio element .	3.205735287270231

Theoretically the system can be used in a soluble form also but just to make it a continuously usable system the bio element is immobilized .	3.4256647507525684

What kinds of electrodes are used usually ?	4.638888755259239

Take for example pH electrode in a laboratory .	4.737095402655386

pH electrode is a transducer , one of the transducers which can be used in the case of an enzyme electrode .	5.044334280781766

What you simply need to do is at the tip of the electrode you need to insert by some mechanism an immobilized enzyme layer so that when you dip that electrode into a sample liquid , the sample comes in contact with immobilized enzyme layer usually in the form of thin film and the reaction takes place ; the product goes through and it is sensed by the pH electrode .	2.9430341713799506

pH electrode is a potentiometric transducer .	5.496084226765738

It generates the potential and that potential is measured and calibrated in the form of pH change and that can be used simply .	3.577151762801314

In principle the enzyme is bound to ion selective electrode that will detect the presence of a substrate or product .	4.081096214647903

That means if the substrate is ionisable it can be measured or it can measure the product of the enzyme catalyzed reaction .	4.627812191249092

One can manipulate and develop number of the strategies like an amperometric …. .. type dissolved oxygen electrode what you use in the case of fermentation fluids for measurement of dissolved oxygen .	2.8253552498745877

That means at the tip of the transducer you have a PTFE membrane so that the sample in which the analysis has to be done for dissolved oxygen is separated from KCl solution because that should not get mixed and a potential of about 0.5 to 0.8 volts , a constant value , is applied because this constant voltage applied will determine the calibration of the current which is generated as a result of dissolved oxygen when it comes in contact with the electrode .	2.803050571031018

The potential of 0.5 to 0.8 volts is usually applied across the electrode and the current generated is proportional to the concentration of the substrate in the sample .	3.344598534455336

The current generated is reflected by dissolved oxygen concentration because on the cathode it is the oxygen which takes up the protons generated on the anode .	2.533595674267527

This dissolved oxygen is a function or is a parameter which is participating in the reaction .	4.646630974090228

In enzymatic reactions usually there will be oxidoreductases , redox reactions if they consume oxygen or give out oxygen a difference in the dissolved oxygen can be used to measure the substrate .	3.0391620296651283

At the electrode is measured dissolved oxygen but the consumption of dissolved oxygen in the fluid is a result of enzymatic reaction .	3.0481352390777605

The three parameters which are important in the case of an enzyme electrode are selectivity .	4.813997916747847

Then sensitivity ; Sensitivity is a function of the Km value of the enzyme that means the range of analysis that it can perform that will depend on the Km value of the enzyme .	4.357956138215311

Usually immobilized enzyme is supplied in the form of sandwich between the membranes so that they can be replaced on the tip .	3.9239961036319246

We are indirectly measuring glucose via measurement of dissolved oxygen .	3.2102752021296017

The dissolved oxygen electrode will measure dissolved oxygen only ; it cannot measure glucose directly .	2.9051284447064627

But the glucose concentration results in either production or consumption of oxygen as a result of the enzyme reaction and that is the purpose .	4.086839924979184

Large number of enzyme electrodes have been prepared and listed here are the ones which are commercially available .	3.0680365206096156

For example glucose is the most commonly used electrode and the immobilization method polyacrylamide gel ; oxygen electrode is electrode used and the concentration range it can measure is of the order of ten to the power of minus five to ten to the power of minus four molar .	2.91833554137279

I like you to see the sensitivity of the measurement which is probably much higher than any physical or chemical measurement system at this concentration level .	2.658468979090104

That is we are talking in the micro molar range .	5.47620825071977

Whereas if the plant operator has an electrode in his pocket and he takes a sample and dips into it , the control becomes very easy .	2.2325331933231025

He can immediately take a decision to either switch on or switch off or terminate ; whatever decision has to be taken on the plan and in those cases such systems are very , very useful .	2.724872283347562

Another analytical device based on immobilized enzyme is enzyme thermisters .	4.259255302169392

The enzyme thermisters are based on the measurement of temperature difference of the reaction liquid in an exothermic biochemical reaction .	3.9162999781645507

Mind it that we are talking of exothermic biochemical reaction .	4.950886891133607

Many of the enzyme reactions which are highly isothermal , I am just comparing the two , although they are known to be in all broad range as isothermal reactions they will have some value of ?	3.6789588552075663

H . So those which have slightly higher ?	4.93117514779142

H value among enzyme reactions they can be used for enzyme thermisters because they will induce a change in the temperature .	3.957965026209905

Although temperature change as you will notice is much smaller .	5.527268758595581

This involves the use of semi conductor material showing a large resistance change with temperature .	3.322785993541751

So measurement of temperature is based on the change in resistance of a semiconductor material as a function of temperature .	4.062262868419368

In semiconductors , the expression which relates the resistance with reference to temperature T one and T two , resistance changes and all those material and semiconductors are known to have a high change in resistance as a function of temperature and they are used here as the sensing device .	2.8194043083626767

So thermister is nothing else but a semiconductor material which is connected to a circuit which measures impedance and if that is put at the tip of the effluent stream of the immobilized enzyme reaction you can use it for measurement of temperature .	3.001259802699667

In practice a well insulated immobilized enzyme column is used .	3.614127701155523

The most difficult part of the enzyme thermister is the very high order of insulation required because the temperature which we are measuring is probably a fraction of the integer ; some times as low as 0.1º centigrade , one hundredth of a centigrade ; that is the kind of temperature change we are talking about to ensure very high order of insulation and the effectiveness of this system depends on the quality of insulation one can provide .	2.96319406996124

The thermister is mounted at the extreme end of the fluid .	4.671079734980364

The ? T is indicated by a change in impedance and the range of temperature measurement for different enzymes lies in 0.004 to 1º degree centigrade .	2.996245741495606

Higher this change is the system can be more effective usually it has been noted that only those enzymes which can generate a temperature change more than 0.1º centigrade are effective .	2.9915835897223477

0.004 is a …… size but you need some reliably measurable amount of temperature change .	2.9569158688665116

The suitability of enzyme thermister depends on the enthalpy changes associated with the biochemical reaction .	3.6750200741670747

More exothermic the reaction we are handling , the system can be more effective .	4.491638495173488

The conventional use of enzymes in therapeutic has been the use of proteases .	4.635983607035284

For variety of situations that range from digestion aid to even treatment of certain deceases which involve the availability of one of the enzyme or removal of some metabolite from the body .	2.69898567006153

But the use of soluble enzymes has certain very serious problems and the problems are listed here : one is that the enzyme has a higher molecular mass , a very large molecule protein and impermeability through biological membranes .	3.314018898402916

In fact the efficacy of any drug or a therapeutic agent depends on its permeability through biological membranes and even the efficacy of a chemical drug will depend on it ’ s ability to permeate through the biological membranes and reach to the site .	2.3721376213527394

So the larger the molecule as the enzymes are it posses serious problem in the permeability and the most toughest biological membrane through which the drug has to permeate is brain membranes .	2.4561990278248578

As a matter of fact almost all drugs which are required to be given for action at brain as the site the concentrations are very high almost 4 to eight times more that of the same drug if it is used at some other site in the body .	2.646706684824967

Say for example steroids .	7.973132352818601

If they have to be administered for some inflammation at some site leg or hand , you can give a very small dose ; it will reach the site and treat the patient .	2.730733410854007

But if the inflammation is in the brain at least ten fold concentration of the drug is required to be administered because lesser than that will not even permeate to the brain membrane .	2.888594123459374

So giving it will be useless it go to all over the body excepting brain .	3.750994114932429

So therefore the high molecular mass which results into impermeability through the biological membranes is a major problem .	3.10741773158112

This is the range .	8.779882493054338

This system which has been followed in the past has lot of problems .	3.739181914755075

One is that the patient after sometime fails to respond to dialysis , if the concentration goes very high the volume of the dialysate required is very large .	3.1455621541858925

The alternate to that is use of immobilized urease and this is an example of an artificial organ which is commercialized which is available commercially and with such a system a patient doesn ’ t have to go hospital because the volume of dialysate they require is only about a liter which he can safely install at the site of his bed in the house and use himself .	2.575000994332601

The principle remains the same .	5.843366245380049

You take blood in ; the dialyser unit is little compact same dialysis bag only thing is much smaller because as soon as the urea comes in the dialysate instead of being thrown out it is passed through an immobilized enzyme column , the one which is shown here as microcapsule in which ion exchange resin and the enzyme have been immobilized in microcapsules .	2.4929291097387414

So the urea which comes out in the dialysate is hydrolyzed to ammonia ; ammonia is absorbed by the ion exchange resin .	2.9300173438511536

Carbon dioxide is not allowed its not bothered about because carbon dioxide even if it reaches in the blood the body has a capacity to exit out to lungs assuming that the lungs are functioning properly of the patient .	2.141521680333205

The advantage here is from the practical point of view instead of dialysate volume using about of the order of three hundred liters we are talking of one or two liters of dialysate and because you are regenerating the dialysate by removing the urea formed in the system and that kind of system is commercially available .	2.7771156211544303

So far we have seen the influence of substrate concentration , inhibitor concentration or activator concentration on the rate of enzyme catalyzed reaction and they very strongly influence the catalytic behavior .	3.8539045564039474

Besides the substrates , inhibitors or activators two major environmental parameters which form or which constitute a bulk environment for the enzyme catalyzed reactions are pH and temperature .	2.758211350042497

Today we will be looking at these environmental parameters and how they influence the whole enzyme catalyzed reactions .	3.4674377578586046

As you know enzymes are primarily very complex molecules and we had also looked into the complexity of the situation as regards to their catalyses , as regards to their specificity .	2.4972925002564104

The whole effect of pH and temperature therefore is not based on a single interaction like in the case of substrate or an inhibitor which is usually their effect on the reaction rate and the formation of dynamic complexes with the enzyme .	3.5926030187990614

In the case of pH and temperature the effects are multidimensional .	4.23475896406624

If you look at the pH effects you will notice that the pH influences enzyme reaction rates or enzyme reaction in general in a number of ways .	3.5805202698637584

The first and probably the most common feature could be the shift in equilibrium .	3.816993737888656

A number of enzyme catalyzed reactions that are reversible in nature primarily can be affected strongly by the pH , particularly the reaction like oxidoreductases .	3.195756353336195

If you take for example ethanol oxidization by alcohol dehydrogenase , forming acetaldehyde plus NADH plus H .	2.369036350677439

If you consider such a reaction you will notice that the concentration of hydrogen ions at any given pH can be regulated by the pH of the environment .	3.7915573251836627

By taking a buffered reaction mixture at a higher pH the concentration of hydrogen ions in the reaction mixture can be maintained at a very low level and the reaction can be driven in the forward direction .	3.534937312212059

Similarly if you reduce the concentration or the pH of the buffer in which the reaction takes place you can also bring down the equilibrium constant of the reaction .	4.256255656686921

If you consider this reaction although this reaction may have an optimum pH of , say for example , seven that means the rate of reaction is maximum at pH seven .	3.6324670006140787

But at pH seven , the reaction may not be driven very largely to the forward direction .	3.340207118195125

To be able to drive the reaction in the forward direction you need to adjust the pH so that the concentration of hydrogen ions can be reduced and therefore the reaction can be driven .	4.560573753029254

But the reaction might proceed at a very slow pace .	4.32717491410553

For example if you consider let us say pH nine .	4.976123670650001

Just alter the pH value .	7.3550896776342904

At pH nine the concentration of hydrogen ions will be hundred fold less , one hundredth of at pH seven and therefore you can drive the reaction as far as the equilibrium constant is concerned but at a very slow rate .	3.27155323498946

The shift in the equilibrium must be considered in terms of the rate .	5.614047829463191

So pH optimum or the equilibrium constant they are two issues which are to be considered independently .	3.9885711043261383

The second issue which is important in the case of pH effects is the stability of the protein confirmation .	4.21676621662334

As we all know that proteins retain their native confirmation within a limited pH range , because electrostatic interactions , which are a major force , non - covalent force are involved in the confirmation of the enzyme molecule .	2.599387226942363

If you shift that pH very often gross alterations occur often called as denaturation .	2.71806894635583

That means if there is an irreversible change in the confirmation then the enzyme is considered to have been deactivated .	4.726674930839205

We assumed the stability behaviour of enzymes .	4.620937952112896

In earlier stabilization studies we saw that a two stage model is the most accepted model for enzyme which consists of two steps , native protein going into an unfolded form and then irreversible inactivation to in - active enzyme .	2.3491842415033686

While the first step is reversible , the second step is irreversible and always the approach to stabilize and a similar effect is noted even for the pH .	2.788668701981574

Initially if the pH alteration is mild if you go beyond a certain level of pH change you might observe only reversible change and therefore the enzyme can be brought back to a native confirmation but if you further change the pH it might undergo to a irreversible inactivation and which may not be possible to bring back .	2.7070355490250932

The third role is in which the hydrogen ions play a role for either inhibitor or an activator .	3.4401434222039606

Wherever we are considering the involvement of ionisable substrates or the products that are formed which are ionisable , the hydrogen ions will play the role of an inhibitor or an activator .	2.9865241009291292

The fourth role of pH and probably one of the most important role which pH plays and which directly influences the rate of reaction is the ionization of the amino acid residues on enzyme active sites .	3.431851374813307

On the enzyme active sites a number of amino acid residues are present which are charged and these charged residues will ionize as a function of pH of the bulk environment and therefore it is required that they are at a particular ionization state in which the enzyme offers the maximum reaction velocity .	3.44924798261274

That means if there is a particular state of ionization of the active site of the amino acid involved , whatever fraction of the enzymes present in that fraction will constitute the catalytically functional enzyme .	3.7749250160658745

This ionization state will affect the maximum reaction velocity of the enzyme because ultimately you are affecting the total effective enzyme concentration which is in the true ionisable state of the system .	3.53148883996503

The last effect is due to ionization of substrate .	4.926981294196348

Although many of the substrates which are used in the enzyme reactions may be neutral , like ethanol or any other non - ionisable substrate , many of them also contain carboxylic group or hydroxyl group or amino group .	3.185633996803535

The ionization of substrate will influence the Km value of the enzyme .	5.060934467544516

The Km value will be altered because the apparent concentration of substrate which we are providing is not the true substrate concentration which is interacting with the enzyme and it may be lesser than that because the ionized state which is catalytically acceptable to enzyme is less than that .	3.6695530560306655

Therefore the pH effects must be looked into all these parameters or all these effects in a comprehensive manner .	3.122143762738433

Practically it may be difficult to consider all these effects in one go because sometimes they may be counteracting and so the net effect of what we notice is a very complex phenomenon , all over .	3.370732524116218

To understand the behavior and to derive certain meaningful conclusions one may create or design experiments in which only one of the pH effect is considered prominent and in fact the pH effect studies have contributed a lot to understand the identification of the amino acid residues in the active site in conjunction with the chemical modification studies .	2.689003683047509

Common technique to study the amino acid residues or identify the amino acid residues at the enzyme active site is by chemical modification of the different function of the groups that are present .	4.062034480128824

In addition to that their effect on the ionization behavior and ultimately the rate effect and putting both the things together can give you a confirmatory result or conclusion on the identification of the amino acid residues on the reaction rate .	2.6718518636419684

We will consider today mainly the ionization of amino acid residues on the active site which is primarily a major factor which influences the typical reaction profile that you are familiar with of the effect of pH on the enzyme .	3.1668472758580255

The effect of pH on the reaction velocity must be considered as a parameter on the rate of reaction .	4.431219222116922

The enzyme kinetics deals with a quantitative analysis of the effect of various parameters on the rate of enzyme catalyzed reactions .	3.8242151708844436

It involves molecular dynamics between the various species involved in the reaction .	3.8269546968601182

One of the principle species as you know is enzyme itself and the interaction of enzyme with all other chemical species that is the substrate , the product , if there is any inhibitor all those molecular species , dynamics of these inter relationship or interactions is involved in the study of enzyme kinetics .	3.098163040891444

One of the essential features for study of enzyme kinetics is the experimental data .	3.454991982139749

To start with any kinetic analysis one needs to initiate with some basic experimental observations and to take some experimental observations the key parameters that are usually involved in the study are the enzyme concentration , substrate concentration , product concentration , concentration of inhibitor or activator if there is one where as enzyme , substrate and product are the universal chemical species involved in the case of an enzyme catalyzed reactions .	2.8701704911925208

Then you have a set of environmental parameters like hydrogen ion concentration reflected in pH , or the temperature of reaction .	3.9689935255626008

Then in most of the enzyme catalyzed reactions , we assume the water concentration to be very large almost in excess and for most of the analytical purposes it is ignored .	3.763597669766226

But at least in two distinct cases where we are handling very high substrate concentrations of the order of say greater than 50 or 60 % weight by volume or in cases where we are carrying out reactions in the non polar medium , water activity also becomes a key parameter for study under enzyme kinetics because then it controls the rate of enzymatic reaction and therefore it must be taken into account .	3.0238561208814723

So when we talk of enzyme kinetics we are looking into the molecular dynamics of various species that are involved in the reaction , their interconversions and the effect of those inter conversions on the rate of reactions as a function of different parameters that are listed here .	3.283042108927285

There are three major constituents in any kinetic analysis .	4.133293471015757

As I mentioned earlier the first and probably the most important are the experimental data .	3.768040938782529

With the start of experimental data one assume certain mechanistic hypothesis that means how various molecules involved in the reaction are interacting and you propose some kind of a mechanistic hypothesis or in other words you can say in a simplistic term the sequence of reaction steps that are involved in converting substrate into product and based on these mechanistic hypothesis or reaction steps we arrive at a rate equation using mathematical analysis .	2.5471554366004376

If it befits the experimental data , if it predicts or gives you a close relationship with experimental data it is acceptable , both the rate equation as well as mechanistic hypothesis we have assumed are acceptable .	2.7853279155402486

If not we again go back to the mechanistic hypothesis modify it , revise it , in the light of the deviations and then again go back to a new rate equation and therefore such an analytical sequence continues till we are able to match our rate expression with the experimentally observed data .	2.4690291685468546

In a very simplistic term the rate equation is a mathematical expression that depicts the reaction process in terms of rate constants .	3.437175983817572

I think we must appreciate that the rate equation has a very new dimension in terms of rate constants .	4.545740795504125

A large number of rate constants might be involved depending on the number of reaction sequence steps and substrate and product and other chemical species if involved .	3.5380394737261094

It also serves as a link between experimentally observed data and the possible reaction sequence steps .	2.900147329771817

These three parameters or these three steps are the critical steps in study of any kinetic system and applies to also the enzyme kinetics .	2.7062935841018754

The second question that might emerge in your mind is why do we study enzyme kinetics ?	2.8531545244996086

What is the function ?	8.762354381826706

I think the first and foremost and probably the most trivial function that could be understood is to get a certain optimum set of parameters for carrying out the reaction .	2.9631240350364996

For example when we consider the optimum temperature of the reaction and the optimum pH for the reaction that is probably one of the primary objectives of establishing the whole kinetics analysis .	4.3272982697190585

As I mentioned you will always assume a mechanistic hypothesis to arrive at rate expression .	3.295539628274328

It also gives a number of inferences about reaction mechanisms and the current accepted rate expressions for enzyme catalyzed reactions involve a hypothesis where enzyme substrate complex has to be formed .	3.7862103369118056

It gives you a very big inference when we look at the reaction mechanism also and that becomes a very important part of the study of reaction mechanism itself .	4.046098757213366

It can also give you lot of insight into the biological phenomena , the kind of reactions that the enzymes carry out inside the cell at molecular level , their intercellular concentrations , their physiology , directions and regulation .	2.5356233779526636

Lot of issues about the function of the enzymes within the cell can be understood and inferred from the kinetic analysis of the enzyme .	4.032480675022907

Then from the point of view of biochemical engineers probably a very important requirement for enzyme kinetic study is to design enzyme reactors .	3.002628030979354

The design of enzyme reactors , like in the case of chemical reactors is based on kinetic pattern .	4.533670328940541

Finally from academic point of view I think the enzyme kinetics has also played a very important role in classification of the enzymes particularly when the same enzyme is obtained from different sources their kinetic characterization gives you a very good tool to distinguish between them and use them so that you can understand and identify the enzyme based on the kinetic characteristics .	3.13976380833245

We will probably talk when we will come to the actual kinetic aspects .	4.565908522498476

The third point which one must look at before studying the actual enzyme kinetics is some of the historical perspectives that have gone into the study of enzyme kinetics .	2.8522850119826066

The understanding in the mind of the scientists that there are some biological catalysts which catalyze a number of reactions particularly the key reaction which people have understood then thanks to the availability of alcoholic beverages that the yeast possesses some enzyme which hydrolysis sucrose into glucose .	2.3158313783732924

The first enzyme in the whole reaction sequence was invertase which hydrolyses sucrose into glucose and fructose and that was essentially the a key enzyme which people were ready to study .	2.6838477872158673

Many of the kinetic analysis in the early stages when I say early stages I am referring to the late 18th century or early 19th century when people tried to understand the kinetic behavior and I think one of the earliest recorded interpretations or results of the kinetic analysis of enzyme was by O ’ sullivian and Tompson as early as 1890 .	2.3758140363523954

He also studied the same enzyme and probably concluded in a very broad fashion that the enzyme reaction rates are influenced by acidity and enzyme concentration .	3.8399057789143383

These are the two parameters which today we understand as pH and the temperature .	4.284806563973104

He did not propose any basic hypothesis but suggested based on his experimental observations that with every ten degree centigrade rise in temperature the reaction rate doubles .	2.50096027013872

He also gave a good clue which became a landmark in the applications of enzymes that enzymes are more stable in the presence of a substrate .	3.1148145383151435

In fact many of the enzyme preparations then could be stored in the presence of substrate and that was another conclusion or observation he gave way back in 1890 .	3.2885176610107885

We store enzyme in the presence of substrate at low temperatures so that reaction rate is stopped during storage .	4.258336298132006

The low temperature was always understood phenomena that at low temperatures the enzymes will have a much better stability .	3.6237134626673115

They didn ’ t have any concept of enzyme substrate complex in those times and he only gave a hypothetical suggestion that one could store the enzyme at low temperature in the presence of substrate .	2.9079024980214014

Then the second major kinetic observations came from Brown , also in the early 19th century and he proposed for the first time the concept of an enzyme substrate complex .	2.9633392997529473

He also proposed based on experimental observations that the reaction rate for an enzyme catalyzed reaction that is conversion of substrate into product follows saturation kinetics .	3.929350600951187

That means the rate increases initially and reaches to a saturation level .	3.460076407850848

He did not give any experimental or any hypothesis or any sequence of steps but he was able to understand that the basic reaction kinetics follows a saturation behavior .	2.4991003389788085

The rate increases to a maximum level and then stops at that and beyond that there will be no increase in the reaction rate .	3.4373626389577665

At low substrate concentrations the enzyme reaction rate is proportional to substrate concentration .	5.165874388824311

That is the phenomena we still understand , now with our detailed understanding of enzyme kinetics today .	2.9350715024235003

We had earlier discussed the reactor performance equations for three different types of reactors that I used for carrying out the enzyme catalyzed reactions ; that is batch , plug flow reactor and continuous stirred tank reactor .	3.311671498372017

While the choice of the batch reactor is primarily based on many factors other than the reactor performance mainly on the basis of the additional requirements of the reaction .	3.4486958354884547

For example if you require a very stringent pH control or a temperature control or addition of a secondary substrate at a different period other than the beginning of the reaction then batch reactor provides you operational convenience ; a better term would be the use of batch reactor is based on certain operational conveniences .	2.966255459588126

But based on the reactor performance the choice remains between use of a CSTR and a PFR and here I have given a summary of the reactor performance equations for CSTR and PFR and three different kinetic designs .	3.491258830261341

The first line indicates the reactor performance with respect to Michaelis Menten kinetics and the second line refers to when the reactor performance is in the zero order of the design that means when substrate concentration is much higher than the Km value and the third line is in the first order design when the substrate concentration is less than the Km value .	4.063176891904952

Similarly in the case of first order regime it is again the same thing that the K ' m is usually greater than 10S0 ten fold increase usually gives you a reasonable performance towards a first order regime As you have noticed that in the case of zero order regime the reactor performance is identical in both the cases in CSTR and plug flow reactor excepting that the magnitude of the tau is altered by epsilon that is voidage .	3.0578485670306965

Otherwise the reactor performance in the zero order regime is identical .	5.634551237390765

On the other hand in the case of a first order regime the performance of PFR , if you look from the point of view of fractional conversion the fact of fractional conversion on the quantity of enzyme required or the value of the space time , to be able to compare the reactor performance , what we need is to look at two different things : the fraction of conversion and the quantity of enzyme required .	3.5598681330887048

These two parameters can be looked at from these expressions .	4.498253257808523

We also looked at the relative quantity of enzyme required in CSTR to PFR which is given by this ratio and here you will notice that as we increase the fractional conversion the relative quantity of enzyme required for a first order regime significantly increases in the case of CSTR .	3.504486643974276

In the zero order regime there is no difference .	5.149247382277546

So therefore when we shift from zero order to first order regime the efficiency of plug flow reactor improves interms of its enzyme requirement or even in terms of space time .	2.9458787087922835

For example there are two parameters : either you can keep the space time constant and increase the enzyme loading ; or keep the enzyme loading constant and the space time can be varied .	3.929637647533268

In the case of PFR the space time required will be much less compared to CSTR in the first order regime .	3.8813089587860055

In the zero order regime the space time will be identical in the two cases .	4.5867974418368656

The intermediate regime is that where Km and S0 are of comparable value .	3.1919447016798044

That means let us say between one and ten .	5.08524333417633

That means S0 is something like about five Km values .	3.712339730884407

In that case the performance will be dependent not only on the magnitude of the fractional conversion but also on the magnitude of Km value and the relation between S0 and Km .	3.887219806518976

the performance will be dictated .	9.54057776525455

To give you a quantitative picture under three distinct conditions here I have taken three different fractional conversions 0.8 , 0.9 and 0.99 .	3.0021595156664937

I must also state here that ideally for most of the enzyme catalyzed reactions we will try to aim at the fractional conversion as high as possible .	3.3909391222874485

Hundred percent is perfect but very often you may not be able to test that and one will like to have fractional conversion anywhere between 0.9 and 0.99 .	3.0795221743040164

That is usually the pattern if the reaction is irreversible practically irreversible .	4.393114770063194

So under those conditions and assuming S0 equal to1M and epsilon of 0.5 , the Erel in the case of first order regime at 0.8 is 1.24 .	3.0527777501757494

They are any units ; don ' t bother about units .	3.4957271082989756

But these are relative ratio ; so the 1.24 .	4.938928457966718

As soon as you go to 0.9 conversion , the relative quantity of enzyme required is 1.95 ; almost about one and half times .	3.1548447432539777

But when you go from 0.9 to 0.99 , the relative quantity of enzyme becomes more than five times and it very significantly increases the relative quantity in the first order regime .	3.3756228971844204

If you consider from 0.8 to 0.99 , the ratio is still higher and the same relationship will also hold good for space time .	2.7738557675052156

equal to so and so .	7.950739573964562

In the case of zero order regime there is no complication whatever is the fractional conversion the relative quantity required are identical ; the same space time .	3.430349054118772

On the other hand in the case of Michaelis Menten kinetics when the Emrel and S0 are comparable , it will vary and it will be a function of Km ; what the magnitude of Km is in comparison to substrate concentration .	3.05268191802531

We have chosen one molar here .	4.964125894086696

Another important parameter of the reactor design when we defined the parameters is reactor productivity that is Pr and is defined as XS0 / ?	3.4448864361253855

. You will notice that the reactor productivity also is linked with the fractional conversion .	3.959466722127567

In the case of the two types of reactor , the reactor productivity is directly linked with the fractional conversion and as it is also linked with the tau , inversely propositional to tau if the tau increases the productivity goes down .	3.348912026481459

Therefore the fractional conversion , whatever we have discussed about relative quantity of enzyme or the space time as a function of fractional conversion a reverse phenomena or the reverse behavior is true for productivity .	3.2662251169643373

When you increase fractional conversion the productivity will go down and for the first order regime the productivity of PFR will be much , much higher than the CSTR .	3.7973239328831316

I was trying to relate productivity and the quantity of enzyme or the space time .	3.5744364795380283

The quantity of enzyme required and the space time are almost analogous parameters .	3.8819896146318382

Their behavior on the basis of the fractional conversion is identical .	5.664706471422451

But the effect of the fractional conversion on reactor productivity is just reverse because tau appears on the denominator , XS0 / ?	3.4412409995511437

. So if the tau decreases more significantly with fractional conversion the productivity will increase more significantly and therefore in the case of first order regime , the productivity as a function of fractional conversion increases much faster in the case of PFR than CSTR .	2.816803481047813

The quantity of enzyme required or the value of tau increases more in the case of CSTR with increasing fractional conversion but the productivity increases more drastically in the case of PFR when fractional conversion is increased .	3.20565844998194

But in general with increase in fractional conversion the productivity will go down in both the cases because in the reactor performance equation the decrease in tau will be much faster compared to increase in fractional conversion .	3.613105884737032

In general there will be a decline in productivity as fractional conversion increases but the relative decrease will be more pronounced in the case of CSTR than in PFR .	3.2386549053532505

No tau .	27.088212920598018

Relative decrease of productivity , the tau and productivity are related inversely .	3.392585247499902

Therefore the tau increases with increase in fractional conversion more pronouncedly in the case of CSTR , the reverse may happen in the case of productivity .	3.647078570957065

Therefore I think one should very clearly understand the relationship between fractional conversion , enzyme quantity required or the space time and productivity .	3.234443654975351

Very often the choice of the right type of reactor whether to use a CSTR or a PFR is dependent upon the type of the reaction system we are looking at .	3.589554404326304

For example in case we are talking of a very high value product say for example .... transformations , a pharmaceutical product where the cost of product or the cost of substrate is very high .	3.860870083555801

You don ' t want to waste the substrate .	4.344926562956669

Then in such case we would like very high fractional conversion .	4.047801469379226

We will not like any substrate to remain unconverted because the cost of substrate is very high and even at the cost of productivity you go for higher fractional conversion .	3.217947005087163

The productivity will decrease ; but even that is desirable to have a higher fractional conversion and a lower productivity .	3.7682002611302794

On the other hand if you are talking of a lower or reasonable value product or in those cases where even the unconverted substrate can be used along with the product you don ' t have to separate the product for application as in the case of glucose fructose syrup when you isomerise glucose to fructose the final product is a mixture of glucose and fructose .	3.126171148652463

We never attempt to get the reaction converted to completion because then the residence time , space time required in the reactor will be very , very high because it ' s a reversible reaction .	3.9262927243477974

Therefore the final reaction product usually is an equilibrium mixture of glucose and fructose where the fractional conversion is only 0.4 or 0.45 not even 0.8 .	3.010294896889801

No separation is attempted .	8.29828609972405

So in those cases lower fractional conversion but we keep very high stake on productivity ; productivity is tried to be maximized .	2.448929468087997

The cost of the product is not very high so productivity becomes very important parameter .	4.920267794950683

But if the cost of the product is very high which also requires to be separated from unconverted substrate then it will be desirable to have a high fractional conversion even at the cost of productivity .	3.755354086544498

So we must clearly understand the inter relationship between the kinetic order regimes , the fractional conversion and the productivity and the parameter which is very important in the case of reactor performance is the effect of substrate and product inhibition .	3.842324068107181

Most of the enzyme catalyzed reactions will experience some kind of inhibition .	5.231061030367098

One inhibition as we talked that you can add a third component in addition to substrate and product and add another inhibitor either for any purpose of study or anything usually but that doesn ' t come into picture when we talk of industrial reactions using enzymes because we will not like to add inhibitor to the system for carrying out the enzyme catalyzed reaction for commercial purposes .	2.7485771987961356

But still most of the enzyme catalyzed reactions are inhibited naturally by either substrate or the product ; the product is a very common case .	4.592166472631971

For example in the case of CSTR the concentration of substrate in the reaction mixture is very , very low , same as in the outlet or in other way the concentration of product is very high in the reaction mixture .	4.782058163883795

So if a system experiences product inhibition and you use a CSTR you are making the reaction going at very high product concentration .	3.4210557467933675

That means in extremely inhibited conditions the reaction rate can be very , very slow .	4.132779835177729

On the other hand the reverse might be true in the case of plug flow reactor and so the incorporation of effect of substrate and product inhibition on the reactor performance equation becomes very important .	3.3601346755721377

Ks is the substrate inhibition constant , dissociation constant and Km is the natural Km value for the reaction .	3.612345178278807

If you recall we discussed substrate inhibition kinetics in which the excess of substrate causes binding of two substrate molecules to the enzyme molecule and which becomes a dead end complex .	3.1793500037317437

The reaction performance equation gets modified and as you will notice that in the case of substrate inhibition , the performance of CSTR will be far superior .	3.819728161949764

If you can use these two equations and substitute arbitrary values for fractional conversion at a given substrate concentration the performance of CSTR works out to be far superior compared to a plug flow reactor because the concentration of substrate at any given time physically is much lower than in the case of PFR which for bulk part , more than half of the part , substrate concentration is very high only in the upper half .	3.236190060665891

If you look at product inhibition , product inhibition also has influence in two modes .	2.7848677931913186

Either the product can inhibit competitively or non - competitively .	3.9596111598398127

In the case of product inhibition the reaction rate is given by v = k2E0 1 + K ' m / S ( 1 + P / K ' p ) K ' p is the inhibition constant which is the competitive inhibitor of the reaction .	3.9881576897636752

e Even in the case of an uninhibited reaction the relative performance of PFR as the fractional conversion increases is superior .	3.766150912476639

e When the enzyme is subjected to inhibition by excess substrate , it is more serious in the case of a plug flow reactor ; effect of inhibition on the reactor performance is more detrimental in the case of PFR .	3.51200065974661

That means you don ' t use a high substrate concentration right at the beginning .	3.8266423779982848

On the other hand the effect of product inhibition is more serious particularly when high conversions are required .	3.318621622196384

So it is not only the effect of product inhibition which is more serious in the case of a CSTR compared to PFR but when high fractional conversions are required the product inhibition becomes even more serious .	3.1291127605831774

The product inhibition is more detrimental in CSTR compared to PFR because the concentration of product is much higher in the case of CSTR .	3.933382275336937

But when higher fractional conversions are required the problem becomes more and more serious because the product concentration is high when the fractional conversion required is high and therefore in those cases the plug flow reactor becomes almost a necessity .	3.361791075357673

We can divide the operational stability in two major patterns .	4.414841527584894

Mind it ; this t should not be confused with the space time .	4.1288151565267555

Today we will be talking about the role of effector molecules in the kinetics of enzyme catalyzed reactions .	4.263597756398929

You will recall that so far we have seen the role substrate molecules play to influence the rate of an enzymatic reaction .	3.775502629502333

They bind with the enzyme and have dynamic complexes that ultimately break down to form the product .	3.84968572967562

Now this complex , enzyme substrate complex formation can be effected by a number of other external molecules which are not really directly the players in the enzyme reactions .	3.741921446681337

That means neither they are substrate may or may not be products and such molecules are called effector molecules .	2.847833535439436

Those molecules whose presence in a reaction mixture influences the rate of reaction , if it is in increasing the rate of reaction we call them as activators if it is decreasing the reaction rate , we call them inhibitors .	4.163860278350348

The role of these molecules is very important in the kinetics of enzyme catalyzed reactions for certain reasons .	4.320790546275876

One is that they give you a picture on the reaction rate in the presence of those molecules .	5.134964829327298

You can regulate the reaction rate to an enhanced value or to a decreased value in the presence of those molecules .	3.3182982541396258

In fact in the living cells also these molecules provide a regulatory device to control the rate of reaction .	3.1182048372900018

We will see when we go on subsequently how many of the molecules control the rate of reaction by inhibiting or activating a particular enzyme in the beginning of a metabolic pathway .	3.7767193483636308

Most of the information on the architecture of the active sites , which are the functional groups that are present on the active sites or the mechanism of the specificity , has resulted from the understanding of the interaction of inhibitor molecules or activator molecules in the enzyme catalyzed reactions .	3.5876397308492334

Particularly in the case of multisubstrate reactions which we will be dealing subsequently where more than one substrate molecule takes part in the enzyme catalyzed reaction their kinetic mechanism is also understood by the role of certain external effector molecules .	3.535759153553195

That is another major advantage .	6.7656926387644445

So these are the issues that provide us a very important understanding towards the role of effector molecules .	3.3195843557297775

But even on the practical aspect probably from the industrial aspect also effector molecules are very important because in large number of drugs and the preservatives that are used commercially they basically work on the principle of modulating the enzyme reaction rate .	2.526148489039557

We are aware of many of the sulphur drugs .	5.45751114536393

In fact all the sulphur drugs are basically inhibitors of one or the other enzyme operating in the living system .	2.9590798698887464

The only care that is taken in designing a drug is that the particular molecule which acts as an inhibitor for a particular toxic substance or let us say for an infection should not be toxic to the human beings .	3.1306516736446146

Most of the materials that we use , whether they are sulphur drugs or antibiotics , they are inhibitors or activators of certain enzymes .	2.4092263458525243

So from that point of view , understanding their interaction is quite important .	3.87620152546251

Activators are molecules , as name suggest , that enhance the rate of enzyme catalyzed reactions .	3.7995662305600733

Some of the activator molecules may be absolutely essential for a given enzyme reaction .	3.8040552176854203

Some may not be so .	9.689317557043154

They may only provide stability to enzyme substrate complex .	4.018223036669713

Therefore the nature of activator molecules might differ from case to case .	3.6997709258077496

Typical examples of some of the activators are for example in the case of alpha amylase , calcium ions act as activators which is known to stabilize the enzyme substrate complex .	3.46581149739741

In the absence of calcium ions , the enzyme substrate complex is not very stable or the dissociation constant of enzyme substrate complex is relatively high and therefore the rate of reaction will be very , very slow .	4.379138438060988

That is another example of an absolute requirement of an activator .	4.254437823031143

In the absence of magnesium ions the enzyme will not be functionally catalytically active and therefore these activators function by participating or facilitating in either enzyme substrate binding or in stabilizing the enzyme substrate complex .	2.65313140464675

The difference between cofactors and activators is a cofactor will have to participate in the catalytic mechanism .	3.2598942026194155

Take for example a cofactor like a NAD .	4.446660001720366

It is used in the oxidation reduction reactions and in the absence of any such residue in the active site which can participate in the oxidation reduction reaction , the NAD provides a molecule which undergoes redox reaction and therefore catalyzes the reaction .	3.0513640735461376

It also plays a role in substrate binding and the role of cofactor is absolutely essential .	3.6858943583794623

The reaction cannot take place in the absence of cofactor whereas in the case of activator we are only enhancing the rate .	3.870176152283658

The rate may not come to zero .	5.133750396023978

It might have a very small insignificant rate in the absence of an activator and in the presence , the rate might enhance .	4.664297696149589

Mg2 + is an absolute requirement .	8.018659603024005

So it falls in the category of both actually .	4.093282289718859

It also participates in the catalytic mechanism .	5.438404243931002

True example of activators will be calcium ions which do not take part in the catalytic function but provides stability to enzyme substrate complex .	3.104673740834197

That means binding process is facilitated .	5.825722551387422

So magnesium is something on interface .	4.945515733841777

Looking at activators from the mechanistic point of view , the role of activators can be considered as binding to the enzyme molecule to give you an activated enzyme .	3.9419793684899465

When the activator molecule binds to it , the EA complex becomes an active enzyme complex .	3.4391593853041424

This EA complex will bind with the substrate which is the active enzyme substrate complex .	6.115457956924831

This enzyme substrate complex can break down to the active enzyme plus product with k1 , k - 1 and k2 .	4.028734867562601

If we consider that the dissociation constant of activator binding to the enzyme is Ka , then in that case the rate of such reaction can be expressed as Vi = Vm .S Km { 1 + Ka / A } + S You ultimately end up in a rate expression in which the Km term is modified .	4.029729800164202

This can be written as Vm .	6.993226108738155

One can also see that the modified Km value is Km ’ = Km { 1 + Ka / A } That is when A becomes very , very large the activator concentration present in the reaction is much larger in comparison to Ka .	3.447839979843525

That means when we have sufficient quantity of activator present as required , the K ’ m approaches to that of intrinsic Km or K ’ m / Km = 1 .	3.0458856940780508

Also when the activator is zero or when there is no activator present , the enzyme reaction will not take place because modified Km value will be too large .	3.5520353927899584

There will be no effective binding taking place and that means the secondary step will be ruled out .	3.3456455995538152

Therefore the activator molecules can influence the reaction rate in an enzyme catalyzed process by this simple way to modify the Km value .	3.9725020957186956

The second category of effector molecules that we noted was inhibitors .	3.46891767997825

As the name suggests , these are those molecules which decrease the rate of an enzyme catalyzed reactions when present in the reaction mixture .	4.2096954435265515

They form complexes with enzyme molecule , enzyme substrate molecule , both or one of them .	3.29733548840173

They form dynamic complexes with the enzyme and enzyme substrate complexes and thereby influence the rate of reaction .	3.680833156480924

The inhibition patterns or inhibitors can be classified into two main classes .	3.684700241604113

One is irreversible inhibitors , which means that the inhibitor molecule binds to the enzyme in an irreversible fashion and cannot be recovered or revoked by physical operations .	3.413746757995976

Very often when into a reaction mixture if you have added an inhibitor molecule , one can remove it by physical method say for example by dialysis or ultra filtration or any of those methods .	3.0103066299467867

But irreversible inhibitors cannot be removed once added to a reaction mixture and their effect is irreversible .	2.973283030810072

That means ultimately they will tend to reduce the rate of reaction and provide a poisonous effect on the rate of reaction .	3.88746252722046

In fact some times there are also called catalytic poisons because they irreversibly poison the catalyst .	2.5596309171214595

In most of the cases the effect is such that the reaction rate or catalytic function of the enzyme approaches to inactive form and thereby they cannot be used for catalytic functions .	4.438685978871115

Reversible inhibition is caused by chemical modification of one of the amino acids residues on the active site .	3.889089690878725

Most of the chemical modification reagents that are used for modification of the enzyme active sites do play a role in the irreversible inhibition .	4.323159663210748

Most of the alkylating agents will alkylate some of the amino acids residues and thereby make the enzyme inactive .	3.155404470756381

Many of the heavy metals like mercury or some of the poisonous gases also have the same action of irreversible inhibition whereby saving the person become difficult .	2.6239790616779812

The role of irreversible inhibitors can be expressed as ki kin E + I EI Einac k - i The first step shows a reversible process but the process doesn ’ t stop here .	2.3357280977034245

Once EI is formed it goes into an inactive first order irreversible step which inactivates the enzyme and the concentration of EI at any given time can be expressed as EI = ( E0 - EI ) .I / ki where ki is the dissociation constant for the inhibitor and then one can write the inactivation rate as Vi = Kin [ EI ] = kin E0 / 1 + ki / I Therefore if I is in excess , if the magnitude of inhibitor is in excess , such that you can consider that there is a constant , then the whole expression is a first order rate constant that is kd.E0 where kd a first order rate constant assuming that I is in excess and can be considered as constant .	3.026395521039519

Such reactions are very often noted to be poisonous in nature .	4.156924486342897

Most of the substances that are technically called poisons whether it is mercury or cyanide or nerve gas and things like that they all behave in the form of irreversible inhibitors .	2.5337294005172732

Except to understand their role to evolve methods to prevent the poisoning they don ’ t have much of industrial value .	2.926245364005671

It is mostly reversible inhibitors which play a key role in most of the industrial processes .	3.8047091355788103

In the second category of reversible inhibitors , the inhibitor binds to the enzyme in a reversible manner .	3.8027353676751976

That means after the addition of the inhibitor to an enzyme substrate mixture one can physically remove it .	3.607226520000362

The physical methods most commonly used are ultra filtration or dialysis such that the enzyme is fully restored to its initial activity .	3.4169733772554367

In the presence of inhibitor their activity will be decreased but once you remove it physically , the original activity of the enzyme is recovered .	3.5671407517993443

In a sense these molecules make dynamic complexes with the enzyme which have different catalytic properties to that of the native enzyme .	3.495421968956717

Different inhibitor molecules bind differently to the enzyme molecule or enzyme substrate complex such that the catalytic properties are altered and thereby the rate of reaction is altered .	4.10530435345872

Our total orientation to study the inhibitors will be mostly directed towards the understanding the reversible inhibition .	2.814755082368816

There are certain general patterns which we follow in studying reversible inhibition and before we go to the individual cases I like to highlight that .	2.7695834178915217

The first thing that we must look at is the pattern of binding of inhibitor to enzyme or enzyme substrate complex .	3.512027857111705

How does a particular group of inhibitors bind to the enzyme molecules ?	4.456726624456664

You are proposing an operational reaction mechanism which may be slightly different than that proposed by Michaelis Menten or others earlier as we discussed and that mechanism need to be understood very clearly and that will give you a physical picture of the enzyme substrate binding .	3.1977993880610276

The second thing is , on the basis of this binding process you develop a rate expression .	4.06145764113667

We always tend to compare a rate of expression with that of Michaelis Menten rate expression .	3.903676517669348

Then look at the effect of the inhibitor concentration on Km or Vm or both of the reaction .	4.83715784607137

First we have looked at the binding pattern .	6.3718173844178745

Based on the binding pattern , we develop a rate expression compare it to the Michaelis Menten equation and see how the Km and Vm of the native enzyme are influenced by the presence of inhibitors .	3.5710308538961915

If a double reciprocal plot is plotted between 1 / S and 1 / V as a function of inhibitor concentration how does this represent ?	3.145385058632132

Fifthly another important pattern is for each class of inhibition , there is degree of inhibition .	3.0484739637124414

That means we define a term degree of inhibition called i which is nothing but v0 - vi / v0 .	3.703587646725252

If v0 is the rate of uninhibited reaction , classically Michaelis Menten kinetics , and vi is the rate expression for inhibited reaction , the degree of inhibition that is produced by the presence of inhibitor is obtained even from a theoretical rate expression .	3.4561347907991378

You can work out an expression for degree of inhibition and that will have a characteristic pattern which can distinguish a particular type of a reversible inhibition .	3.469409725784537

All other reversible inhibition studies will be based on these five approaches in general .	3.0712338563771526

Probably one of the simplest and the most commonly encountered pattern of reversible inhibition is what we know as competitive inhibition .	4.2158992137556135

As the name suggests , competitive inhibitor combines with the free enzyme on the same site which is the substrate binding site and therefore the inhibitor competes for the binding site with the substrate .	4.120215613011094

Usually both inhibitor and substrate molecules are mutually exclusive and compete with each other .	3.195488769315088

The inhibitor binding site on the enzyme molecule and substrate binding site on the enzyme molecule are identical .	4.529851543405758

This should be taken in a very broad sense .	7.713241729704982

It is not always necessary that the binding site has to be exactly the same as that of substrate .	4.615226608305131

The purpose is that the presence of inhibitor makes the binding of the substrate difficult in a competitive mode .	4.076171579393066

That means the proximity may be such that the inhibitor molecule has such a confirmation that the original binding site is disturbed and substrate binding is not feasible or alternatively after binding of the inhibitor molecule the substrate binding site might be modified in such a way that substrate binding is not feasible .	2.726273751266441

All those cases , variety of cases will come under the category of competitive inhibition and the purpose is that the presence of inhibitor must reduce because reversible inhibition depends on the concentrations of the two species , inhibitor and substrate and they will affect the binding mechanism .	3.2681771193238833

A very typical example and probably the most easily understood example is of oxidation of succinic acid to fumaric acid .	2.9168926868733167

This is inhibited by a molecule closely resembling the substrate , malonic acid which has two carboxyl groups but only one methyl group , unlike succinic acid .	2.3063891513850674

It is very similar in confirmation and very often enzyme active site mistakes it for succinic acid and therefore it acts as a competitive inhibitor in the same reaction .	3.5365027840485577

It acts as a competitive inhibitor for folic acid biosynthesis from para amino benzoic acid .	2.8066877305369884

The amino group on the aromatic ring is identical in both the molecules .	4.033967276486633

This is sulfanilamide and this is para amino benzoic acid .	4.6589757524272075

So to summarize the competitive inhibition , we must notice that the inhibitor molecule binds to an enzyme molecule at a site either on the same side which is ear marked for substrate molecule or at a site in proximity to it in such a way that it interferes or restricts the binding of the substrate molecule onto the enzyme site and therefore it competes for the binding process on the enzyme molecule .	3.017240798363202

There is no binding of the inhibitor molecule with the enzyme substrate molecule once the substrate molecule has bound to the enzyme , the inhibitor is ineffective .	4.897365908819753

That means the total enzyme concentration is distributed between inhibitor and substrate and that is one .	4.822578422084388

Second thing is the enzyme catalyzed reaction in the presence of a competitive inhibitor results in an increased km value and the Vm value is totally not affected .	4.013003100980015

Third thing is that the effect of the competitive inhibitor can be successfully overcome to a significant extent if you increase the substrate concentration to a very large value as compared to inhibitor concentration .	4.010264488203073

Because they are competing on the same side , if the concentration of substrate is much , much larger than inhibitor then the possibility of substrate molecule binding to enzyme is much more and once substrate molecule is bound the enzyme will no longer be available for inhibitor to act upon .	3.170146775128611
