Today we shall discuss about the effect of immobilization on functional properties of the enzyme molecules .	4.978291126313782

We have seen a number of immobilization methods that we have discussed in previous classes .	4.676892364096453

We see that in most cases the enzyme undergoes loss of activity during immobilization .	4.595153675722896

In fact no method can ensure that you can recover the enzyme in hundred percent yield .	3.7021525187293935

The yield can vary depending on the method of immobilization , depending on the carrier and the stability of the enzyme itself with respect to the conditions of immobilization .	4.337301933120484

By real I mean that you cannot recover , after the immobilization , the original enzyme activity by physical interventions .	3.381815956313947

On the other hand the apparent loss refers to the reduced enzyme activity that you are measuring but by certain physical interventions the original activity can be restored .	2.6813850880428367

It is not a permanent loss of activity but due to certain physical forces which make a interplay with the catalytic function , the enzyme activity seems apparently to have been lost .	2.9465208664502063

The reasons for the two types of losses , the real and apparent , could be attributed to one or more of the following four factors that are listed here .	2.7739261648640623

The first and foremost factor is the change in the enzyme conformation itself .	5.32457441868943

When the soluble enzyme is immobilized on to a matrix the interaction between the matrix and the enzyme amino acids might lead to certain conformational changes possibly due to the result of involvement of some of the amino acids residues in the immobilization process .	3.7346697412354466

Very often it has been noticed that a very common feature is that upon immobilization an enzyme may undergo some kind of unfolding ; some kind of a stretching .	3.287297779354457

There are no parameters which can be simply measured .	6.181026716633036

A detailed analysis or detailed study on the conformation , just like what we do as for identification of the globular structure the tertiary structure of the enzyme , one can study .	3.0694497151168223

But other wise a quick quantitative measure of the conformational loss is only through measurement of enzyme activity .	2.899965873930799

For example here you see that this is a typical soluble enzyme shown here .	4.543344391190415

It has been immobilized on to a solid matrix by some bonds ; it could be an electrostatic bond ; it could be a metal salt linkage ; it could be covalent bond or it could also be as an entrapment within a gel .	3.237419642367779

Entrapment within a gel fortunately does not involve the amino acids of the enzyme protein and therefore the chances of any conformational change during gel entrapment are minimum .	3.573923961730062

Then during immobilization , the enzyme may under go some conformational changes .	3.766568095984164

Just a hypothetical change I have shown here .	4.308457504449734

It could be in any shape .	6.231993553375615

It could be simply unfolding ; it could be some kind of stretching and it may lead to a totally inactive enzyme preparation or a reduced activity of an enzyme preparation .	3.4228622608698744

Reduced activity means that the protein content will be reduced .	5.449338851075443

The specific activity of the enzyme that means the enzyme activity in terms of international units per milligram of protein might get reduced .	4.638957964242391

There have been certain exceptions .	5.997449388335953

I am saying exceptions which are rare examples where the enzyme activity after the immobilization has also been analyzed .	3.87266112687035

If the conformational changes are more favorable to the factors that are responsible for reduction in activation energy either by strain or any other mechanism that we discussed earlier by entropic or enthalpic changes which reduce the energy of activation for the enzyme catalyzed reaction , it might also lead to favorable conformational change .	2.9341896178996674

But those examples are indeed rare and not very common examples .	3.8398630563426854

Then the second factor which is responsible for loss of enzyme activity is steric hindrance .	3.8914502803713207

In many cases the immobilization process might involve the reduction in the access of the substrate molecule to the enzyme active site .	3.9247814086520068

You have achieved a good binding but the enzyme active sites are hindered from access to the substrate molecule .	3.328565623041138

A typical case is shown here .	5.537750385915404

In this case , the enzyme has been immobilized on sites which are in very great proximity to the active site and therefore the participation or the involvement of the substrate with the active sites is reduced and that also results in reduced enzyme activity .	3.510522512203509

However such a enzyme activity can be recovered or this phenomena can be reduced if you can use a proper choice of the method for immobilization .	3.643476785256684

In some of the cases the steric hindrances can be minimized by introduction of the spacer arm .	3.6947623028628707

That means between the binding sites introduction of a spacer arm which is usually a hydrocarbon chain and which can make the binding more flexible and there by the steric hindrances can be reduced .	3.1570355068661167

But in a particular method of immobilization the steric hindrance results in a definite loss of enzyme activity which is a real loss and cannot be recovered by physical methods .	3.4003540616707397

For example if you have covalently bound an enzyme i.e. , by covalent bond depending on the method of binding if you have not involved a spacer arm the loss will remain there .	2.9209999852210746

But you cannot recover that .	7.02111288230486

Unless you modify enzyme immobilization procedure whereby a spacer arm is introduced then you can reduce the steric hindrance .	3.2367114588832506

The method can be modified to result in reduced loss as a result of steric hindrance .	3.457308035908338

But once a preparation has been made with a definite amount of steric hindrance , the loss is real .	3.116215234997095

The third factor which contributes to loss of enzyme activity is partitioning effect .	4.073436290309733

We must consider immobilized enzymes in the light of a shift from homogenous catalysis to heterogeneous catalysis .	3.0049279327401024

Instead of looking at the catalytic reaction in a homogenous phase where the catalyst is dissolved in the same medium as the reactant here the catalyst has a different phase - solid phase and the substrate is in the liquid phase .	3.4046348727394884

You lead into a heterogeneous catalysis and the various species that are involved in the reaction , it could be a substrate ; it could be inhibitor ; it could be simple hydrogen ions which contribute to the pH ; they might get partitioned in the two phases depending on the chemical nature of the bulk and the carrier particles and this partition effect can also lead to an apparent loss of enzyme activity in a particular situation .	3.337817747311615

The fourth is the diffusional limitations .	6.130636709583012

A result of incorporation of a solid particle in a reaction mixture and particularly we consider a porous solid particle where most of the enzyme has been immobilized on the interior of the particle .	3.150297673788705

When a solid particle is immersed into a liquid phase there is also bound to be a stationary film of liquid around the particle .	2.8441047491002953

This film thickness can vary depending on the physical properties of the substrate solution ; for example viscosity or density .	3.9142172917445603

They may control the film thickness and these might call also a diffusional constraint particularly with respect to transport of the substrate from the bulk to the site of enzyme catalyzed reaction .	2.833121940072531

The two effects the partitioning effect and the mass transfer of the diffusional effect can be visualized here If you notice here for example in the right hand side diagram we have assumed a hypothetical carrier preparation which is poly anionic in nature .	2.9793017560207677

That means it is highly negatively charged and an enzyme molecule is entrapped or located in the midst of negative charges .	3.072851698877685

The total charge inside the carrier particle or around enzyme where the catalysis is going to take place will be different than in the bulk .	3.67100833088805

If in case the substrate also happens to be a charged molecule , so there will be some partitioning effects of the substrate between the bulk and so the real substrate concentration what we are considering in the bulk phase will not be same at the site of the enzyme reactions .	3.909425514893347

I will come to that .	6.5584590984594495

I am just describing the right hand side one .	5.085652770792932

There could be very clear cut partitioning effects with respect to hydrogen ions because they are positively charged and a poly ionic carrier will definitely have preference for hydrogen ions .	2.6233004377939033

Therefore the hydrogen ion concentration inside the carrier will be greater than the bulk .	4.45236982538126

Similarly if the substrate is also positively charged you are going to have higher substrate concentration in the carrier or at the site of enzyme rather than the bulk or it could be the other way .	4.108655426771576

If suppose the substrate is also negatively charged the reverse might happen .	3.9317345648377264

That means the bulk concentration vary more than at the site of the reaction .	3.5836204496001063

That might lead to the apparent effect on the enzyme activity .	7.112210629895644

On the left hand side I have shown the diffusional effects .	4.173443311138709

In fact a very large percentage , more than ninety percent of the enzyme will be distributed on the porous network within the particle .	3.5868784187301057

Only very small fraction will be on the surface and for the reaction to take place the substrate has to diffuse from the bulk to the site of the enzyme reaction .	4.156873078869389

Here you notice that in the case of the immobilize enzyme unlike a soluble enzyme what we are conventionally used to where the enzyme is in direct proximity with the substrate and can interact and reaction can take place without any resistance other than the chemical reaction , the biochemical reaction .	3.4587234422436204

Here in addition to biochemical reaction you have another limitation .	5.906075150615927

That means the bulk substrate has to diffuse through the stationary film which is on the surface of the particle .	3.603003637768968

This surface , they have a thickness delta on the basis of the physical properties of the substrate molecule and the carrier particle .	4.600322772504113

The thickness of the stationary film can be reduced by changing the flow properties in the reactor stream and as we will see further that the effect of thickness of the stationary film can be reduced if you increase the linear field velocity in a continuous reactor or increase agitation speed in a stirred vessel in a stirred reactor .	3.2252200917822997

So you can reduce it .	7.8502343502801075

But any way it has to transfer from the bulk phase to the stationary phase and their might be some concentration gradient in the substrate .	3.659141665523751

From the surface , the substrate has to move to the enzyme active site and the enzyme is distributed all over the particle .	5.202807741397341

Depending on the particle thickness , let us say diameter of the particle is dp the substrate might be able to reach only up to a part of the carrier .	4.032220767887734

Let us say it reaches up to here .	4.374382203948657

The substrate value comes down to zero .	4.99348003239386

This means that a fraction of the total enzyme available in the immobilize preparation is not able to interact with the substrate because of diffusion limitations .	3.8539267410334417

This will depend on the relative rate of diffusion vis - à - vis , the rate of biochemical catalysis .	4.682021454295909

The slower rate will dominate the effect .	4.609372103692501

If suppose the biochemical reaction rate is very fast compared to rate of diffusion of the substrate into the carrier particle , it might happen that soon after the surface of the catalyst particle the substrate concentration might drop to a very small level or even to zero depending on the rate of diffusion which is smaller than that .	3.852772724596473

So in case of enzyme reactions where enzymes have a very high activity or in other words a few are able to make a preparation which has a very high enzyme loading that means the amount of enzymes in terms of international units per gram of the carrier particle if that can be increased to a significant level , then the system can be operated which is under diffusion limitations .	3.774264284897545

If you are able to prepare an immobilize enzyme preparation with a very high enzyme loading that means the catalytic rate is very high .	3.7096921825007154

Enzyme loading high means the catalytic rate will be very high because the enzyme activity in terms of international units , the reaction rate per unit weight of the carrier , if that is very high compared to the rate of diffusion then the whole system can be conceived to be totally diffusion limited .	4.2125016749180695

The biochemical reaction kinetics will not have a major role to play and the whole thing will be controlled by the physical diffusion .	3.769739733012639

I have told you two kinds of effect of diffusion .	4.381672872085022

One is the external film diffusion .	6.2062565002038275

The other is the diffusional limitations caused by the boundary layer film , inert film on the boundary as external film diffusion .	2.8281500870605245

On the other hand , the diffusional process within the pores of the particle or internal pore diffusion .	2.8258064508514207

The two types of diffusion , we will subsequently see their quantitative analysis in relation to the biochemical reaction but we shall understand that these two processes will put you four additional resistances over and above the biochemical reaction .	2.4504241707376972

Ultimately for all practical purposes our measurements or monitoring will be in the bulk .	4.045702990465644

So the product has to also transport and it might also undergo a kind of a gradient .	3.7748974792212033

Just to illustrate a little more detail on the transport behavior consider a typical spherical particle with an external film shown here .	2.4172759459126545

This is substrate concentration .	9.56923599579231

“a ” is shown as substrate concentration at the bulk phase , that means at the entry of the boundary layer .	3.6564393573805862

There will be a gradient of substrate in the boundary layer .	5.364403013224516

This gradient will depend on the thickness of the boundary layer and you can minimize this by increasing a very high agitation speed in the stirred reactor or increase a very high linear flow velocity in a continuous reactor .	3.3450947429155122

There is a reduction but in the internal porous structure the substrate concentration may undergo also a gradient .	3.547677868330084

This gradient it might so happen that it comes down to zero .	3.4558109616477553

The substrate concentration comes down to zero at this point and therefore all the enzyme present in this phase is not available and apparently it will look as if there is an enzyme activity loss .	3.778817105240097

So the enzyme activity loss as a result of diffusional limitations is a totally apparent loss .	4.485904424756064

If you reduce the particle size to the extent that the rate of diffusion is enough to counter or enough to take the substrate up to the interior of the particle .	2.975249175430262

That means if you can reduce the particle let us say if this particle was only of this much size and this is the center , then it could happen that the enzyme might reach up to the center of the particle .	3.476868890788762

The substrate might reach at the centre of the particle and all the particle is interacting with the substrate .	3.731169923512112

So there is no activity loss and that is what really I meant by the apparent loss of the enzyme activity that means by some physical interventions , by reducing the particle size one can overcome the internal pore diffusion .	3.053380814873969

Similarly by increasing the agitation speed in the stirred vessel one can reduce or totally reduce the thickness of the film and thereby the gradient on the external film diffusion can be minimized .	2.757182255593456

In the part b and c , you notice the combined effect of partitioning and diffusion .	3.1814817834964573

You see here in the bulk phase , the part b shows that in the carrier particle the diffusional limitations are not very high .	4.885755873986716

Although there is a very , very mild concentration gradient , the substrate is present all through the carrier particle .	4.6856141998856025

But the concentration of the substrate in the carrier is higher than the bulk .	7.024318446047137

So there is a partitioning effect .	6.4472369203350315

That means the chemical nature of the carrier has more affinity for the substrate than the bulk .	3.9392200243720645

In the c part the reverse is there .	4.501089958225806

The substrate has lower affinity that means suddenly from this boundary surface the concentration drops and there is a partitioning .	3.137701224417822

So these pictures shows the first one is totally diffusion ; the b and c part indicate the combined effect of diffusion and partitioning .	2.8527643657734476

These are the four major parameters or the factors which cause the various effects on the functional properties of the enzymatic reaction .	3.3199178795913173

Whenever we have to look at any particular feature of an immobilized enzyme reaction , we have to look into these four effects and try to find an answer to the observed behavior .	3.5049097460851817

Let us look at some of them .	6.678287006575007

The first is effect of pH .	6.850484645122478

Very often we look at enzyme catalyzed reaction unknown to have an optimum pH and particularly in the case of immobilization by ionic binding it has been noted that there is an apparent shift in the optimum pH .	3.729731219842682

When you take a soluble enzyme , a native enzyme and determine its optimum pH as against the optimum pH of an immobilized preparation you find that the optimum pH has shifted and this shift is attributed mainly to the partitioning of hydrogen ions between bulk and the carrier particles .	2.990985882386898

That means the partitioning effect of the hydrogen ions between the bulk and the carrier particle depends on the nature of charge .	4.339861819881931

If suppose the carrier is negatively charged , there will be higher concentration of the hydrogen ions compared to the bulk and vice versa and therefore in the case of a negatively charged carrier , the apparent shift in pH will be on the alkaline side .	3.7248395801033105

Because for the higher pH in the bulk the actual pH in the carrier particle will be lower .	4.62941111427648

Hydrogen ion concentration is more in the carrier .	7.295450126133694

So there will be apparent shift in the pH optimum because what we are considering we are not varying the pH in the carrier particle ; we are varying the bulk pH .	3.596083563672267

So at even a higher bulk pH at the enzyme reactive site the pH will be lower and so we will consider it almost like an apparent shift in the optimum pH on the alkaline side and the reverse is true .	3.022673939794539

If suppose you take a polycationic carrier , the shift will be on the acidic side .	3.819428813053486

The second effect of pH is on pH stability ; the same thing , the same partitioning effect .	3.4978702739549927

Particularly in some cases of the enzymes which are known to be more stable under alkaline side or acidic side , an immobilization can lead to increased or decreased stability of the enzyme depending on their behavior , although the pH stability as well as optimum pH in the real sense at the molecular level does not change .	3.095919008500084

The behavior remains the same .	6.93889586532786

It ’ s only an apparent change in the monitoring system because we are measuring in the bulk and therefore the two effects are noted .	3.8800169465398353

If you consider the stability fact of the enzyme with respect to pH certain enzymes are more stable under alkaline conditions .	3.5744928855042923

So the immobilization to an anionic polymer will be able to give you a more stable preparation with respect to pH .	3.940502320127488

I am talking of stability with respect to pH and not thermal .	3.896100528276194

There will be no effect on thermal as a partitioning effect .	4.023822700496584

But there will be some effect on the pH stability because the pH what you are offering to the enzyme particle in the bulk is not the same at the enzyme active site .	4.227868005645191

It is reduced and if it is less stable at the alkaline pH , then even at the higher pH the enzyme particle may show higher pH stability .	3.287543778176219

Right . They are the same .	11.079666086191535

The physical reason which attributes to both the effects is identical .	3.419441302606148

That is partitioning of the hydrogen ions between the bulk and the carrier particle .	3.645821350209586

As an example if you look at some of the optimum pH of the immobilized preparations , which are reported in literature you notice that in most cases here the effects are mostly on ionic binding .	3.9030719055645045

But the pH effects are noted on a minor site in cases of gel entrapment and non - specific binding and particularly crosslinking effects also .	2.584946318354411

But they may be a result of a very complex system which cannot be defined very accurately but ionic binding can be defined very accurately .	3.6282835314926905

In trypsin by binding on to DEAE Sephadex the free enzyme pH which was 8.5 was reduced to 7.0 .	2.878797684671034

Similarly on invertase DEAE cellulose , 5.4 to 3.3 , the immobilized enzyme optimum pH is reduced .	4.093759846661247

Yes . Diethylaminoethylether has lot of amino groups with positively charged matrix and therefore the enzyme activity is reversed .	3.8308558975227744

On the other hand look at an example here on physical absorption on bentonite .	2.598066678002785

Bentonite is clay with high negative charge and this attributes to an increase in the optimum pH .	3.3379067656935497

Some optimum pH changes have also been reported in the case of crosslinking but their effect of change in the optimum pH is a result of some other conformational interactions and not due to partitioning .	3.290832097420012

Particularly the last example of the immobilization of NADH hydrogenase by crosslinking also indicates the shift of the optimum pH but here the optimum pH shift will not be attributed to partitioning effect .	3.269215881566133

It could be due to some of the conformational changes as a result of crosslinking because conformational changes also can bring in some change in the optimum pH .	3.4309319428330705

I must give you an example of glucose isomerase .	6.866128177151083

A very significant property of apparent change in the enzyme optimum pH has bee used by immobilizing those enzymes to a positively charged matrix .	2.910980762759889

The other effect of this immobilization is on the kinetic parameters .	4.960822549336097

Although the kinetic parameters of the enzymes does not change in the real sense but there are apparent changes in the kinetic parameters .	4.336488323989173

First we consider the km , the Michaelis Menten constant .	5.902733860583721

In most cases you will notice , if you look into literature , that the km value undergo a change .	4.046378459404624

The changes can be of various nature .	5.031638443947353

Different methods have yielded increase in km value , decrease in km value and sometimes no change in km also .	3.3324504536299484

The change in km value can be attributed to diffusional limitations as well as partitioning of substrate .	4.27950954082102

Very often wherever the substrate is also a charged molecule similar partitioning effect will take place .	3.857601556191154

There will be a difference in the substrate concentration between the bulk and the enzyme active site as we saw in the substrate profile of the immobilized enzyme particle that in the bulk phase and in the immobilized carrier particle , there will be a substrate gradient and depending on the chemical nature that will undergo and kappm can also be related to km of the native enzyme by kappm = kmez.e. ?	3.628951756955324

/ kt where z is the number of charges .	6.539655421799163

It ’ s an observed change .	5.706374717815266

…… does not change really ; on the on the substrate if we consider the charges on the substrate .	4.818491053538981

The second reason for the apparent change in km would be attributed to diffusional limitations .	3.2942746097020414

The effects due to diffusional limitations on km have been clearly demonstrated by experimental data because if you just use an immobilized enzyme preparation in a reactor and measure km by reducing the particle size you are able to come to a km value which is of the native enzyme which only implies that the diffusional limitations are playing a role .	2.8503544915057497

One of the result reports the km value of the immobilized glucoamylase on different substrates : soluble starch , amylopectin , amylose and maltose ; four different substrates which can be acted upon by glucoamylase or amyloglucosidase .	2.7812834661314043

For the free enzyme the km values are given here on the left hand side .	3.6241230603762222

For the immobilized enzyme you see the km values have significantly increased except on maltose where it has decreased .	3.5007347499216563

This also gives you the feature that the molecular weight of the substrate can also influence the partitioning effect because the maltose being the smallest molecular weight molecule substrate here , it can easily and freely pass through a carrier particle and thereby one can achieve a much higher km value compared to the insoluble one .	3.19039324819343

km in the case of maltose has decreased .	7.021304352719543

It has decreased means higher affinity ; the concentration of the substrate in the enzyme active site is much higher .	4.697333026424945

So it affects particularly high molecular weights substrates and they behave in a reverse way .	3.0832330553511302

This has to be taken care while preparing the immobilized enzyme preparation so that the km value does not increase because otherwise it will lead to a less sufficient catalysis .	3.67821102758958

Another data is on the influence of particle size on the Michaelis constant of immobilized enzyme .	4.058082466913543

If you look at soluble starch as substrate as a function of particle size , particle size being in micro meters the km value increases as the particle size increases .	2.7971440275395394

For example roughly about two fold increase causes 19.3 grams per liter to 31.6 , a very significant increase in km value .	3.154345494206462

Similarly on the external film diffusion also the linear velocity of the immobilized glucoamylase using the 30 % weight by weight 40DE corn syrup , the data here are important in the case of starch syrup because starch syrup when we use for hydrolysis we use a very thick syrup .	2.730314026961748

Even in the case of glucose isomerase when we carry out the industrial reactions , the substrate concentration which is used is about 2.5 - 3 molar glucose which means almost about 45 - 50 % weight by volume .	3.7047572849115604

So it is very thick syrup and at such thick syrup , the boundary film can be very thick .	3.3024347501966314

The film thickness can be very high and external film diffusion in those cases where we use substrates as very thick syrup is usually very high and external film also becomes a major parameter and as shown here if you consider a packed bag reactor with a liner flow velocity from 0.85cm / min to almost as high as 14.5 almost twenty fold increase gives you a km value which decreases from 7.76 to 3.79 almost half the initial value of km .	2.5805702946206623

That means if you are able to overcome external film diffusion the increase in linear velocity means you are reducing the thickness of the boundary film and that ’ s why when we talk of km we are talking only apparent change and not the real change .	3.2810866659282736

The other parameter which is important in the case of kinetic parameter is change in k2 that is the turn over number or in other words you can say if you multiply with the enzyme concentration it becomes Vm¬ .	3.855940167158949

That is if the enzyme undergoes a conformational change its specific activity will undergo a change .	3.5656322272311933

In some cases the change has been favorable .	4.715283981777652

There have been reports , although rare not very common , that the enzyme activity increases as a consequence of immobilization .	3.4266174336086586

Another functional parameter is temperature which is important for all catalyzed reactions .	4.2734769302716975

Just like optimum pH , we also need an optimum temperature for a reaction which is known for a native enzyme .	3.770573908417135

In many cases there has been report in the change in the optimum temperature also .	3.823713982733507

The change in the optimum temperature is a result of temperature gradient across the bulk and the enzyme particle and this is very prominent when you talk of gel entrapped enzyme preparation .	4.770216652068079

The gel acts almost like a thermal insulating material and therefore the temperature at this site is relatively much less as compared to the bulk temperature and therefore apparently the apparent optimum temperature will be higher than what is required .	3.1266008357668795

At the active site it is the real optimum temperature but in the bulk it is slightly higher because there is a gradient of temperature between the bulk .	4.927277126808928

Optimum temperature has also been attributed to conformational changes particularly in the case of adsorbed enzyme preparation or covalently coupled preparations where there is no likelihood of any temperature or you can even notice the temperature changes in the case of a non - porous matrix where all the enzyme is just immobilized on the surface of the matrix .	3.250850391643079

There is no porous network and in those cases if there is optimum temperature change it is attributed to conformational change and diffusional effects are also very prominent with respect to temperature effects mainly because the diffusion itself is a process which is very significantly affected by temperature .	3.0006159440907214

In fact the diffusion process is much more sensitive to temperature effects than many of the catalytic reaction rates .	4.470464184517812

The rate of diffusion can be enhanced significantly as a result of increase in temperature and particularly in the case where the system is diffusion controlled the temperature optimum might undergo significant change .	3.5967953157785764

In the case of enzymes which are immobilized by carrier binding methods , for example , either by adsorption or by covalent binding where there are no there are no likelihood of much temperatures gradient in the bulk and the enzyme active site this can be very easily checked .	3.3308475441653713

In case if you consider a non - porous matrix where all the enzyme is supposed to be on the surface there is no porous network .	4.9803858934995695

In those cases the change in the optimum temperature will be attributed to conformational effects only because there is no chance of any diffusional effects .	3.5431547550888256

There is no chance of any temperature gradient .	4.5324917395396

In different cases different kinds of changes in optimum temperature have been noticed .	3.1971339446238

Then the second parameter which is affected by the temperature is the energy of activation .	4.119084654903404

The effect of temperature on reaction rate gives you a parameter activation energy and which is considered also to be a characteristic parameter for any chemical reaction and in the case of activation energy the major reason , the contributing factor is the diffusional limitations that is the rate of diffusion because as I mentioned that the diffusion process itself is highly sensitive to temperature and the activation energy in the case of immobilized enzyme preparation is a net resultant of the two temperature dependent processes the chemical reaction and the diffusion .	3.7458885908254365

So the net effect of the temperature on the overall reaction rate which is a combined parameter between the rate of diffusion and the rate of reaction can be different than the native enzyme because there is no diffusional limitation .	4.17855196389118

There is increase in activation energy there are reports on decrease in activation energy .	3.319832497368701

But one parameter what is understood as storage stability which is attributed to the thermal deactivation of the enzyme with time is always favorable in the case of immobilized enzyme preparation mainly because of the additional intermolecular forces and the intermolecular forces that are involved which keep the process of deactivation to a minimum .	3.1351335197944534

In almost all cases of the immobilized preparation the storage stability has noted to be higher in terms of its half life .	3.951831015467531

So that is almost a proven fact and that is one advantage we have to take of immobilized enzyme for all operational purposes .	3.8625674440213604

Take an example of optimum temperature of various immobilized invertases .	4.81984218045367

As you notice here the native invertase has the optimum temperature of 55ºC and by immobilized preparation by different methods or like physical adsorption on activated carbon is 40ºC , ionic binding to DEAE cellulose is 30ºC which is a very significant change .	2.5848883478615816

As I mentioned some time earlier also that the adsorption process undergoes slight unfolding of the enzyme protein and unfolding of the enzyme protein is an endothermic process which results in reduction in the optimum temperature ; alkylation by covalent binding is 45ºC , entrapment is 50ºC .	2.9980868693680325

Here entrapment is solely as a result of insulation effect , the temperature gradient .	3.8801148196017823

In the case of gradient , but here that means there is some conformational change also occurring .	3.127166372430834

In fact optimum temperature should be higher than entrapment if it is solely by temperature gradient .	3.7314804871468783

No . I am not talking about the stability .	8.004359543885082

I am talking of the initial reaction rate as a function of temperature ; not stability .	4.0923370248159845

Look at the data on the activation energy of various immobilized aminoacylases .	4.843043444249889

I will come to operational stability a little later .	3.925055265020193

Why ? It should decrease .	9.02253155348111

Finally the most important parameter which we are concerned within the case of immobilized enzyme is their use in continuous reactors or long term reactions whether we can use them in a stirred vessel or in a packed bed or in a ……… reactors or a variety of reactor configuration that are known to us from chemical reaction engineering and we can see that the parameter which is most important to look at the immobilized enzyme preparation property is operational stability that over a period of time when we use it , it should remain stable .	3.5752736605308724

And in case of by the mechanism which you can synthesize polymer you can divide polymer into two classes by step polymerization or by chain growth polymerization .	3.568109025934172

Now , if you remember from the last lecture that in in case of chain growth polymers , the monomers are not started the polymerization reaction by itself , you need to have external agent which will initiate the polymer chain and once the chain starts , monomer can add one after one and thus completing the chain quickly .	3.359806122967092

So , you get high polymer , high molecular weight polymer at the beginning and as time goes more and more chains get initiated .	3.7976705693617796

So , it takes much longer time compared to chain reactions where the reactions happen quickly in a shorter time .	2.7875792735514477

Obviously as the reaction , reactivity of the functional groups are lower you need high reaction temperature to overcome the activation energy , which requires your your reactions to be done at very high temperature .	3.2546676853741094

Now , high temperature reaction is not only to increase the reactivities in or the equilibrium constant of the reaction , but also if you want to remove , if somebody wants to remove the bi product like say water in polyester formation or say example , a water formation water form polyester formation to take out the water you have to increase the temperature high and put a high vacuum so that you can take out the water from the system which will give you the equilibration towards product side towards right hand side which will lead to formation of polymer molecules .	3.095075661121399

And in other case of chain reaction you can do it with lower reaction temperature as well because the reactivity of these monomers are quite high .	3.8019633834668056

In case of step growth polymers you generally get a bi product formation and , but if there are example where this reaction happen without formation of bi product formation and in case of chain polymers there is no bi product formation .	3.3043003307016696

In case of step polymers the monomers as you have seen from the earlier pages that monomers disappears early from the reaction whereas , in case of chain polymers the monomers disappears steadily with time and as monomers disappears you get high molecular chains forming and typically even step growth polymers you have heteroatom in the backbone whereas , in the chain polymers typically are formed by the carbon backbone .	3.1007237727436916

Now , this classification of step and chain growth polymers also is not completely unambiguous .	3.456035757894657

Having discussed some of the characteristic features of enzymes in the light of their chemical nature , today we will discuss the functional nature of the enzymes and as most of you are familiar , catalysis is the universal property of enzymes .	3.4529081608487067

The essential characteristic of a catalyst is to accelerate the rate of reaction that it is supposed to catalyze , but in the process it is not used up in itself and in an ideal situation it must be possible to recover the catalyst at the end of the reaction .	3.2614304703384853

As a biocatalyst in the living systems two very significant characteristic properties of enzymes are noted that is the catalytic efficiency .	3.618689039097916

As you will notice , as we go further , that the enzymes provide a much more efficient catalytic system than their chemical counter part .	3.2328416810409983

There are basic intrinsic mechanisms and the confirmation of the chemical nature of enzymes is the responsible factor for providing the catalytic efficiency .	3.0719203744778554

We look into the basic factors that provide the catalytic efficiency .	3.9541434035528504

When I say catalytic efficiency , I normally mean the magnitude by which it is able to increase the rate of reaction compared to an uncatalyzed reaction or the turn over number of the enzyme that means number of moles of substrate converted to product per unit time per mole of the catalyst .	3.2412412677129985

The other feature which is very important is their specificity which is again not attributed to chemical catalyst and the enzymes provide a very specific catalytic system specific to the extent that we can recognize even the isomers they can distinguish .	3.2463153498927917

Therefore it will be interesting to note how they catalyze the reactions such that these properties are built in , in the system .	3.2526525661332237

Another feature which I think must be important to note is that an enzyme like any other chemical catalyst does not influence the thermodynamic status of the reaction .	2.6631582971498378

That means whether it is the free energy change or the equilibrium constant of the reaction , it remains unaltered during the process .	4.886248836456699

It only accelerates the reaction rate by an order of magnitude .	4.787337171684719

Now just as an example if you look at isomerization of glucose to fructose , the reaction can be catalyzed by an alkali say NaOH .	3.4056462585405587

You can get isomerization .	7.9853886847990445

You can also carry out isomerization by enzymatic route using the glucose isomerase .	2.870117609553557

In both the cases the equilibrium constant of the reaction is approximately equal to one .	5.110640424679023

So whether you carry out the reaction by alkali or by the presence of glucose isomerase , the reaction will end up under equilibrium conditions at an equimolar mixture of glucose and fructose and that remains unchanged .	3.071113587203262

The only difference , lies by the virtue of the presence of a catalyst or an enzyme in this case , will be that you can reach to the equilibrium status much faster than in the case of an uncatalyzed reaction .	3.876841775240413

Besides the equilibrium conversion or equilibrium constant of the reaction , the catalysis or the enzyme catalysis also follows all thermodynamic concepts that are applied to chemical reactions .	3.0262219873568146

Some times it may look in the case of living systems that certain reactions that are catalyzed are in totality have a positive free energy change .	3.3557754768318424

An example could be cited of conversion of carboxylation of Acetyl coenzyme A to Melonyl coenzyme A .	2.7244987475434255

The enzyme carboxylase catalyses the reaction .	4.972853096510001

The reaction has a free energy change of + 4.5 kilo calories per mole .	3.5237681119944626

The reaction must be non - spontaneous , should not take place as per the normal thermodynamic concepts .	3.4016206710647774

But we all know that this conversion does take place in the living cells .	4.479377891742106

Apparently it may look as if enzyme is doing something which is not allowed by a chemical thermodynamics but in practice it is not so because the reaction is catalyzed in association with another hydrolytic reaction which is energy yielding , which has a much higher negative free energy change and that is hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and inorganic phosphate .	3.1877714048269055

The free energy change of this is highly negative – 8.9 kilo calories per mole .	4.129010974636969

While the reaction takes place as a coupled reaction of the two systems , the net reaction is a coupled reaction where the acetyl coenzyme carboxylation is coupled to hydrolysis of ATP .	3.1008609559476796

But in practice the reaction does take place in a living cell as shown in the second half .	3.494491913450148

That is the enzyme which uses biotin as a cofactor activates the carbon dioxide at the expense of energy of hydrolysis of ATP and you get activated carbon dioxide with a negative free energy change which is a spontaneous reaction and this activated carbon dioxide then carboxylates the acetyl coenzyme A to melonyl coenzyme A , an enzyme along with the cofactor biotin is released free .	2.639597770996667

The second reaction is also a negative free energy change and therefore it is also carried out and the net reaction is the sum total of the two reactions , what we have shown here .	4.23851812611476

Therefore another feature is that the enzymes often show certain behavior which can be explained on the basis of coupling of more than one enzyme reactions where by we are able to produce certain net results which may look apparently to be non feasible but otherwise they follow all the laws of chemical reaction kinetics as well as thermodynamics .	2.922276980400644

The catalytic behavior of enzymes can be probably best illustrated by chemical reaction rate theory .	3.156745525348004

One of the most accepted theoretical interpretation of chemical catalyzes can be considered from point of view of chemical reaction rate theory which illustrates that molecules can react only if they come in contact with each other .	2.7762384474558655

That means the molecules do undergo certain collisions .	4.113712960215154

Therefore for different molecules of reactants to react collisions must take place .	3.0902343983888416

Any factor or any parameter which increases the frequency of these collisions between the molecules will tend to increase the rate of reaction .	3.3892599671295245

Of the two of the most sort after parameters , one is temperature .	4.60563430294878

We know that if we increase the temperature of a reaction system the frequency of collisions will increase and there by the rate of reaction .	4.1097368785920025

Another is if you increase the reactant concentration again there also the frequency of collisions will increase and therefore rate of reaction will also increase .	3.314903868123003

However while collisions among the molecules might lead to product formation as per this chemical reaction rate theory , it is also understood by virtue of some of the studies on the distribution of molecules which undergo reaction that not all the molecules that collide will result into the product .	2.854530812116637

Only certain molecules which have sufficient energy to undergo reaction will result into the product formation and it will be only a fraction of the total molecules that participate in the collisions process are able to yield the product .	3.6569172360185647

If you consider two molecules in a binary reaction , bimolecular reaction that is A and B and both of them are in their ground state keeping in view all their electronic , vibrational and rotational ground state but possess translational energy which makes them to move for the collisions to take place .	2.389626766558588

If they are to react when they collide the rearrangement of the electronic confirmation in each molecule must take place .	2.4950603607526025

Consider two molecules say for example A and B which are supposed to react in the presence of a catalyst or without a catalyst .	3.668331272383

If the reaction has to take place , then they must start colliding with each other .	3.417595663848641

Initially they will be at a ground state of their electronic , vibrational and rotational ground states but they will posses the translational energy which can make them move and collide .	2.776701948071926

They can only react when the rearrangement of the electronic distribution in each molecule perhaps by transfer of atoms from one molecule to the other takes place .	2.762844033598203

It is clearly pointed out by Eyring in his transition state theory that every chemical reaction proceeds via formation of the unstable intermediate between reactants and the products .	2.2107861613603768

Take the example of hydrolysis of an ester , a very common reaction even occurring in the case of enzymatic reaction .	4.00153724426811

To the ester molecule a water molecule is added .	4.176918963253421

This addition of water molecule results into an unstable transition state compound , which has partial bonds , partial negative and positive charges at the molecule .	2.5073883660357943

This is a stable molecule which has much higher free energy change than the reactants and will break down to give the corresponding acid and the alcohol .	3.3610472253396555

Eyring ’ s transition state theory states that for each reaction to occur it must pass through a transition state which is an unstable state of the molecules or unstable state some where in between the reactants and the products and which has much higher energy than possessed by the reactants of the ground state .	2.70510966227644

This energy requirement is considered as the energy of activation .	4.011882878929697

That means the free energy required for the reactants to reach the level of transition state compound is considered as the energy of activation .	3.4633003910769977

The transition state compound will ultimately break down to give you the product or in other word the energy of activation acts a barrier .	3.8666265317550845

Unless the reactant molecules cross the barrier they cannot get converted to the product .	3.626708804752718

From the energy diagram , consider the first stage which is an uncatalyzed reaction .	4.473694635496651

In the case of this reaction you see the reactants are at a ground state .	4.338018549182238

The X - axis denotes the extent of reaction the Y - axis is the energy content and then the molecules have to undergo an increase in energy till the point where a transition state is reached and then this transition state will break down , will undergo reduction in energy and lead to the products .	3.0939638900530695

These are the reactants and these are the products .	6.964789963197993

The difference between the ground state and the maximum level of energy at which the transition state is generated is called as energy of activation .	3.9501967099189277

That means the transition state will be able to break down and form the products .	5.07278810080427

Rest of the molecules which have much lower energy content will not be able to lead to product formation.On the other hand when we consider the second area where we use a catalyst the main role of a catalyst as we will also further confirm is to reduce this energy of activation by some means .	3.2061443548436053

Whether it is chemical catalysis or enzymatic catalysis the primary function or the primary route by which a catalyst functions is by reduction in this activation energy .	2.3440148101333564

You see that the energy of activation from here is reduced to this level .	3.986130367990837

The number of molecules , the fraction of total number of molecules has increased , which possess sufficient energy for the transition state molecule to break down into product , and large number of molecules can then take part in the reaction and result ultimately into the product .	4.029619837484439

In conclusion by lowering the energy of activation for the reaction , a catalyst makes it possible for substrate molecules with a smaller internal energy to react .	2.9043147524774677

Even at a smaller internal energy level the product formation can take place .	3.8922052524487074

You can see the related concentration of the shaded portion in the two cases without the catalyst and in the presence of catalyst .	4.115066080526067

That will illustrate the point .	8.003565130188278

The attraction of the enzyme for the activated complex would thus lead to a decrease in its energy and hence decrease the energy of activation for reaction and to an increase in rate of reaction .	3.306214083282355

Coming back to the role of the energy of activation on the reaction rate constant , if you take arbitrary value of energy of activation , say from 25kcal mol - 1 downwards to 5kcal mol - 1 , a decrease of activation energy results in a very significant increase in the reaction rate .	3.673212574705024

That means an increase of magnitude by 1015 fold of the rate constant .	3.999956122816563

That means if you maintain same temperature and pressure and substrate concentration increase in the reaction rate constant by a factor of 4.58 x 103 fold can be achieved for every drop of 5kcal mol - 1 which is a very , very large .	3.4769038689906

So therefore even a decrease of the energy of activation by 5kcal mol - 1 can lead to an increase of the reaction rate by a factor of 4.5 x 103 .	3.8918706064488524

In the last lecture we had discussed Michaelis Menten kinetics as applicable to enzyme catalyzed reactions and also the proposed modifications by Briggs and Haldane , whereby he confirmed the formation of enzyme substrate complex and the steady state hypothesis with respect to the formation of ES complex and that the enzyme substrate complex is in steady state soon after the reaction starts .	3.45964364478595

After a very brief induction period the concentration of enzyme substrate complex comes to a steady state .	4.254389424578675

That was initial hypothesis and based on this hypothesis we had also arrived at a rate expression vo = k2 E0 S / Km + S I am just writing here only the capital letters for the concentration terms without putting the parenthesis and km = k - 1 + k2 / k1 ; Vm = k2E0 These two parameters that is Michaelis Menten constant and the maximum reaction velocity can be used to characterize an enzyme .	2.805180335116072

I also pointed out that Vm is not a constant ; it ’ s a function of enzyme concentration and we must take a corresponding kinetic parameter as k2 which is often called as turn over number .	3.134758904243033

One of the most important features of these kinetics which I like to reiterate are the assumptions that are involved in arriving at these rate expressions and I would like you to clearly consider them while applying this kinetics to any experimental situation .	2.402429383306859

As we also mentioned right in the beginning , that any kinetic analysis will involve the match between the hypothesis , the rate expression and the experimental data .	3.0224598142460564

Therefore whenever we look at any experimental data you must ensure that under certain set of conditions the assumptions that are built in , in the Michaelis Menten kinetics are true and they are met .	3.185222905923369

Just to reiterate the assumptions , the major assumption which were made here are formation of E - S complex .	2.7550582407260333

We have assumed that the enzyme has a single substrate binding site and on this the substrate molecule binds and E - S complex is formed .	4.360965301538625

This also limits to a single substrate reaction .	5.06218426285498

The kinetics is basically developed on single substrate enzyme catalyzed reactions .	3.4865214488260343

It doesn ’ t directly interpret the multi substrate reactions which are so common in the case of biochemical systems .	3.6672670510900014

The third assumption is it talks of initial reaction rate and when I say initial reaction rate the emphasis is that the product concentration is almost zero .	3.8400816990391218

That means we are talking at the rate when there is no product formation .	4.992046877639938

So inhibition by the product or the effect of product concentration on the reaction rate has been negligible .	4.772866942763669

Fourthly we also assumed that the substrate concentration is much , much larger than enzyme concentration which is in most cases a very true assumption and the enzyme concentration being a catalyst is very , very small compared to the reactant as is also the case in most of the catalytic reactions .	3.8182028709380997

The implications of this assumption are the fact that when we monitor the reaction rates we can safely assume that S0 is approximately equal to S .	3.0922436437942946

That means substrate concentration at any given time because not much of product is formed and therefore such an assumption can be held true .	3.2631885412025907

Briggs and Haldane hypothesis was regarding the steady state with reference to E - S complex .	3.779725727191581

But this is a very loaded statement in the sense particularly a deviation from the original Michaelis Menten hypothesis which states of equilibrium of E - S .	3.6313962282914987

Here you must appreciate that when we talk of equilibrium of enzyme substrate complex with enzyme and substrate molecules it means that the break down of enzyme substrate complex into product is a very , very slow process and it does not disturb the equilibrium process of the enzyme substrate binding .	3.983483715256756

That was the original concept of Michaelis Menten .	5.920258977877194

But this was disputed by Briggs and Haldane particularly observing certain reactions which were known to be relatively fast .	2.977225281708247

Then you cannot say that the break down of E - S into product is a very slow step and a reasonable rate of break down will disturb the equilibrium .	3.1044638799709037

Therefore he mentioned that the rate of break down of E - S and rate of formation of E - S are probably the same and E - S remains under steady state .	3.704300134808615

So the rate of change of concentration of E - S is zero and the steady state assumption .	4.620731780418101

That is a very major understanding which we must appreciate .	5.567565978830802

Finally very simplistic assumption is that we always monitor or study or consider these kinetics in terms of constant pH , temperature , ionic strength and all other environmental parameters we try to keep constant .	2.8613874997228836

May be some times water activity and all those parameters are maintained constant .	3.7939401582292134

Any kinetic analysis should be made keeping in view the mechanistic hypothesis , the rate expression and the experimental data .	3.241808523687273

For understanding or for probably analyzing the experimental data for any given enzyme catalyzed reactions we can simply use Michaelis Menten hypothesis directly .	3.732682944883255

But the direct use of Michaelis Menten hypothesis or Michaelis Menten equation has a limitation because it represents a rectangular hyperbola where the maximum reaction velocity is an asymptotic situation and you can never experimentally reach that .	3.0869900202617453

So therefore this simplistic way as we were also talking yesterday was to linearize the Michaelis Menten equation and one of the simplest ways to linearize was double reciprocal plot .	2.7020693203437554

That means you take reciprocals on both the sides of the expression .	3.490487741495574

1 / v0 = 1 / vm + km / vm.1 / S Such an equation which is double reciprocal on both the sides of the Michaelis Menten equation represents a straight line and the experimental data can be easily analyzed based on 1 / s vs 1 / v profile .	3.1453678133894787

The expression will represent a straight line with a slope of km / Vm and intercept on the y - axis as 1 / vm and intercept on x axis as - 1 / km .	3.0680009926924847

This was one of the earliest analyses for the experimental data in the light of Michaelis Menten hypothesis .	4.164334071214382

It was noted to have very serious limitations and the serious limitations are that if you look at any set of data for enzyme catalyzed reaction that means data on the substrate concentration versus reaction velocity you will notice that the experimental data gave very low weightage to the measurements at low substrate concentrations .	3.3251063696245664

Most the data points will be rather concentrated near the origin where as weightage at a low substrate concentration will be very , very low .	3.547683812747355

Under weightage at the low substrate concentrations and at high substrate concentrations near the origin the data points will be heavily concentrated .	3.1498936032536187

If you consider substrate concentration in millimolar quantity and the reaction velocity in some arbitrary units , you see at 5 , 1 / S will be 0.2 , 10 - 0.1 , 15 - 0.66 , 20 - 0.05 , 30 - 0.033 , 40 - .025 and so on .	3.242567748372671

You see that when you increase the substrate concentration the weightage to 1 / S concentration is so low that ultimately you end up in a scattering , a cluster of data near the origin and therefore getting the realistic value of km and vm often tends to be difficult even after making a statistical analysis .	2.6141105564811427

Therefore a number of other linear plots were thought of and the other linear plots are Hanes plot which is nothing else but the modification of original equation .	3.1092103260029895

That means if you multiply the Lineweaver Burk equation simply by substrate concentration on both the sides you arrive at S / v0 = km / vm + S / vm This also represents a straight line and if you see a graphical representation of such a plot of substrate concentration verses S / v0 , you will again end up in a straight line position with a slope of 1 / vm and intercept of km / vm , the intercept on the X - axis as - km .	3.0541761002328163

Here you have little better situations in the sense that the data are usually not so clustered .	3.2601568774502767

They are scattered because you have substrate concentration on both the axis and therefore you get a much better fit .	4.165264030240107

Similar profile an alternative profile is Eadie Hofste plot .	3.55308672534438

Another version of the linear form of Michaelis Menten equation where you can arrive at v0 = vm - km / s.v0 If you plot such an equation and that you can obtain by multiplying the Lineweaver equation by v0.vm on both the sides and then you get a straight line with negative slope where slope is - km .	3.080859343629429

The axis here is v0 / s versus v0 .	4.630228009291748

You get a slope of - km and the intercept on the y axis is vm itself .	3.767331472402186

This also has the advantage of almost well scattered or data points that can be easily used .	3.625438043952661

Now in all the three linear plots which I have discussed that is Lineweaver plot , Eadie Hofste plot as well as the Hanes plot again there is one limitation which has been noticed .	3.3872490703522815

We have no means to look at the adequacy or the effectiveness of our analytical procedure which we have used .	3.5869022037884295

After all the accuracy of our determination or analysis of experimental data will largely depend upon the accuracy of our experimental methods and whatever data point you get we can always make a statistical fit to form a straight line and get the values .	2.7067318277076855

We don ’ t get any insight into the correctness of the data .	3.399250694551392

To take care of that another important plot was proposed in 1974 by Cornish and Bowden .	2.780918123759029

This had the characteristic feature in the sense that if you write the Michaelis Menten equation assuming the substrate concentration and the initial reaction velocity as constants and km and vm as variables although it is little unusual and unrealistic but just for the sake of a mathematical analysis if we write that , we can write for example 1 / v0 = km + S / vm.S If you just take a reciprocal vm / v0 = km + S / S vm = v0 ( 1 + km / s ) We have just written the equation in the form of vm and km as variables .	3.115122178261391

vm and km also represent a straight line with a slope of 1 / s and intercept of v0 .	3.522546342717579

It may look little unorthodox and because km and vm we know are constants .	2.904745161136226

At a constant enzyme concentration vm is also constant .	3.8220973708606945

If we consider a single data point that means at any given point of S1 , we consider v1 .	3.373357797865166

Another set of conditions S2 we consider v2 .	4.555438322534176

For each of these two data points a straight line relationship between km and vm must be valid at least from the mathematical point of view .	3.0959633906535986

So what we do is in this case therefore for each set of data point between S and v we develop a straight line .	3.2995602301851883

We just assumed the hypothetical value of km , corresponding vm is calculated in a table and we draw a straight line with reference to let us say S1V1 .	2.737928486117989

Similar exercise we do for the second data point we also develop another expression , another straight line and this gives you let us say for S2 v2 .	3.2746001063322443

So for each data point we can develop a straight line .	3.8425824929039045

In the enzyme system the reaction will have only one set of km and vm and that will be the one which is obtained by intersection of these straight line relations and that gives you a perfect check on your experimental data .	3.5411809044235807

Very often you notice that in experimental data you may not get a perfect point of intersection .	3.830111397475523

The point may let us say go something like this .	4.634401713778301

Then you are sure in one thing that your km and vm values are somewhere in this range .	3.1259875052524677

You know the range of km and vm values not the absolute value and you also know the limitations of your experimental methods that you are following .	3.2733385299747897

There is some where something flaw because theoretically if all your data points or measurements or substrate concentration or reaction velocity are perfect they must intersect at each other assuming that Michaelis Menten kinetics is valid .	2.2687289315210633

Cornish Bowden plot gives you a possibility not only to get the range of km and vm values but also makes a check on the validity or accuracy of your experimental data and which is probably one of the very basic features in the case of enzyme kinetics that your experimental data must be pretty accurate to be able to analyze the kinetics of enzyme catalyzed reaction .	3.091488628814236

Using either of these plots , personally I recommend you Cornish Bowden plot , for any analyses .	2.72935833979023

We must be able to analyze or get the kinetic features or characteristics of any enzyme catalyzed reaction broadly in terms of the value of k2 that is what we call as turn over number and vm and km value .	3.8372563723249105

There is another very interesting feature as far as the Michaelis Menten equation is concerned .	3.9295232733868914

When we mentioned our assumptions of Michaelis Menten equation , you will notice that these assumptions will largely not fit into most of the actual enzyme catalyzed reactions .	3.350060745338448

But Michaelis Menten equation is still considered to be the universal model for analyzing the enzyme catalyzed reactions .	3.687649555766065

There is some where some compromise .	5.032165359544567

If you look at each of the points where we have paradoxes in terms of the actual enzyme catalyzed reaction and those which can be done by Michaelis Menten kinetics , the first one that the Michaelis Menten kinetics deals with is the single substrate enzyme catalyzed reaction .	3.840249758481006

With the background in the biochemical metabolics you will appreciate that most of the enzyme catalyzed reactions in practice in the living cells are not single substrate reactions .	3.20888851730026

They are multisubtrate .	11.803754479469278

At least two substrate reactions and if not any other directly converting substrate water is a molecule which participates in the reaction .	2.9127046420101705

Now in such cases the applicability of Michaelis Menten equation is still valid under conditions that one of the substrate is held at a constant concentration which is in excess and one substrate which is limiting .	3.734947800835415

The Michaelis Menten kinetics should be applied to a limiting substrate and the other substrate must be in excess and therefore its concentration can be considered to be constant .	4.506288410083612

Even after it is consumed partly the concentration drop is not very large and actually if we look into most of the hydrolytic reactions the water which is almost more than fifteen molar concentration in the reaction mixture , even after participation of water in the hydrolytic reaction , the concentration doesn ’ t drop to significant level and therefore Michaelis Menten kinetics is still valid and gives you on analysis practical results .	2.7367367132365628

The significance of Michaelis Menten equation is that it assumes one substrate binding site per enzyme molecule .	3.830432281758438

When we wrote mechanistic expression for enzyme substrate binding , we are taking one substrate molecule which binds towards enzyme molecule thereby assuming that the enzyme possesses only one substrate binding site which is also not true in many cases .	3.324986269995924

Most of the enzymes , particularly the ones which have quaternary structure for their function , they will have more than one binding site on the enzyme molecule .	3.5191701056527505

But such a fallacy can be taken care in the light of Michaelis Menten kinetics .	3.447747041476643

If the binding sites even if they are more than one , if they are not interactive that means they are independent of each other and do not interfere in binding of each other , then Michaelis Menten kinetics will be valid .	4.246686089860302

The only difference will be that we must take in account multiple binding sites in terms of concentration of enzyme .	4.06812159340272

That means concentration of enzyme will reflect the concentration of active sites .	5.334415697678266

The third is we have talked about the formation of single intermediate complex .	4.9268548733451345

When we say enzyme substrate complex is formed we are talking of only one enzyme substrate complex that is formed .	4.713349881230957

We just simply consider these the irreversible process .	4.020611984112659

This is k1 , k - 1 , k2 and k3 .	6.050157531685885

Most of the enzyme catalyzed reactions involve more than one intermediate complex .	5.1958218936826865

Or in other words in place of turn over number k2 that appear in the case of Michaelis Menten kinetics you put the rate limiting rate constant in this sequence of interaction in the enzyme substrate or in the enzyme kinetics and that will still be valid .	3.6464520965216187

The next and very significant advantage of Michaelis Menten kinetics and particularly the significance of the km , Michaelis Menten constant , is very often we get an insight into the functioning of enzymes in the living cell .	3.354130883726973

Take the simplest example of glucose - 1 - phosphate .	5.189968325425872

Glucose is the starting point when we go into the metabolics and its first step is phosporylation of glucose and you get a series of products glucose - 1 - phosphate , glucose - 6 - phosphate or fructose - 1 - phosphate and so on .	2.6337315385638163

These molecules can go further either into the glycogen synthesis as a storage molecule or further to fructose biphosphate .	2.3893030309072993

The route which these molecules will follow will depend on the relative km value of the two enzymes involved .	4.3261346209801355

The km value for the fructose biphosphate forming enzyme is much , much smaller at least thousand folds smaller than the glycogen synthesizing route .	2.967248152125278

Therefore as long as the concentration of these molecules , phosporylated glucose , is not very high it will always tend to go to the fructose biphosphate route and release the energy .	3.8835876717322626

Only when the concentration of this phosporylated glucose becomes quiet high , a part of it , depending upon the ratio of the km value will go to glycogen synthesis .	3.673027668989123

That is one simple example but at many points where the substrate has more than one routes to follow in the biochemical metabolics its preference or the likely physiological route can be decided on the basis of km value and that has been possible based on the understanding of Michaelis Menten kinetics .	2.6766411329006923

One of the analytical advantage is very often we are required to estimate the activity of an enzyme sample .	3.893208498719621

There are two parameters , two constraints which have to be strictly …. .. when we talk of assay of the enzyme .	3.349719215892459

Another important feature of Michaelis Menten kinetics is to define specificity constant .	4.299392710163004

Under this first order design or under condition of S0 &lt ; &lt ; km there is another feature which we must look at .	3.3057967154203842

So these are some of the practical implications of the significance of Michaelis Menten kinetics which applies to most of the kinetic analysis .	3.7131706680842327

One of the most important features is to test the validity of steady state assumption .	3.168085808560574
