Today we shall consider various reactor configurations for carrying out enzyme catalyzed reactions You will appreciate from the previous discussion that among the various applications of enzymes and particularly the immobilized enzyme , their utilization for carrying out various chemical transformations is perhaps one of the most important sectors of industrial processing .	2.7538372656830385

This field of application is also more important from the point of view that it has an economical implication particularly because that you have some other alternatives available particularly in the form of chemical transformations with which the enzymatic transformation have to compete and therefore the system has to be optimized up to the complete plant design .	2.8807433734069092

While the major feature of the whole process will include the immobilized enzyme preparation itself but over and above you also need some kind of a hardware , an equipment in which the immobilized enzyme or for that matter even soluble enzyme can play around and catalyze the reaction .	3.014253931081552

The proper design , proper choice of configuration of these enzyme reactors is therefore very important keeping in view the whole process of economics and which plays in addition to the catalytic function of the enzyme the whole operation will be controlled economically by even the choice of the reactor .	2.8096481612466526

A number of reactor systems are available .	5.641541466881052

They can be classified in a very general way on the basis of their mode of charging and discharging of the substrate and product stream .	4.034419160219392

In laboratory experimentation , take a simple stirred vessel in which you take a beaker .	4.727058536615742

You put it on a magnetic stirrer or you can also insert a mechanical stirrer if you want and then you can add the enzyme particles into it and the substrate can be fed to it .	3.6422829748471384

You can control the pH and temperature of the reaction and you can carry out the reaction in the laboratory .	5.9224146755330445

Here the mode of charging and discharging of substrate is once .	3.6400884334815347

You initially feed the enzyme as well as the substrate and at the end of the reaction take out the final product and enzyme is mixed with it if it is soluble enzyme ; if it is an immobilized enzyme preparation , you can filter it or centrifuge it to recover back .	3.8504934681531067

So that is one of the probably simplest configurations that are possible to carry out an enzyme catalyzed reaction .	3.4593385156309964

The two factors on which the classification of enzyme reactors can be based are on the mode of charging and discharging of substrate and product stream and also physical configuration .	2.7926924304096605

What is the shape of the reactor ?	7.051320166367357

For example it is a column ; it is a stirred vessel or it could be an ultra filtration cell or what ever kind of configuration is available that also can be used and keeping in view a very broad classification can be given on the basis of batch reactors and continuous reactors and the kind of reactor system that I described a little earlier for experimental purposes fall under batch category .	3.0280735689955827

That means the batch reactors are very suitable for small scale experimental studies mainly because that they are simple in construction and operation and they don ’ t need any supporting structure unlike in the case of continuous reactors where you need to feed the substrate stream continuously so you need a pump .	2.667210238391238

Similarly at the outlet you also need a pump to withdraw the product stream whereas in the case of batch reactors you just initially charge the reactors and continue under reaction conditions ; then discharge the reactor and at the end of it do cleaning operation .	2.7332448129687963

So no supporting structures are required and therefore they are very simple and they find a very common application in the small scale experimental studies .	3.2854422106287755

In the case of soluble enzymes , the enzyme cannot be separated .	3.7980402205269956

So therefore most of the enzyme reactions that require crude enzyme preparations where no degree of purifications is needed particularly in cases for food or beverage productions , the soluble enzymes are added and they carry out reactions and they go along with the product stream and the enzyme is not required to be separated .	3.122141667561069

However if we use immobilized enzyme preparation , the separation of the enzyme is feasible by filtration or centrifugation and you can reuse it .	4.43446054082428

In fact even batch reactors are used in commercial preparations extensively mainly because of their simplicity and ease of fabrication and operational convenience for many reactions .	2.8170091285337886

One typical example is the hydrolysis of penicillin to 6 - amino penicillinic acid , 6 - APA , which is an intermediate for ampicillin .	3.3615709164436245

This is usually done in a repeated batch reactor using immobilized enzyme and the immobilized enzyme is retained in the reactor either by providing a mask for filtering the enzyme to be retained in the reactor or it can be strained after the product stream has been recovered .	3.218516536316978

Batch reactors also have an important feature for use with the soluble enzymes where most of the continuous enzyme systems are not very suitable .	3.6169903124675717

There are options where even soluble enzymes can be used in a continuous reactor but for practically most applications the use of soluble enzyme is usually with the batch reactors .	3.2684111026824034

The third feature in favor of the batch reactor is the use of insoluble substrates .	3.7490011271958665

While in the case of continuous reactors the use of insoluble substrate particularly using immobilized enzyme preparations is not feasible particularly in terms of reactions being carried out by solid contact which is difficult , for most of the enzyme catalyzed reactions which involve insoluble substrates the batch reaction systems are very ideally suited .	3.0998752890063783

To illustrate with example the insoluble substrates are like hydrolysis of cellulose .	3.6071013412821946

Cellulosic materials are insoluble and the enzyme has to be reacted with this insoluble substrate to hydrolyze into glucose .	4.110996408991961

Very often for small scale operations you can have this stirred tank with jacket for temperature control .	3.2125365335980876

On the large scale you can also have coils inserted into the reactor whereby temperature control can be monitored and another advantage is even you can have devices for addition of acids or alkali if pH control is the requirement of the reaction .	2.768628777078013

In the example I cited a little ago on the hydrolysis of penicillin to 6 - APA because of simultaneous acid production you need to control the pH otherwise the enzyme gets inactivated and a very precise control of pH is needed and therefore addition of the alkali simultaneously is a must and which can be carried out very easily in a stirred batch reactor and with a control system you can control the pH .	2.6563234842436896

The extent of reaction can also be monitored by the quantity of alkali consumed because stoichiometrically the quantity of acid produced is same as the extent of conversion of penicillin to 6 - APA .	3.510174326064977

The other modified form is a packed bed reactor particularly when we are talking of immobilized enzymes and the enzyme now in the form of either spherical particles , globules , chips , membranes then can be packed into a column and make a packed bed and the reactor can be operated in a batch mode in the total recycle .	3.3023980265365727

In the second case of recycle reactor , if the product outlet is closed and the total enzyme is then recycled back into the feed , the whole operation can be carried out over a period of time which is a batch reaction time .	2.927493066010041

The only constrain or the assumption here to be considered from the quantitative point of view as the batch reactor or as a perfect mixed batch reactor will be that the cycle time of the substrate must be very , very small compared to the total batch time .	3.3549143112710054

For a perfect total recycled reactor to be considered as a batch reactor operation the requirement should be that the total recycled time must be very small or negligible compared to the total batch cycle ; that is the recycling has to be very fast .	3.283145522711401

In the case of batch reaction at any given time all the enzyme must be in contact with the total substrate feed .	3.772989603013686

So to achieve that the recycle time must be very small or the recycling has to be very fast and therefore these two kinds of reactor systems are very commonly used as batch reactor .	3.2349302713955574

The second category and probably which is of most significance to us as in the case of immobilized enzyme systems are continuous flow reactors because the major purpose of the immobilizing enzymes is to use them in continuous modes or repeated mode .	2.523876400219975

You can use the batch reactors also in case of repeated mode .	5.437373497494474

But more conveniently they can be used in the form of the immobilized enzymes in continuous reactors .	5.458619631494946

Three major classes of continuous reactors are listed here .	4.451627806255079

You have continuous stirred tank reactor and the classical feature of a continuous stirred tank reactor is it is a type of a stirred reactor in which you give a continuous supply of substrates in the form of feed and the same volume at the same rate the product stream is taken out while retaining the immobilized enzyme preparation in the reactor stream .	3.60701560462616

The major characteristic feature of the continuous stirred tank reactor often denoted as CSTR is that the contents of the reactor are perfectly mixed or the system is totally homogeneous .	3.2663081182393543

That means the concentration of any particular species in the reaction system is uniform through out the content of the reactor and this concentration is same as that in the outlet stream .	4.311640739739632

These characteristics makes a very unique situation and whenever contents in the reactor are at the same composition as in the product stream it implies that the concentration of the substrates in the reactor is at a level which is present in the outlet stream .	4.040015768813509

For example if you want to carry out a conversion of let us say a 95 % leaving back 5 % of the substrate that means the concentration of the substrate in the reactor will be only 5 % of that of the feed inlet .	4.524446825291986

So the effective concentration of the substrate at which the reaction is taking place is much smaller than the substrate inlet stream concentration and therefore such reactions will be ideally suited for the enzyme catalyzed reactions which are strongly substrate inhibited because the effective substrate concentration in the reactor will be much lesser than the actual substrate concentration in the feed stream .	3.7040258819691765

So the inhibitory effect will be totally masked .	4.575257328405485

On the other hand if the reaction is inhibited by the product then such reactors are not very suitable because the content in the reactor will also have a very high product concentration at any given time .	3.6298505589101318

So therefore the reaction will always continue in a product inhibited design .	4.322794195336582

So the reaction rate can be very slow .	7.175111691033405

So therefore the reactors in the form of continuous stirred tank reactors are ideally suited for substrate inhibited reactions rather than product inhibited reactions .	3.0179136583181942

So that is one feature .	6.548770840622391

The second category is plug flow reactors .	4.801374201683548

Plug flow reactors or in a much boarder sense you can say packed bed reactors are probably one of the most commonly used types of reactors in the immobilized enzyme applications mainly because of the nature of the catalyst .	4.065455001805154

Because it is used in the form of either particles or films it can be easily packed in the system and can provide a very high catalyst density , enzyme density in the reactor system .	3.8406444548807452

Higher the catalyst density the over all reaction rate can also be very high because the enzyme concentration per unit volume will be much higher compared to a CSTR .	4.328317214560084

But the basic characteristics of plug flow reactor is that the substrate inlet stream moves do they flat concentration profile or velocity profile along the length of a reactor ?	3.2712900741214885

Consider an enzyme reactor .	9.843845035304783

This is an enzyme reactor , a plug flow reactor and then consider the central axis , the velocity profile of the feed .	3.3908988876109

This is s ; this is the product stream .	9.29404482377677

The concentration profile of the feed at any given cross section of the reactor is flat .	4.4613220468427945

That means there are no actual dispersions and so the velocity profile of the feed stream throughout the length of the reactor is flat or in other words the feed inlet , the feed stream moves almost like a plug and therefore the name what we talk about as a plug flow reactor .	3.1359565683093034

But in the case of large reactors there are lot of deviations from the plug flow behavior which we will consider .	3.6949876102415

They can be accounted in while we consider the reactor performance .	3.991785518835991

The third category of the continuous reactors are fluidized bed reactors .	3.6593542732505866

They are somewhere between the continuous stirred tank reactors and the plug flow reactors and if you put the substrate feed at a speed high enough to lift the bed or fluidize the bed but not allow the catalyst particle to go out of the reactor , unlike in the case of a packed bed there is a static bed of the immobilized enzyme particles and the linear velocity of the feed is not large enough so that the bed can be disturbed .	3.110549382123949

This will be a function of the particle shape and size .	6.737996003785345

Particle shape and size will control the voidage in the packed bed but when you move ahead from the plug flow behavior and continue to increase feed velocity stream to a level that the bed is packed , bed is disturbed .	2.5443872103963883

It gets fluidized ; the particles are fluidized in the reactor system almost like as shown here in the reactor but not to the extent that the catalyst particles are driven out of the reactor system .	3.5523373892532155

We call it fluidized bed ; fluidized bed immobilization reactor .	3.4229795275190473

Such reactors in terms of fluid dynamics probably provide a performance somewhere in between the CSTR and PFR but are ideally suited for the reactions which have a requirement of good heat and mass transfer because in many of the situations like in packed bed the heat and mass transfer may be very difficult and particularly in case of reactions which are exothermic in nature there might be lot of local heat hot spots which can inactivate the enzyme .	2.7818962527800557

Fortunately in the case of enzyme catalyzed reactions , the reactions are not highly exothermic .	5.493425238983958

They are usually isothermal and therefore the problem of heat transfer is not so severe .	3.9249300389616963

But even a smaller level of heat generated can be taken care very easily in case of fluidized bed reactors .	3.801016773662782

Alternatively if your substrate is highly viscous or let us say colloidal in nature , in those cases also a fluidized bed reactor can provide you a much better system for carrying out immobilized enzyme reactions in a continuous mode .	3.1046611598448517

In fact fluidized bed reactor itself is a hybrid between the two major classes .	4.323387153739855

But even under CSTR a modification which has been proposed is in the form of CSTR coupled with the ultra filtration cell .	3.6675029105199233

Particularly in case where you want to carry out reactions using insoluble substrates or soluble enzymes and want to use a continuous reactor .	3.679893658073856

For a soluble enzyme you cannot use a plug flow reactor .	4.696315759365454

So CSTR coupled with an ultra filtration reactor can be easily used for carrying out a reaction with the soluble enzyme or with insoluble substrates .	3.936781002594535

In the case of soluble enzyme the use of plug flow reactor will drive away the enzyme simultaneously and you cannot use it continuously .	3.2540183648031236

In the case of a CSTR , you can use a soluble enzyme or along with a soluble or insoluble substrate by carrying out in a CSTR and coupling the CSTR with the ultra filtration module .	3.3119790643998583

That is the reactor output instead of going directly to the product stream passes through ultra filtration unit in which the product stream is filtered out and can be taken out of the product stream while the retentate which contains mainly the enzyme is recycled back into the reactor .	3.4029364950174243

In this case here we do the same thing ; a part of the output stream which is the filtrate from the ultra filtration unit is taken out to the product stream and the retentate of the ultra filtration unit is cycled back into the reactor and it can be operated in a continuous shift .	3.746909983102247

So overall performance wise in terms of the reactor performance it can be considered almost similar to that of a CSTR .	5.738040623510301

There are two major modifications which has been proposed in the case of plug flow reactors .	4.438680723503386

While the conventional systems as we have seen use the packed bed and feed the substrate in either at the top of the column or at the bottom of the column either of the combination is feasible but they may also have some operational problems .	3.2519487461789383

Of the two major modifications of that which have been proposed and have been used in the enzyme catalyzed reaction , one is a hollow fiber reactor .	3.9839706569545874

In the case of hollow fiber the system is something like in a shell and tube reactor ; shell and tube heat exchanger type of situation where you have very fine capillary type of fibers which are semi permeable in which the enzyme can be entrapped .	2.682726910170509

The enzyme feed is put in , in the hollow fibers and the main feed substrate is passed through the cell side and because of the semi permeability of the hollow fiber membranes the substrate and the enzyme can come in contact .	3.255012605513696

That means the substrate can go into the vicinity of the enzyme and product can go out and ultimately the product stream can be taken out but the enzyme cannot go out of the ultra filtration tubes and such a reaction system has an advantage that you can use such a system as a continuous plug flow reactors even using the soluble enzymes .	3.719414878114574

While a packed bed system cannot be used in the soluble enzyme but a hollow fiber reactor can be used in soluble enzyme and particularly where contacting an enzyme and the substrate is a problem such reactors have been used and in terms of flow behavior , because of these hollow fibers being of the capillary size , very fine capillaries and a bundle is made so they almost provide a reactor performance in line with the plug flow barrier No .	2.9064083893333788

In the hollow fiber tubes , capillary tubes is the enzymes contained and in space provided between the tubes and the cell the substrate feed is fed into it .	2.375683597777456

You are referring to this one .	5.317589711191562

This is only a cross section of the system .	4.104513227434397

In fact all the tubes at the top are joined in a section so that they come out in the same section .	3.3222224517536243

This is only a cross section shown here in the expanded form .	3.6711308942183223

The circles which you are seeing here they are blown up here in this form and they indicate one hollow fiber .	3.121051197756564

The whole reactor consists of a bundle of hollow fibers almost about eighty or hundred hollow fibers can be constituted in about one square inch of that order hollow fiber .	1.9697827365956022

But there are systems reported in which they are on the tube walls .	3.5991087713802137

The enzyme can be immobilized but alternatively in the general fashion it can also be in the form of soluble enzyme .	4.217412381468429

When you say when you are immobilizing on the walls of the tube then they don ’ t operate really on the hollow fiber reactor .	2.7766819800212037

Then it is almost like a packed bed reactor in which the tube side is used as the matrix and it is almost like a packed bed reactor .	4.381481263120464

It doesn ’ t matter whether you pack it in a horizontal fashion or a vertical fashion the tubes are used as the immobilized matrix whereas I am talking about that the enzyme which is used in the soluble mode .	3.336601563747346

It is retained in the semi permeable hollow fiber tubes so that it is not able to go out almost similar to microencapsulation where the enzyme is contained in the forms of tubes .	3.277004938608579

The other noble modification of the plug flow system is a spiral membrane bound module .	3.5771274591787563

It is a very specific configuration which has been reported and has been used industrially and this system has been used extensively for immobilized enzyme preparations which are in the form of thin films .	3.8295911230979813

The typical application which reversed is where the enzyme is immobilized on the collagen matrix in the form of thin films and you get a very long roll .	3.6557417106261707

It can even also be used along with , like your fiber entrapped enzymes , if the fibers are woven in the form of a cloth or thing like that so that you get a very large surface area in the form of a film , long film .	2.893864515136071

What is done is that this thin film of the enzyme containing enzyme is bound spirally on to central core .	3.578516351352203

You take a central core on which spirally the enzyme sheet is wrapped around the core and in between to provide strength there is a matrix or there is a kind of a porous sheet which can keep the two enzyme sheets separated .	2.8747044214497164

It serves two purposes ; one is that it provides strength to the enzyme sheet .	4.547010650702459

The other is it also doesn ’ t allow the enzymes system to get clogged and that can be packed into a column into a tube and such a system also can provide a very high enzyme loading because the surface area available on the thin film is very , very large and therefore it can provide a very high enzyme loading and also the system performs almost like a plug flow reactor .	2.7296806927450326

Only thing is instead of packing the column with the particulate material what you are doing is the film is being wrapped along a core spaced by another sheet and then the whole core is inserted into a column .	2.588583452330614

So you can feed the substrate either from the top or the bottom and take out another stream .	2.907231125282088

It is almost like a plug flow reactor .	4.858437823593159

I must say that this is not the comprehensive list of the type of the reactors that has been reported .	4.518527306091917

Very large variations of reactor designs have been reported .	4.170922969384307

Even for example in the case of a CSTR people have immobilized the enzyme on to the base of the …… and carryout the reaction .	3.5320222519711133

So a variety of configurations had been used but some of them are purely of catalytic interest also .	3.514708645886958

But by and large from the fluid dynamics and reactor performance point of view they have to be classified on one of those standard operational modes .	3.0538967205694267

To sum up the type of reactors that are available the combined continuous stirred flow reactors with the ultra filtration system is useful with the soluble enzyme or along with the immobilized enzyme particularly by an insoluble substrates are required to be handled or colloidal substrates are required to be handled .	3.0087920897495772

Because in the handling of colloidal substrates , you often find difficulty with the flux flow reactors .	2.441798016173188

So the combined CSTR coupled with the ultra filtration reactor can be easily used .	3.966021793717332

Such reactors had been very poor in terms of long term operations mainly because of the adsorption of the enzyme on to the membrane surface .	4.089135103497856

So most of the membranes provide a good adsorption surface and the enzymes get adsorbed on to that and the reactor performance is … .	3.7981838811316675

All the defects or all the limitations of an ultra filtration system will also be associated here .	3.506182024507477

The reaction system will have to face all the problems like concentration polarization of an ultra filtration system and unless those are taken care the reaction performance will be adversely affected .	2.5850592125042784

One is that the system undergoes a very fast rate of deactivation mainly because you have to transfer the whole material along with the substrate into the ultrafiltration module and recycle back the retentate and so during that transfer there is a significant loss occurring .	3.214687943317269

In most of these one of the reasons of activation is also … .	5.2590150772266435

inactivation and in case of even CSTR many of the enzymes or the carrier particles that are … .	5.60264376942593

sensitive or carriers which can go undergo lot of attrition during use the CSTR becomes a sort of a disadvantageous system because if the carrier particles get disintegrated during use it will involve the loss of enzyme .	2.5415781207456263

In the case of CSTR , the most favorable point is that for reactions which are substrate inhibited , CSTR is a desirable feature .	3.0684562294519573

In the case of a plug flow reactor you have a recycle system so that have an external loop in which the pH monitoring and control is exercised or otherwise in the ideal plug flow behavior the pH control is difficult .	2.9223166889503487

But the CSTR provides an ideal tool and in many cases of immobilized enzyme reactions pH control is a requisite .	3.4842977699609414

Then in the case of CSTR even colloidal or insoluble substrates can be processed which is not feasible in the case of plug flow behavior and then easy replacement of catalyst .	3.561555052880676

We have talked about higher yields for reaction undergoing substrate inhibition .	3.319313573444573

Then in the case of plug flow reactors often it has been noted that the conversion efficiencies are much higher compared to CSTR and the major reason for that are two .	3.294247460666946

We will see the quantitative analysis of the reactor performance in both the cases .	5.2513390019201704

But one of the major reason is that most of the enzyme reactions are inhibited if not very excessively but mildly by product concentration .	3.622085004092603

So the plug flow maximizes or minimizes the product concentration at any given point .	3.786916954349814

The maximum product concentration is only at the outlet stream but across the reactor length the product concentration is much lesser than the outlet stream as the opposite happens in the case of a CSTR .	3.4455976373586332

So the reactor performance is much better usually in the case of PFR .	5.532578079468585

The second reason is that the enzyme loading per unit volume is much higher in the PFR compared to the CSTR .	5.468502998093309

In the CSTR , the concentration of the enzyme which you can …. .. usually is not very high when compared to the PFR .	5.677586224344791

The other category of enzyme reactor , fluidized bed reactor , as I mentioned earlier are much better suited for heat and mass transfer characteristics and freedom from plugging .	2.8143535541753146

Very often if colloidal substrates are to be used a plug flow reactors faces problem in terms of plugging or choking of the column .	3.737750475218967

Insoluble substrates can be used .	9.865296616222658

One of the disadvantage is the power requirement for fluidizing the beds because you need to feed the substrate at the very high linear velocities which requires a much higher power consumption and the scale up of the fluidized bed reactors has also been very largely empirical .	2.558916453619825

The scale up systems is more empirical compared to CSTR and PFR which are considered to be idealized reactor systems because in terms of fluid flow behavior they represent the two extremes .	2.8104814358456314

In one there is no actual dispersion ; in the other case there is complete back mixing .	4.584261420631671

So therefore their modeling or their arriving of electrode performance is much certain , much more defined and therefore the scale up can be easily carried out whereas in the case of fluidized bed reactor a scale up is more empirical .	2.757695969152844

There will not be much pressure drop because just like in the case of a packed bed reactor the particles are all compact .	3.6407990649052007

So when you feed a substrate the pressure drop will be very large if the particle size is very fine .	3.760147497901858

In the case of a fluidized bed reactor the voidage is very high .	3.6737680606157945

The voidage is almost approximating to that of CSTR ; not the same but it is approaching to that and therefore there is no pressure drop and the system has a very large voidage ; the voidage increases .	3.5126066114058214

Before we go into the reactor performance of different types of reactor for the immobilized enzyme systems , we cannot normally consider all the parameters like non - ideal fluid dynamics , the mass transfer constraints and along with the biochemical reaction we cannot really combine at one stage .	3.2670097432876735

We can take up those issues one by one and to begin with we can only consider an idealized enzyme reactor system .	2.939796034920501

We would like to make certain assumptions before we go into the reactor performance and the assumptions are that first thing we are assuming that the reactor undergoes an isothermal operation .	3.328006110383481

That means ?	22.89119573583991

H value of the reaction is not very high so that there is no temperature gradient in the reaction ; the first assumption .	7.1517971264578994

Second is uniform enzyme distribution .	7.087894455470074

In practice there are reports that even in an immobilized enzyme preparation itself there are no uniform enzyme distribution practically .	3.5283855176826027

But for theoretical purposes , we assume that the enzyme is distributed uniformly in the reactor whether it is a plug flow reactor or is a batch reactor or a CSTR .	4.316702878693634

The third condition is we are assuming either a plug flow behavior for packed bed or a completely back mix behavior for CSTR in terms of fluid dynamics .	3.2941222461128534

We are not considering anywhere that means even fluidized bed is not considered as an idealized reactor system .	2.741754984637045

So we are considering the two extreme conditions either a plug flow behavior or a completely back mix system .	3.618759119876098

Then we are also ignoring external film or internal pore diffusion limitations if any .	3.281261612425789

We are considering that there are no diffusional limitations .	6.034750140599439

That means the rate of reaction is much slower than the rate of diffusion .	5.3474175188891735

The rate of diffusion is fast enough .	6.2199365087014264

Then the last assumption is that there is no significant partitioning of substrate between bulk and the carrier phase .	3.39844046155615

If the system follows such we can evaluate or conduct a reactor performance on the basis of biochemical reaction , their reaction kinetics and to do so the major reactor design parameters which have to be considered are listed here .	2.7293098798511073

The first one is “tau ” which is the reactor space time in terms of V / Q .	5.585718328605601

Here V is the reactor volume and Q is the flow rate in the case of a continuous reactor .	4.723039647320653

“tau ” in the case of the batch reactor is the batch reaction time .	4.730163426321615

Then you have initial substrate concentration ; another parameter which we have to define in any problem of a immobilized enzyme or soluble enzyme reactor we first define the S0 , the batch time or the reactor space time in continuous reactors .	2.9427421600089567

Then the total enzyme concentration in the system .	7.014045573990832

When I say E0 , I think it will be desirable to also have the magnitude of kd , the deactivation constant .	3.802627002947035

Particularly it will be more important when we are talking of continuous operation where the reactor operation time is large enough the deactivation constant will also play a key role .	3.603063847372748

Then the temperature of operation because deactivation also will depend on the operational temperature .	4.115233355390778

I would like to mention here that most continuous enzyme reactors are usually operated little below their optimum temperatures just to increase or reduce the kd values and increase the operational half life .	2.3942158598073466

Then pH ; pH here is not only monitoring but more important is the control of pH .	3.371026184862711

How are you exercising control of pH ?	4.712624606528799

Then fraction of conversion in the reactor which can be defined as ( S0 - S ) / S0 .	7.400205232441401

That means the concentration difference ; substrate concentration between the inlet and the outlet stream , the ratio of the two .	3.436245958183833

Then the reactor productivity is another parameter which is important .	5.065427399086057

X.S0 / tau .	24.223511781564266

If we consider S0 as the concentration term so that it becomes per unit volume also .	4.535778114720235

Then the reactor capacity ; although under given set of conditions you may get certain kind of productivity for a reactor capacity will be given by the Vm .	2.7349110532751286

k2.E0.V.e * .	8.765536755133343

Here even in case of tau also we can multiply by voidage if you want to consider a broader picture of a packed bed reactor because this V , reactor volume is not the packed bed volume it is the volume of the fluid in the reactor .	3.4801307155448558

So the total bed multiplied by the voidage will give a fluid volume in the reactor .	3.6401706685539876

In the case of CSTR voidage can be considered almost equal to one whether the volume occupied by the carrier is very , very small compared to the total reactor volume .	3.496449731220995

Then reaction capacity can be given by k2.E0 which is Vm multiplied by the reactor volume and the voidage and then finally the important parameter is enzyme kinetics itself because the reactor performance will depend upon the reaction kinetics which controls the reaction .	3.402183635875455

Mind that we are not considering under idealized reactor conditions .	5.426625273979436

Anything like diffusional limitations , partitioning effects and non - ideal fluid flow behaviour which we will consider subsequently one by one to arrive at the final reactor performance .	3.2563980548936295

Pr is reactor productivity and Cr is the reactor capacity .	4.30119636168306

Today we will discuss two of those cases that do not represent the reaction velocity profile in terms of hyperbolic kinetics .	4.15153313846561

One of them is substrate inhibition the other is sigmoidal kinetics particularly as it applies to multisite and allosteric enzymes .	2.82297591977464

If you look into the reaction profile , a typical substrate verses initial reaction velocity profile , for a hyperbolic kinetics goes like this with an asymptotic reaction velocity Vm .	2.666575181948523

In the case of substrate inhibition the reaction velocity when you increase substrate concentration does not reach to a saturation level rather even earlier than that it deviates and passes through a maximum .	2.641876033123963

When substrate concentration goes high the reaction velocity starts dropping and does not retain saturation level .	3.6993895143086135

On the other hand in the sigmoidal kinetics instead of a reaction profile being represented by rectangular hyperbola it is in the form of a sigma .	2.8848632004222847

Ultimately it can reach the same kind of saturation behavior but the initial profile will be different in the case of a sigmoidal profile .	3.5280630186417214

Coming to the first case of substrate inhibition , the reaction profile passes through a maximum and at a particular substrate concentration it reaches a maximum value and then it starts dropping .	3.5771530730795433

This substrate concentration corresponds to maximum reaction velocity .	4.421680414261013

This substrate concentration corresponding to maximum reaction velocity is not really something which is corresponding to maximum reaction velocity of enzyme catalyzed reaction .	3.454590045596417

It is as a result of certain enzyme substrate interactions such that the rate gets tapered even before the saturation level reaches .	3.372616869915632

This effect can also be visualized when you look for the classical Lineweaver plot .	4.059270631602314

Instead of giving you a straight line it becomes convexed to the x axis and it can meet .	3.681043591190198

That can give an indication that the enzyme catalyzed reaction is having some kind of a substrate .	4.556629177517101

There are number of examples in practice for such kind of a behavior in the reaction .	4.07087554162737

One of the most conventional and simplest examples could be hydrolysis of sucrose to glucose and fructose by invertase .	2.699792636145532

A very classical example , where at a substrate concentration of greater than 0.1M , 0.1M is not a very high substrate concentration , is about say 3.4 or 3.5 % .	3.9424675592598843

Even at that level the effect of substrate concentration inhibition is noticed and the reaction velocity starts dropping .	4.202842822338206

Another example of substrate inhibition is in the form of succinic dehydrogenase which catalyzes the interconversion of succinate to fumerate , a reaction which catalyzes the formation of a double bond .	3.139506327730077

Succinate as a substrate has two carboxylic groups .	5.639891756741072

As per the normal function of the enzyme the two carboxylic groups of the substrate are required to be bound to the enzyme molecule .	4.859103007045879

When substrate concentration becomes very high , the possibility or the statistical feasibility of one carboxylic group from each of the two substrate molecule binding to the same enzyme molecule becomes much higher .	3.650635878902421

In that process when the two substrate molecules gets bound to one enzyme molecule and one carboxylic group of each of the substrate molecule then the reaction is not catalyzed and then ultimate enzyme substrate complex is a dead end complex .	3.4649201863036945

The structure of succinic acid is - OOC - CH2 - CH2 - COO - .	3.465989436119168

As per the normal reaction of succinic dehydrogenase two carboxylic group of substrate molecule are required to be bound to the enzyme active sites and at low concentration of substrate this can very well happen .	3.2317604278401038

So therefore the active sites are not functional yet because instead of one molecule there are two molecules attached and the enzyme substrate complex so results in the form of dead end complex which doesn ’ t go into the final product forming stage .	3.385414857572287

For such a reaction there is a feasibility that you may end up in an enzyme molecule having such kind of a confirmation , instead of having the two carboxylic group of the same substrate molecule bound to the enzyme , there are two substrate molecules bound to the same enzyme and one carboxylic group of each of the substrate molecule and such a complex does not form the product .	3.7932779613257575

Similarly in the case of hydrolysis of sucrose by invertase also by one of the possible mechanistic models when one substrate molecule binds , the enzyme substrate complex leads to a product formation .	3.6456268845321946

If the enzyme is bound to two substrate molecule a dead end complex is formed .	4.277085597902305

A simple reaction mechanism can be expressed like E + S ES E + P + S ESS We can write exactly in our nomenclature of k1 , k - 1 , k2 and this equilibrium of the second substrate binding can be expressed by dissociation constant of Ks , individual rate constant being ks and k - s .	2.9424914752104323

This ESS is a dead end complex .	4.756901081640651

That means the product formation will take place from the substrate complex .	4.794239627796992

This will not lead to any product formation and whatever fraction of the total enzyme is bound in the form of ESS will not participate in the reaction with the result that reaction velocity will drop .	3.714644702955455

That means at the saturation level you are assuming that the entire enzyme is bound to the substrate .	3.9457346064250864

The entire enzyme is not bound to the substrate here .	6.501761895745902

On the basis of equilibrium kinetics one can write the rate expression of such a system as Vi / Vm = S Km + S ( 1 + S / Ks ) The Vm is the true maximum reaction velocity if there was no such substrate inhibition to take place and Km is , the classical ( k - 1 + k2 / k1 ) , the Michaelis Menten constant and ks is the dissociation constant of the second substrate binding .	3.254911841759307

This can also be written as Vi = Vm S / Km + S + S2 / Ks If you plot such profile the rate expression will pass through maxima and if you differentiate that dv over ds and equate it to zero you will end up in maxima and the maximum reaction velocity will be obtained at substrate concentration which is Sm = vKm .	3.0047931025168904

In such cases you notice that such enzymes do not really strictly follow the typical Michaelis Menten kinetics .	2.743157238088433

There are another group of enzymes which are multisite .	5.02258009782529

Notice the two terms which I have highlighted here .	5.124131612571014

That means free energy of binding on either site is same and it does not matter to which site the substrate molecule binds first or second ; it makes no different .	3.0999556635959875

Very often it might happen that initially the binding sites may be identical and they are free , free for the substrate to bind to any one of them .	3.8920766946370247

But when we talk of allosteric enzyme we are talking of a favorable interaction .	4.277686638909332

Multisite enzymes have identical , independent subunits .	5.260060534875846

In such cases when all the catalytic sites on the enzyme molecule , even look at its different subunits , if they are identical and non - interacting or non - cooperative , they have no interaction among each other .	2.7501708212123126

The net result will be that you are handling something like if you consider that let us say one nano mole of an enzyme substrate concentration of n binding sites per mole will be equal to n pico mole of one binding site molecule .	3.4899812992109593

The rate profile will be hyperbolic in nature .	4.048267575502654

That means all the binding sites are equal .	5.418418311076799

They don ’ t influence the binding to other site .	3.798243506355129

In the second and more complex case when we talk of co - operative binding if you consider two binding sites on enzyme molecule they may be identical .	3.8220486252182995

That means the free energy change for binding process may be the same .	3.8945611790616184

That is what we mean by identical binding sites .	4.738559546829642

There are number of mechanistic hypothesis which have been proved .	4.709721922222513

The first binding site is free for all the substrate molecule and once this is bound if it makes a change on the confirmation of the other binding sites such that the affinity of the substrate to the binding site gets altered , if you want a positive favorable effect , the affinity must increase or the Km value must decrease , dissociation constant must decrease .	3.04718534773618

If the km value of the subsequent binding sites decreases with the binding of the first substrate molecule we call it co - operative binding .	4.213632201519738

The significance of co - operative binding lies in actual practice in the case of allosteric enzymes .	3.5834934594030337

All of you know probably with your background in the biochemical metabolism that with each metabolic path way you have certain regulatory enzymes which behave in allosteric manner .	2.500912744572486

By allosteric manner I mean that substrate binding process in case of those enzymes is co - operative in nature and they do not exhibit the typical hyperbolic kinetics rather they exhibit sigmoidal kinetics .	2.9484924097625176

If you just compare the two kinds of profiles , this is a sigmoidal profile and this is the hyperbolic profile .	4.811527377174523

For two different enzymes which are coincidentally having the same velocity at substrate concentration let us say nine arbitrary units in both the cases whether it follows a hyperbolic kinetics or sigmoidal kinetics the enzyme velocity reaches the same value at a particular substrate concentration .	2.7245426460280138

Only initial phase changes and the first one is typical hyperbolic profile , the second one is the sigmoidal profile which is exhibited by allosteric enzymes .	3.0461773077147396

The allosteric behavior has in some way an advantageous situation for the regulatory enzymes to function .	2.7441666239033498

The role of regulatory enzymes in a metabolic pathway is the control of metabolic pathway .	3.1881898899559675

That means it should be able to switch on and off the path way with a very subtle change in substrate concentration .	3.4827877189313825

These two profiles have identical reaction velocity at high substrate concentration .	3.551606051257648

For the two enzymes to act , in the early phases when substrate concentration increases from zero to three arbitrary units whatever are the units , in the case of sigmoidal kinetics the reaction velocity is only 0.1 in some arbitrary units .	2.9288718116473738

Whereas in the case of a saturation kinetics or hyperbolic kinetics the reaction velocity can reach to almost 0.75 , 75 % of the saturation value , a very high level .	3.430585311027643

That means at a very small change of concentration , the reaction velocity can be very high .	4.830952101954081

In the case of saturation kinetics or hyperbolic kinetics the ratio of the concentration of substrates for the two levels to reach will be almost about twenty seven times .	3.116289721321609

That means at 0.1 , it can reach only at a very small substrate concentration here .	3.903499792370275

The ratio is twenty seven fold .	5.040033292150289

On the other hand in the case of sigmoidal kinetics this ratio is only 2.3 .	3.229322905723854

In the case of living cells the intercellular concentration of substrate does not change over a very large range .	4.105678238692745

Whereas for control purposes it will require a very small concentration change by which the reaction velocity can be regulated and that is what can happen in the case of a sigmoidal kinetics .	4.059155230883692

That means just by changing concentration ratio of two to three fold you will notice that the reaction velocity can be altered from 0.1 to 0.75 and that is the advantage with this kind of reaction behavior the regulatory enzymes obtained in the case of cellular metabolism With this kind of a kinetic behavior the enzymes are able to act almost like an on and off switch .	3.2298193902590415

That means if the substrate concentration comes down reaction velocity is very slow ; the metabolic pathway is slowed down ; it is not made to zero .	3.8038207934558512

If the substrate concentration slightly increases the pathway is fully on and the product formation or whatever is corresponding intermediate in pathway are fully available and that advantage provides to the cellular metabolism .	2.5583777102718837

Such a behavior of sigmoidal kinetics has been very appropriately explained at least by two mechanistic hypotheses .	2.804764867486292

One and probably in its simplest form is on the basis of sequential interaction model .	3.382760138008748

This is an extension of Koshland ’ s induced fit hypothesis which we discussed when we were talking about the specificity and how the enzymes obtain their specific action .	2.939714558967503

We talked about the Koshland ’ s induced fit hypothesis whereby when the substrate molecule binds to one of the binding sites the enzyme undergo a conformational change so as to fit on to the substrate molecule .	3.7310842043398535

For each binding of the substrate to a binding site the affinity reduces by a factor let us say a , as interaction factor .	3.7116916748453717

That is what you see in a diagrammatic picture like here .	3.9458949996713053

If this is the free enzyme which has two binding sites , identical binding sites the substrate molecule binds first to let us say , A .	4.635957647892203

It immediately brings in a conformational change on the second binding site whereby the dissociation constant reduces to a Ks .	3.4165518945529807

The conformational change leads to the dissociation constant or Michaelis Menten constant for the second binding site and then second binding site also gets bound .	3.8072574618231037

It is logical that if this dissociation constant is low the substrate will have much more affinity for the second binding site .	3.6463564230869436

Similarly if it initially binds with Ks on to other binding site it can influence the conformational change on the other binding site and it can meet .	3.21535118540643

Both the binding sites are occupied and such a system can be represented by a mechanistic model whereby you have the first binding as Ks either here or here .	3.009471350882908

The second binding process is represented by dissociation constant of a Ks either here or here .	3.349381940958406

The product formation with ES will be E + P .	5.015847868612554

Similarly when both the binding sites are occupied , the product formation rate will be twice the Kp because then it can go either to SE or ES , there is no difference .	3.359834928003214

The situation which I have shown here is rather too simplistic .	4.304500032618128

That means we have tried to explain with the two binding sites .	4.020850434578403

In many cases particularly with the regulatory enzymes , the number of binding sites may be four or six or eight even tetramers are a very common example in the literature and therefore the rate expression will be quite complex and their analysis can become difficult .	3.0687044480933867

To simplify the situation there is an equation available corresponding to Michaelis Menten equation which can be applied to allosteric enzymes .	3.9110771604731753

This was given by Hill .	7.549251965229227

One of the basic assumptions here which we made is that the interaction factors , what I mentioned earlier as Ks and a Ks , the ratio alpha is very , very small than one .	3.1287060801297724

That means the co - operativity is very high .	4.695188614550287

Once a substrate molecule binds to one of the binding sites it makes a drastic conformational change so that the affinity is increased very significantly .	3.9746841314688077

If you consider n binding sites what will happen in such a situation is that with each binding site being occupied by the substrate , the next subsequent binding sites will have much more affinity .	3.2841797699575546

Ultimately at equilibrium or in steady state condition the net effect will be that the bulk of the enzyme will be in the form of ESS .	4.265325160133699

Theoretically at equilibrium the enzyme must be available in the form of E , ES , ES2 , …… , ESn .	4.317361131581209

Normally if there are n binding sites and the binding process continues sequentially then the enzyme must be available in different species in difference forms as E , ES , ES2 , up to ESn .	3.113806220306366

But if the interaction factor alpha is very , very small , at each stage affinity will increase by a very significant level or what we understand as co - operativity is very high .	2.91975304900972

In that case the assumption by Hill was that most of the enzyme will exist in the form of ESn .	4.0891140457176025

There will be small concentrations but they can be neglected .	5.610514782675913

Based on that assumption then he gave a rate expression which is v / Vm = Sn / K ’ + Sn This is called Hills equation .	2.7144416794110717

Here n is the number of binding sites per enzyme molecule and K ’ is the Hill ’ s constant .	4.04550663742963

This K ’ is different than the Michaelis Menten constant .	5.484250712014983

Michaelis Menten constant is the substrate concentration at which reaction velocity is 50 % of that of the maximum reaction velocity .	5.482122011377991

That situation will not apply here , if you analyze .	4.64913400457287

If you put n = 1 , then the equation will get into Michaelis Menten kinetics .	3.131682632492751

Vm here is the maximum reaction velocity when all the binding sites are occupied by the substrate .	5.104518960920692

The substrate concentration is high enough but again this is not identical to the Vm of the Michaelis Menten equation because Vm of the Michaelis Menten equation is an asymptotic value .	3.529334486127644

You can never approach it practically .	5.031668806462484

It is a theoretical value .	6.319905557013775

Whereas in this case of Vm , you can approach to that value when all the enzyme binding sites are totally occupied by the substrate molecule .	4.176230641461957

So , basically in feasible you inject the polymer samples in a column which is consist of highly cross linked gel beads ; the beads are typically having diameter of 5 microns to 10 microns and they have definite pore size which can start from say for 10 to the power 100 Armstrong or 50 Armstrong to 10 to the power 5 Armstrong .	2.3777896533693545
